city.name: New York City
city.about: '''New York''' (known as "The Big Apple", "NYC," and often called "New York City") is a global center for media, entertainment, art, fashion, research, finance, and trade. The bustling, cosmopolitan heart of the 4th largest metropolis in the world and by far the most populous city in the United States, New York has long been a key entry point and a defining city for the nation.

points_of_interest.name: Forest Hills Station House
points_of_interest.description: A whiskey bar and gastro pub in the Forest Hills area, close to Forest Hills Stadium.

points_of_interest.name: Bill's Bar
points_of_interest.description: A small watering hole found in Mill Basin, Bill's is one of the only bars in the area. Stop in here to get a taste of what the community is like.

points_of_interest.name: Sista's Place
points_of_interest.description: Sista's is central Brooklyn's highest profile jazz venue, with performances at Sa 9PM and 10:30PM in their relatively small, friendly cafe space (performances are sporadic on other nights—call for schedule). It's also a political space, and the collective in charge sponsors Sunday afternoon panels on various issues relevant to the local community.

points_of_interest.name: Botanica
points_of_interest.description: A not-too-cheap homemade liqueur and cocktail bar.

points_of_interest.name: Sit & Wonder
points_of_interest.description: Hip little coffee shop serving Stumptown coffee and pastries. A nice place to hang out with free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Other Half Brewing
points_of_interest.description: Small warehouse brewery in an industrial area of Carroll Gardens. Other Half has a big selection of beers on tap, 9 of which are IPAs. The taproom is small and can get pretty crowded. It has a funky vibe completed by the antelope head mounted on the wall.
points_of_interest.hours: M Tu noon–8PM, W–F noon–10PM, Sa 10AM–10PM, Su 11AM–7PM

points_of_interest.name: Washington Commons
points_of_interest.description: Bar with a good selection of beers as well as a dimly lit but cozy atmosphere. Large outdoor area in the back with picnic tables is great in warm weather.

points_of_interest.name: Franklin Park
points_of_interest.description: Huge bar with a dance floor, lounge areas, two bars, and outdoor space brings in a diverse crowd (if not predominately hipsters). Connected to the restaurant "Dutch Boy Burger" if you are hungry.

points_of_interest.name: The Whiskey Ward
points_of_interest.description: This whiskey specialist bar can be quiet on weekdays. It's a good spot for anyone who enjoys whiskey or/and wants to explore more whiskeys, as they have a selection of unusual bourbons, ryes, Scotches, and Irish whiskeys. The prices for whiskeys that are also found in non-specialist bars may be higher here, but the bartenders are real experts, who can guide you in selecting 3 half-pours for a whiskey flight (or two flights, if you aren't driving and have the tolerance). The flights are priced as a sum of exactly half the cost of a shot for each whiskey or rye you drink. There are also beers on tap, etc., so if you are with a non-whiskey drinker, do not despair.

points_of_interest.name: Woodside Cafe
points_of_interest.description: The store is opened for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

points_of_interest.name: The Ear Inn
points_of_interest.description: Located on the ground floor of the James Brown House, the Ear Inn is one of the oldest bars in New York.

points_of_interest.name: Charlie's Sports Bar
points_of_interest.description: This place is a friendly, neighborhood pub and sports bar. With 15 big-screen TVs you can take in a variety of football, soccer, and rugby games while enjoying a beer or your preferred drink.

points_of_interest.name: The BeerKeeper
points_of_interest.description: A nice pub. A friendly crowd, and decent friendly service.

points_of_interest.name: The Beer Garden at Bohemian Hall
points_of_interest.description: Bohemian Hall or BoHall The most famous Queens nightlife venue of them all, and a must-see for visitors. This large outdoor beer garden (the oldest in New York City), has a fine selection of German and Czech beers, the authentic vibe of a Bavarian beer hall, and frequent live music, often in lederhosen.

points_of_interest.name: Coney Island Brewery
points_of_interest.description: Brewery offering about twelve beers, an outdoor patio, and food.

points_of_interest.name: Barbès
points_of_interest.description: A truly wonderful neighborhood bar and live music venue. Barbes tends tends to bring in bands that play early swing, Balkan brass bands (which are fabulous), and singer/songwriter types. The shows tend to be very high quality, and the drinks are reasonable, and well made. The help is extremely friendly, and will make you feel at home in no time.

points_of_interest.name: Dominie's Hoek
points_of_interest.description: The massive backyard patio makes this chilled local hangout an especially great place to be in the summer, with high quality live bluegrass and Americana music on weekend evenings.

points_of_interest.name: Wheeler's Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Wheeler's has creditable food, with a fairly extensive menu and many mains below $20, but it's also a sports bar with a good and well-priced drink selection, including some excellent whiskeys, and friendly bartenders and clientele. Look for their bar hours to be extended again as the pandemic ebbs.

points_of_interest.name: Buttermilk Bar
points_of_interest.description: The main local for South Slope folk. Free pizza on Wednesdays. Sadly, the photo booth has been taken away.

points_of_interest.name: L.I.C. Bar
points_of_interest.description: Long Island City’s signature watering hole, an attractive spot that’s packed every evening, with a wide range of beers & cocktails and a great burger.

points_of_interest.name: Commonwealth
points_of_interest.description: A new bar worth looking into in southern Park Slope. Good jukebox.

points_of_interest.name: Jacques Torres
points_of_interest.description: A small chocolatier on a sparse street in DUMBO near some of Brooklyn's best views of the Manhattan skyline. Go for the goodies, but stay for the "Wicked Hot Chocolate".

points_of_interest.name: Sweet Afton
points_of_interest.description: Natty as any Manhattan cocktail lounge, but with a more relaxed vibe befitting an outer borough neighborhood bar, this is the most popular of the many bars along booming 34th Avenue. Don't leave without imbibing a few of their home-brew fruit-infused liquors.

points_of_interest.name: Barcade
points_of_interest.description: Features at least 30-40 classic 1970s and 80s arcade games, all for 25 cents! Also has 20 microbrews on tap and specialty beer nights.

points_of_interest.name: Surf Bar
points_of_interest.description: A tiki bar, true to form with sand on the ground, coconuts and all kinds of other beach artifacts. They serve tiki cocktails plus your usual bar drinks. A fun place, especially in flip flops.

points_of_interest.name: Westlight
points_of_interest.description: On top of the new William Vale hotel, this upscale lounge is the highest bar in Williamsburg with panoramic views of Manhattan.

points_of_interest.name: American Legion Post 398
points_of_interest.description: Two words sum this place up: juke joint. A real one. It's a dive bar hosted by the local American Legion with basic soul food, good company, and jam sessions three nights a week. Sunday is the night to come if you want to see some really good musicians come in and light up the Hammond organ. F-Sa they have basically an R&B dance party, but as of 2013 the Fridays have become member only (hopefully this policy won't extend to other nights in the future, as this place gets better known outside the neighborhood!). No cover (although you are required to "sign in" for some reason), but you will be expected to be spending money: think of it as a vague drink minimum, and order food if you take a table.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Barge
points_of_interest.description: Open only during the summer, this outdoor bar floats on the East River.

points_of_interest.name: Three Sheets Saloon
points_of_interest.description: formerly The Town Tavern

points_of_interest.name: Bill's Place
points_of_interest.description: Bill Saxton, clearly a man destined to play the sax. His Coltrane-like performances are among the best you'll see in the city, but you'll see them here in his own basement apartment with a crowd of just 25 aficionados on a street heavy with jazz history. Previously unbeknownst to Bill, his apartment was one of many jazz-filled speakeasies on 133rd, and was where Billie Holiday got her start and Fats Waller's left hand strode mightily upon the keys. BYOB (and bring cups if you don't want to drink out of the bottle). Make reservations by the kind of confusing process of leaving a voice message (or you could try the less-reliable online form), then show up around 8:30PM and buzz yourself in.

points_of_interest.name: Maison Première
points_of_interest.description: An oyster bar with old-world charm that specializes in Absinthe drinks.

points_of_interest.name: Stonewall Inn
points_of_interest.description: A veritable icon of the worldwide gay community, not just New York's. While it's not the original incarnation of the bar that was the site of the Stonewall riots of 1969 (the building has gone through several uses since then), the current incarnation pays homage to the old and has regained its prominence as a meeting place in the LGBT community. You must be 21 and a proper ID is required. 2-drink minimum.

points_of_interest.name: Ginny's Supper Club
points_of_interest.description: This is the upscale (and pricey) option for live jazz and other music in Harlem, with a beautiful, classy space, room for dancing, and fine dining (think soul food steakhouse with craft cocktails). Sundays see the gospel brunch, for which reservations are a must. Check the calendar for who's playing and dress to impress.

points_of_interest.name: Spritzenhaus33
points_of_interest.description: A large indoor beer garden with a wide selection of craft beer. On weekday afternoons, it's a popular place for parents with children. On weekend nights it becomes very packed with young people who come into Williamsburg.

points_of_interest.name: Jackbar
points_of_interest.description: A small divish bar with a large collection of vintage pinball machines.

points_of_interest.name: Caffe Cafe
points_of_interest.description: A café with outdoor seating, allowing diners to observe the flow of people on Bay Ridge's 3rd Ave.

points_of_interest.name: Radegast Hall & Biergarten
points_of_interest.description: A large indoor beer garden that often has live old-time jazz.

points_of_interest.name: Omonia Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Greek café known for its delicious pastries. You can also get a full meal, but don't miss out on dessert.

points_of_interest.name: The Bowery Electric
points_of_interest.description: Good local music club (the music room is in the basement). There is usually a cover charge of at least $8 to get in, and drinks are marked up (e.g., $9 for Stoli and soda). Good acoustics. You might get lucky and get a seat (if that's what you want to do), but most of the crowd stands for the entire performance. Bring earplugs in case the volume is pumped out louder than you like.

points_of_interest.name: Lot 45
points_of_interest.description: A large lounge with a quasi-outdoor area and some games like ping-pong.

points_of_interest.name: Judy's
points_of_interest.description: Coffee shop by day, bar by night. Popular with locals, and you'll often see regulars chatting with the friendly staff.

points_of_interest.name: Webster Hall
points_of_interest.description: This large, beautiful, landmarked dance and event hall with three performance venues dates from 1886. It was closed for renovations starting in 2017 but reopened on April 26, 2019 with a concert by Jay-Z.

points_of_interest.name: Bondurants
points_of_interest.description: Delicious, rustic brunch spot by day and unique cocktails draft beers by night, this spot is ideal for everyone. The food here is based on classical dishes such as steak and eggs but is specialized with delicious garnishes that make this place unique and a great spot for anyone looking for either a relaxing place to rest during the day or a crazy party at midnight.

points_of_interest.name: Café Grumpy
points_of_interest.description: The coffee and attitude here are both fantastic, but the elongated shoebox shape and gigantic space-wasting counter area opposite those clumsy tiny tall-tables makes it feel like a hallway. If it were an actual hallway between two other random places, the big building around it might make it seem cozier, but since it stands alone, the sense of jostling bumping linear traffic may make you feel distracted after half a drink. This property makes it perfect for meeting people before a show at the Atlantic Theater one block west.

points_of_interest.name: Freehold
points_of_interest.description: This is a coffee shop during the day and a stylish lounge in the evening. In warm weather, they have a large courtyard with various games.

points_of_interest.name: B Bar
points_of_interest.description: Restaurant and bar, this place caters mostly to the bar and club crowd.

points_of_interest.name: Ethyl's Alcohol and Food
points_of_interest.description: A 1970s-themed bar with specialty drinks and quick yet delicious bites, Ethyl's certainly isn't a place to miss if you're into funky dancers, live music, and DJs.

points_of_interest.name: Ginger Man
points_of_interest.description: Sister bar to the Volcano (below). Larger bar with a broad selection of drinks that also serves bar food and snacks. Also an after-work crowd, this bar is also popular with your average Joes. Good place for groups.

points_of_interest.name: Gallow Green
points_of_interest.description: Although Gallow Green is closed during the winter months, it is without a doubt a place you want to visit while it's open. It's a garden restaurant and bar in the McKittrick Hotel. Definitely for the hopeless romantics.
points_of_interest.hours: M–W 4–10:30PM; Th Su noon–10:30PM; F Sa noon–12:45AM

points_of_interest.name: Nook
points_of_interest.description: Friendly hipster coffee shop in the Bushwick Collective street art district, usually packed with writers, artists, and students. Large windows, chill music, and drinks served in old-fashioned ceramic mugs.

points_of_interest.name: Ten Ren Tea Time
points_of_interest.description: Some of the best bubble tea in town, but price is slightly towards the expensive side compared to other bubble tea stores in the neighborhood.

points_of_interest.name: d.b.a.
points_of_interest.description: Has a good selection of beers including many from microbreweries, as well as a bunch of single malt whiskeys, and prices are slightly high for the neighborhood but not outrageous. It can get crazy on Saturday nights, but it's a pleasant, relaxing place on weeknights.

points_of_interest.name: Hilo Bar
points_of_interest.description: Nightspot offering cocktails, DJs & bottle service in an industrial-chic subterranean space.

points_of_interest.name: Vivi Bubble Tea
points_of_interest.description: A small (with a grand total of three seats) but very popular branch of this bubble tea shop chain, with inexpensive drinks and some rather quirky decorations, like Homer Simpson sitting on a bench out front and little coin-operated prize machines to entertain you while you wait in line. The tea can have a weird chemical taste and also be kind of dilute at the same time; your mileage may vary.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Cocktail Lounge
points_of_interest.description: Old-timers to the neighborhood may remember this as a no-frills bar that had booths with torn upholstery and was presided over by a friendly old Ukrainian bartender/owner. After he died, the bar remained shut and vacant for several years. The new owners had it renovated and somewhat redesigned, but it still has the feel of an old-time room. To afford today's expensive rents and follow the new trends, they now specialize in excellent cocktails and also have a menu of small plates. However, one thing hasn't changed: The bartenders are still personable.

points_of_interest.name: Paddles
points_of_interest.description: NYC's alternative/fetish/BDSM club

points_of_interest.name: Mr. Fong's
points_of_interest.description: This local bar is pretty chill on the weekdays, but it can get packed on the weekends. Chinese-inspired cocktails & bar bites, plus a jukebox.

points_of_interest.name: The Immigrant
points_of_interest.description: Wine bar with great list and some microbrews. Cozy, elegant without being pretentious. Great place to meet with friends or bring a date.

points_of_interest.name: Troy Liquor Bar
points_of_interest.description: Foosball, board games & pool meet cocktails & beer at this low-frills basement lounge.

points_of_interest.name: International Bar
points_of_interest.description: This might be one of the few bars left in the East Village that isn't overrun by frat boys, sorority girls and loud drunken youths from New Jersey. It usually isn't crazy even on weekends. They are not whiskey specialists but have a pretty good and relatively well-priced selection of whiskeys and ryes (though prices have started to creep up, and Sophie's, listed below, is cheaper), among the rest of their drinks. The sound track tends toward country and classic rock, the bartenders are personable and helpful, and the clientele tends to be a quirky, friendly motley crew of various ages.

points_of_interest.name: Raines Law Room
points_of_interest.description: Drinks are prepared in a beautiful, half-hidden back room (they call it 'The Kitchen') surrounded by gleaming examples of every tool a barkeep could wish for. 'The Lounge' is modeled after a 19th Century English town home with Chesterfield sofas and a wood-burning fireplace. Servers are summoned with the touch of an electric bell. 'The Parlor' consists of elegant banquette seating areas enclosed by dark curtains. Reservations are recommended.

points_of_interest.name: KGB Bar
points_of_interest.description: A hard-drinking literary bar.

points_of_interest.name: McSorley's Old Ale House
points_of_interest.description: The oldest pub in continuous operation in New York, this small Irish pub packs up fast. Sawdust on the floors and dust on the century-old decorations, this place is a favorite with tourists and locals alike. There are only two drinks to choose from: McSorley's light ale or McSorley's dark ale, always served in a pair of half-pint mugs. The ancient chandelier above the bar has turkey wishbones dating from WW1 when a turkey dinner was thrown for the departing soldier and the wishbone was hung up till he returned. Abraham Lincoln drank there and Teddy Roosevelt's signature graces the walls. Boisterous atmosphere and cheap food too!
points_of_interest.hours: M-Sa 11AM-1AM, Su Noon-1AM. No kids after 6PM

points_of_interest.name: Otto's Shrunken Head
points_of_interest.description: A fun, boozy reimagining of the once popular post-war American tiki bar. Yeah it's pretty tacky, that's the idea. Grab a sickly sweet Hawaiian-styled cocktail, or just get a basic beer. Sometimes hosts live bands with more of like a Punk/Country/Rockabilly vibe. No cover.

points_of_interest.name: Sophie's
points_of_interest.description: This is one of the few authentic East Village dive bars remaining. Their drinks are probably the least expensive in the neighborhood, and the selection is good. Lots of interesting decor including a large papier mache model of a blimp. Pool table and jukebox in the back. Their sister bar, '''Josie's''', which is a block to the north at 520 E 6th St, tends to be more quiet but is otherwise quite similar.

points_of_interest.name: Vazac's Horseshoe Bar
points_of_interest.description: 7B A rock 'n' roll hangout that dates back to Prohibition, 7B has been featured in numerous movies for its classic Manhattan atmosphere.

points_of_interest.name: Flagship Brewery
points_of_interest.description: As of 2020, this is Staten Island's first brewery in nearly 60 years. There are some locally crafted beers in the tap room. The tap list is always changing.
points_of_interest.hours: W 5–11PM, Th–Sa noon–11PM, Sa noon–8PM, closed M Tu

points_of_interest.name: Nurnberger Bierhaus
points_of_interest.description: Offers a wide variety of imported German beers and well-prepared, authentic German food. There is an outside beer garden that offers a limited menu, open in seasonable weather. Beers are served in liter steins and the food is as good as any you will find in Germany.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu–Sa non–10PM, Su noon–9PM, closed M

points_of_interest.name: The Dead Rabbit
points_of_interest.description: Atmospheric Irish pub, good cocktails.

points_of_interest.name: The Irish Pub
points_of_interest.description: Great place to drink after a long day at work.

points_of_interest.name: McGee's Restaurant and Pub
points_of_interest.description: This is an unpretentious pub in the middle of a pricey neighborhood. The pub also provides downright good food. Their dining room is upstairs. Service is pleasant and helpful.
points_of_interest.hours: M-Sa 11AM-4AM, Su noon-4AM. Lunch 11AM-4PM; dinner 5PM-midnight; late night menu: 11PM-1AM

points_of_interest.name: The Perfect Pint
points_of_interest.description: Two-story pub off of Times Square with good Irish beers on tap and pricey main courses. Definitely not typical pub-grub, but the price matches.

points_of_interest.name: Alice's Tea Cup
points_of_interest.description: Good tea selection, excellent scones and an Alice in Wonderland theme. Very popular with families with daughters

points_of_interest.name: Crumbs
points_of_interest.description: Bakery specializing in cupcakes, including the Oreo cupcake and the Hostess cupcake cupcake

points_of_interest.name: The Hungarian Pastry Shop
points_of_interest.description: Coffee and super-rich pastries in a "bohemian" setting. A Columbia University neighborhood fixture, the cafe has been in business since 1963. There is no WiFi, but that doesn't stop it from being perpetually crowded.

points_of_interest.name: Levain's Bakery
points_of_interest.description: Bakery best known for their big, dense cookies.

points_of_interest.name: Magnolia
points_of_interest.description: Part of the cupcake bakery chain

points_of_interest.name: Oren's
points_of_interest.description: A local chain with good coffee and excellent teas.

points_of_interest.name: Amity Hall Uptown
points_of_interest.description: Food and drink in a large pub-like space.

points_of_interest.name: Amsterdam Ale House
points_of_interest.description: Local pub specializing in microbrews.

points_of_interest.name: Dive Bar
points_of_interest.description: One of the few bars with any type of scene during the week. Good whiskey selection, good bartenders.

points_of_interest.name: Dublin House
points_of_interest.description: Neighborhood bar.

points_of_interest.name: George Keeleys
points_of_interest.description: Excellent beer selection

points_of_interest.name: Dominick's Hot Dog Truck
points_of_interest.description: A food truck serving what is often regarded as some of the best hot dogs in the city. The onions and sauerkraut are superb.

points_of_interest.name: Lillian Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: Some say it's the best pizza in Forest Hills, others give it to Nicks. Try their tomato & garlic slice, it's unique and delicious.

points_of_interest.name: Elegante Restaurant and Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: Often called the best pizza in the Rockaways, this place has one wall near the register lined with bills with compliments written on them.

points_of_interest.name: Pahal Zan
points_of_interest.description: A real Jewish establishment, right under the LIRR tracks in Forest Hills. The falafel, red cabbage, spicy sauce, hummus and tzatziki pita pocket is amazing.

points_of_interest.name: Di Fara Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: An old-school pizzeria. Waiting for Dom, the only pizzaiolo in the shop, to painstakingly make your pizza or calzone is worth it. People returning to the neighborhood stop by here to indulge their nostalgia for quality that never wavers. This is not really cheap pizza, but it is very good pizza. Toppings include baby artichokes, porcini when available, and baby eggplant, as well as more usual toppings that are unusually good. Don't let the worn appearance of the shop's exterior fool you.

points_of_interest.name: Bubby's
points_of_interest.description: One of the more affordable restaurants in Tribeca, this place caters to families and those who don't mind sitting next to high chairs. They do indeed have a wonderful variety of pies on any given day, one of the best cheeseburger in town, and an interesting choice of beers.

points_of_interest.name: Saraghina
points_of_interest.description: Located in the heart of Bed-Stuy, Saraghina is a fantastic pizza restaurant offering up freshly baked thin-crust pizzas for $16 or less - and that's for a good sized pie that one person could tuck away with some effort, but which is more easily shared by two. Favorites include the classic margherita and the proscuitto i funghi. Their oven is a true wood-burning brick unit, and their ingredients are fresh and succulent. In addition to pizza, Saraghina offers a menu of traditional Italian fare, including burratina, sautéed artichokes, swordfish carpaccio, and spaghetti with ragù di pesce, to name a few. The beer selection is a bit limited, but there are plenty of wines on the list, and the atmosphere - a deceptively small area converted from a storefront with lots of old wood paneling and hidden back dining room and garden - more than makes up for the brevity of the menu.

points_of_interest.name: Original's Pizza
points_of_interest.description: Original's Pizza, or "OG's" as the locals refer to it, is home to some of the most authentic pizza you can find in South Brooklyn. You'll come for the plain, but you'll stay for the other creative slices they offer.

points_of_interest.name: Ninja New York
points_of_interest.description: A ninja-themed restaurant with dark hallways, sneaky ninja/waiters with swords, and many elaborate dishes that involve smoke or fire. Caution: Many who have eaten there don't recommend the food, so if you go, go for the experience.

points_of_interest.name: Pho Bac
points_of_interest.description: An excellent Vietnamese restaurant whose menu goes far beyond the noodle soup that supplies its name. It is also quite inexpensive. Expect to pay no more than $15, even if you have a humongous dinner. One word of warning, though: the banh mi (roast pork sandwiches) are, seemingly inexplicably, very disappointing.

points_of_interest.name: Sugar Hill Supper Club
points_of_interest.description: An old school Bed-Stuy southern/soul food restaurant with outstanding crabcakes and frequent live jazz (always one, at least, on the first Thursday of the month) as well as R&B, dance floor downstairs. The atmosphere is simple but elegant—a white tablecloth kind of place.

points_of_interest.name: Dolly's Ices
points_of_interest.description: A summertime favorite for South Brooklyn residents, Dolly's boasts a wide array of flavors which keep locals coming back for more.

points_of_interest.name: Square Diner
points_of_interest.description: An inexpensive diner; a neighborhood institution.

points_of_interest.name: Jackson Diner
points_of_interest.description: Best known Indian restaurant in Jackson Heights, serving vegetarian and non-vegetarian North Indian cuisine. Lunch buffet on weekdays.

points_of_interest.name: Baked
points_of_interest.description: A well-priced cafe and bakery.

points_of_interest.name: The Islands
points_of_interest.description: A great Caribbean restaurant with superb jerk chicken, ox tail, and other regional specialties.

points_of_interest.name: Mill Basin Deli
points_of_interest.description: Known for some of the best pastrami in Brooklyn, the Mill Basin Deli is a true Brooklyn/Jewish Deli. If you find yourself in the area, a sandwich from here is a must.

points_of_interest.name: Arunee Thai Cuisine
points_of_interest.description: Tucked away behind a modest storefront on a quiet side street off bustling Roosevelt Ave., this little gem of a place has served authentic Thai food for over 20 years. Great noodle dishes, soups, fried rice, and seafood.

points_of_interest.name: Hyssop
points_of_interest.description: Supper club.

points_of_interest.name: Tom's Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: A classic diner with an old-school feel and friendly service. They even give you snacks while you wait in the (usually long) line for their famous breakfast/brunch.

points_of_interest.name: Agnanti
points_of_interest.description: Delicious traditional Greek fare with outdoor seating along Astoria Park and a cozy indoor dining room that seems a million miles away from New York City. Don't miss the grilled saganaki or the Greek salad, and for the main course focus on the many amazing seafood offerings.

points_of_interest.name: Chung Ki-Wa Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Korean cuisine, also has a sushi bar. Korean Barbecue, with meats cooked right at your table. Also full Korean menu including bibimbap (rice with meat, egg, and vegetables in hot stone pot), hot and cold noodle dishes, soondubu (tofu stew), and many others. All diners get a selection of side dishes ("banchan"), included in the dinner price. Beer and Korean beverages (soju).
points_of_interest.address: 40-06 74th St (just south of Broadway/Roosevelt Ave intersection)

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Farmacy & Soda Fountain
points_of_interest.description: The Farmacy An old-fashioned ice cream parlor and soda fountain located in a restored apothecary shop. Offerings including eggcreams (a classic New York Jewish drink with no egg and no cream), unique fountain sodas, and specialty sundaes. Vegan options.

points_of_interest.name: Congee Village
points_of_interest.description: Hong Kong-style food. It is a very popular banquet spot for Chinese people, with a wide and interesting menu including some of the best hot and sour soup you'll find in Manhattan and the garlicky house special chicken. Some people find the food overly oily, though. Seafood dishes are expensive, but most of the rest of the menu remains a good value as of 2022, as it has been for decades. Call for reservations if you have a large party or are going for dinner on a weekend.

points_of_interest.name: Bare Burger
points_of_interest.description: Innovative burger joint that offers organic burgers made from a choice of beef, ostrich, elk, and lamb. Very good milkshakes.

points_of_interest.name: Chao Thai
points_of_interest.description: This is an Isaan restaurant, featuring dishes from the northeastern part of Thailand which is near and culturally related to Laos. That area of Thailand features salads, larb, sausages, soup with spare ribs, and curries without coconut milk. The food at Chao Thai is excellent and connoisseurs find it well worth a trip from Manhattan.

points_of_interest.name: Doughnut Plant
points_of_interest.description: This ain't no Dunkin' Donuts! Each doughnut costs roughly $2.50, but the place is a really fabulous, artisanal palace (albeit humble-looking) of doughnutry.

points_of_interest.name: Casa Enrique
points_of_interest.description: Snazzy little nuevo Mexican joint just off the main strip of LIC eateries on Vernon Blvd. A lot of great options here: braised lamb shank, chicken enchiladas with salsa verde, stuffed chiles in a cream sauce and more.

points_of_interest.name: The Alcove
points_of_interest.description: Gastropub that also serves tapas, breakfast & brunch and is open late.

points_of_interest.name: Hot Pot Village
points_of_interest.description: formerly Congee Bowery Congee Village's sister restaurant specializes in hotpot.

points_of_interest.name: Kabab Cafe
points_of_interest.description: This tiny, unpretentious gourmet Egyptian restaurant run by renowned Alexandrian chef Ali El Sayed is a major pilgrimage site for foodies everywhere. Recommended are the sauteed artichokes and sauteed beet, apple & garlic starters, along with a variety of excellent traditional north Egyptian entrees like braised lamb cheeks and calamari with eggplant & grilled vegetables.

points_of_interest.name: SriPraPhai Thai Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant is big with a lot of seating, there is a very cute outdoor seating as well for the summer. There is a huge line during weekend specially at night.

points_of_interest.name: Bay Thai
points_of_interest.description: Rich Thai food.

points_of_interest.name: Katz's Deli
points_of_interest.description: A classic NYC delicatessen. The famous fake orgasm scene in ''When Harry Met Sally'' was shot here. Have what she was having: A pastrami sandwich. If you're a pastrami lover, you will long remember your trip to this establishment. Don't lose your ticket, and don't forget to tip the counterman at least $1 per sandwich. If you want something other than pastrami, their corned beef and brisket vie for second best and even their turkey is fine (though it's probably not what you're there for); make sure to ask for anything "juicy" (i.e., fatty).

points_of_interest.name: Koliba Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Czech and Slovak restaurant serving traditional cuisine along with a variety of fine Czech and Slovak beers and a full bar to accompany your meal. They lean slightly towards Slovak, but their Czech cuisine is very good also. Try their bryndzové halušky.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu–Th 3–9PM, F Sa 3–10PM, Su noon–8PM, closed M

points_of_interest.name: Matsuri
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant offers the perfect selection of both traditional and modern Japanese food, from sushi, ramen, to izakaya. We strive to provide the highest quality food and excellent service with reasonable prices. Our goal is to deliver a superlative dining experience, in a relaxed setting.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Harvest Market
points_of_interest.description: This is the place to get groceries; it's a grocery store with organic and otherwise fancy foods.

points_of_interest.name: Yonah Schimmel's Knishes Bakery
points_of_interest.description: Claims to have served "The World’s Finest Knishes since 1910" - a bakery that has been selling knishes on the Lower East Side since 1890 from its original location on Houston Street. As the Lower East Side has changed over the decades and many of its Jewish residents have departed, Yonah Schimmel's is one of the few distinctly Jewish businesses and restaurants that remain as a fixture of this largely-departed culture and cuisine.

points_of_interest.name: La Guli
points_of_interest.description: Old school Italian bakery with the best cakes in Queens, a variety of fresh cookies, cannolis and gelatos, and Italian ice the consistency of fresh snow. A few tables available in the back if you'd like to hang out and sip an espresso.

points_of_interest.name: Peking BBQ
points_of_interest.description: This is a Chinese, Peruvian, Barbecue.

points_of_interest.name: The Bagel Hole
points_of_interest.description: The Bagel Hole's bagels hearken back to the days when bagels were small hockey pucks with a definite chew and a nice malty flavor. Easily among the best in New York, and some of the best priced, at about 90 cents for a bagel and a price that just keeps going down the more you buy. This is a good place to stock up on bagels for self-catering.

points_of_interest.name: Gino's Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Popular local Italian restaurant with great pasta.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu–Th 11AM–10PM, F Sa 11AM–11PM, Su 11AM–9:30PM, closed M

points_of_interest.name: B&H Dairy
points_of_interest.description: This unassuming place is one of the few remaining old-time inexpensive restaurants in the neighborhood. It serves kosher dairy and pareve (non-meat but including fish) food. Since the soup costs only 50 cents more for a bowl than for a cup, always order a bowl. Good challah and good honest food - nothing fancy, but a very fair value. You can view the menu as of 2018 at their Facebook page; some prices have gone up, but it'll give you a fair idea of the selection.
points_of_interest.hours: W–F 8AM–10PM, Tu Su 8AM–9PM, Sa 8AM-11PM, closed M

points_of_interest.name: Balthazar
points_of_interest.description: Balthazar has the feel and quality of a good Parisian brasserie. Though informal and relaxed in feel, it is not inexpensive; however, many New Yorkers and visitors alike find it a worthwhile experience. Brunch is especially popular there, so unless you plan to show up for an early breakfast, make sure you make reservations; you don't want to be one of the people waiting on line for an hour or more, just to get in.
points_of_interest.hours: M-Th 7:30AM-5PM and 5:45PM-midnight, F 7:30AM-5PM and 5:45PM-1AM, Sa 8AM-4PM and 5:45PM-1AM, Su 8AM-4PM and 5:30PM-midnight

points_of_interest.name: Loukoumi Taverna
points_of_interest.description: Out of the way but worth the trip, this always-buzzing Greek taverna has remarkable seafood entrees like butterfly shrimp or salmon doused in lemon and traditional spices and provides free thick Greek yogurt and honey for dessert. Don't miss the Cypriot salad, a delicious mix of savory (grilled halloumi cheese & olives) and sweet (cranberries and figs).

points_of_interest.name: Emoji Burger
points_of_interest.description: 7 days. Great burgers right in the neighborhood, not too far from the 82nd St subway station! Fun concept, and even better varieties of loaded fries (recommend the Woozy Fries!), hot dogs, and milkshakes. Run by a Colombian who owns a health food restaurant (Just Made 4 U) on the same block!

points_of_interest.name: La Bruschetta
points_of_interest.description: A small pizza place close to John Jay and Millennium Brooklyn High School. Expect students to come in at 10AM-noon for their lunch breaks. However the pizza is well worth waiting in line behind hungry students.

points_of_interest.name: Hazar Turkish Kebab
points_of_interest.description: A good kabob place.

points_of_interest.name: Banh Mi Saigon Bakery
points_of_interest.description: This is in back of a jewelry and gem shop; no kidding! Both the Banh Mi Saigon (pork) and Banh Mi Ga (chicken) sandwiches are fantastic. Get them to go and eat them in a nearby park such as the one on the corner of Spring and Mulberry, a few blocks north and one block west. Note: Do not confuse this place with Saigon Banh Mi So at 369 Broome St, which serves sandwiches that are fine but nowhere near as good.

points_of_interest.name: Crif Dogs
points_of_interest.description: Widely renowned by hot dog lovers for their pork and beef, deep fried frankfurters. Perennial favorites include the Spicy Redneck and any of the bacon-wrapped dogs.

points_of_interest.name: Dos Caminos
points_of_interest.description: One of four up-market Mexican restaurants in Manhattan by the same name and under the same ownership (the other's are in Gramercy, Chelsea, Midtown East) Sticky, saucy ribs and guacamole.

points_of_interest.name: Mombar
points_of_interest.description: Artsy dining room filled with Joseph Cornell-like tables and paintings by chef/artist/owner Moustafa El Sayed (brother to the owner of nearby Kabab Cafe). Mombar focuses on southern Egyptian cuisine, notably a number of delicious clay pot dishes, and a mezze plate with the smokiest, most delicious baba ganoush you're ever likely to taste. Don't miss the milky bread pudding for dessert. Popular with hipsters in the early evening; fills up with Egyptian locals later at night.

points_of_interest.name: John's Deli
points_of_interest.description: Great roast beef heroes.

points_of_interest.name: Hunan Delight
points_of_interest.description: Neighborhood Chinese restaurant; excellent vegetarian options (fake meat, etc) and sweet and sour soup. Delivery available.

points_of_interest.name: Kathy's Dumplings
points_of_interest.description: Good dumplings.

points_of_interest.name: Bo Ky
points_of_interest.description: Very inexpensive food, reliable soups that are especially welcome in cold weather. Very quick service. They have side dishes of offal (pig's ears, etc.) for those who like them. They are also known for their Teochew country-style duck. There is another branch with an identical menu at 216 Grand St., between Mott and Elizabeth. Cash only.

points_of_interest.name: Málà Project
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant specializes in Sichuan dry pot, which is different from hotpot, in that hotpot is a soup that the diner traditionally prepares by being given two kinds of broth and ingredients of their choice to boil in real time, whereas dry pot has some sauce but is not soup-like, is prepared in the kitchen before being brought out to the diner and can be ordered to go without a notable dropoff in quality or freshness. The restaurant also serves appetizers, but the flavorful, aromatic (and if you order it spicy, quite chili-laden) dry pot is what you should order. You must order at least 3 ingredients in your the dry pot, but 4-5 are common for an individual and 7-8 for a couple. Ingredients range from $3-12, but cluster around $4-8, so the price can mount fairly quickly, and tabs of around $24-27 plus tip for an individual and $40 for a couple are common. Tastes vary, but some of the ingredients that stand up well to the powerful sauce and spices are the soup filled beef balls, the lamb, the beef tongue and the lobster balls, and among the better ingredients for enjoying the sauce are the bean curd sheets, noodles and enoki mushrooms. Rice is also available for an extra charge of $1 for white rice and $2 for purple rice. This restaurant has other branches at 41 West 46th St. and 245 East 53rd St.

points_of_interest.name: Dos Caminos
points_of_interest.description: One of four up-market Mexican restaurants in Manhattan by the same name and under the same ownership (the others are in Gramercy, Chelsea, SoHo) Sticky, saucy ribs and guacamole.

points_of_interest.name: Famous Ben's Pizza
points_of_interest.description: Famous Ben's Pizza is one of the oldest and best pizza places in SoHo. Some people get taken on a pizza tour here. It is a small place with few tables, but the environment fits New York perfectly. You can watch as they make the pizza, and lines are usually out the door. Their pizza doesn't cost a lot. If you are just looking for a quick and simple meal while you are out shopping, Famous Ben's is a great place to consider. They deliver, too.

points_of_interest.name: Rose & Joe's
points_of_interest.description: Workaday local bakery notable for its truly outstanding fresh squares of Sicilian pizza available at the back of the shop.

points_of_interest.name: Dera Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: A cozy spot offering Indian, Pakistani, and Bengali cuisine with flavorful curries and grilled dishes. Known for its excellent catering services and affordable prices.

points_of_interest.name: Kashkar Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Really flavorful, inexpensive Uyghur food, big portions, friendly service. The personnel are observant Muslims, so no alcoholic drinks; consider washing your meal down with ayran (yogurt drink) or green tea.

points_of_interest.name: Mr. Wonton
points_of_interest.description: Another Chinese eatery, though the dishes here are somewhat different from most. Although they have all the standard stuff, their pork buns cannot be found elsewhere in the neighborhood. The "Chef's Specials" section of the menu really is where the best (and most unique) dishes are.

points_of_interest.name: DeKalb Market Hall
points_of_interest.description: Large, lively food court located underground. Mood lighting and a bit of a maze, with lots of different cuisines for eating there or taking out.

points_of_interest.name: Paneantico Bakery Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Amazing Italian sandwiches and a great bakery, too.

points_of_interest.name: Chinatown Ice Cream Factory
points_of_interest.description: Enjoy the "regular" flavors like taro, green tea, lychee, black sesame, mango, and coconut (or the "exotic" flavors like strawberry, vanilla...), and don't neglect the sorbets. The owner also experiments and creates new flavors. Even though there is a Haagen Dazs down the street from this ice cream store, Chinatown Ice Cream Factory is the go-to place for ice cream when you visit Chinatown. On a nice, sunny day, you'll most likely find a long line of customers outside the store waiting to purchase their ice cream. That is how popular this store is. If you really like the ice cream, you may purchase one of their Chinatown Ice Cream Factory t-shirts.

points_of_interest.name: Mud
points_of_interest.description: A real neighborhood hangout that offers terrific coffee and light meals.

points_of_interest.name: Ess-a-Bagel
points_of_interest.description: This legendary place serves up doughy, chewy bagels the size of hubcaps that some New Yorkers consider 'the best bagels in NYC - which means everywhere'. Bagel-eaters will also find a wide variety of mixed cream cheeses, tofu spreads, and smoked fish. Bagels are cheap, but prices depend on whether you eat in or take out! Expect to pay $3 for two bagels and a small tub of your favorite cream-cheese spread. Lines can be long at lunchtime.

points_of_interest.name: Il Corallo Trattoria
points_of_interest.description: Il Corallo offers an extensive menu of pasta, pizza, antipasto, and salads. You will find unfamiliar yet tasty dishes. It's a small, unpretentious place with efficient, friendly service. Both locals and visitors dine here.
points_of_interest.hours: Su–Th noon–10PM, F Sa noon–11PM, closed M

points_of_interest.name: Taverna Kyclades
points_of_interest.description: One of Astoria's staples, this Greek seafood restaurant is very popular with locals and tourists alike. Expect long wait periods between 6 and 9PM any day of the week.
points_of_interest.hours: M–Th noon–11PM, F Sa noon–11:30PM, Su noon–10:30PM

points_of_interest.name: L & B Spumoni Gardens
points_of_interest.description: Consistently rated by many as one of the best pizzerias in the city. Talk to any Brooklynite and they will tell you to get an "L & B Square".

points_of_interest.name: Bogota Latin Bistro
points_of_interest.description: Pan-Latin cuisine ranging the South American continent with main dishes from Colombia. Full service bar featuring mojitos and imported Latin American beers and wines. Happy hour and live music.

points_of_interest.name: Bien Cuit
points_of_interest.description: the Smith St Bakery Bien Cuit offers a variety of house-baked breads and pastries served in a central Smith Street location with wifi and Crop to Cup coffee and espresso drinks.

points_of_interest.name: Rocky's & Nicky's Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: Pizza place with good slices.

points_of_interest.name: Fay Da Bakery
points_of_interest.description: This bakery offers a wide assortment of traditional and fusion buns, pastries, cakes, as well as an assortment of drinks and bubble teas. All their buns are freshly baked every morning so the quality and consistency is always there. It's a self-serve bakery so you can easily pick and choose while taking your time.

points_of_interest.name: Oh! Taisho
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant specializes in yakitori - Japanese-style grilled items on skewers. They sell other food items, but in general, it is best to stick to yakitori and similar items, and definitely do not get things like ramen there, because the further away it is from being grilled, the worse it is likely to be. Most of their yakitori is dependably good, and it's definitely a great value. They also sell pretty good sake for about $8 for a large carafe, and the servers are knowledgeable about the sakes. Because the restaurant is cheap and open late, it gets all kinds of freaky, drunk customers, and the aisles and seating are definitely at close quarters. Just consider it an experience and enjoy.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Central Oyster Bar & Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: An institution, opened in 1913 along with the station itself.

points_of_interest.name: Ai Fiori
points_of_interest.description: This Ligurian restaurant has delicious cocktails (the fiori d'arancia, made with Old Forester bourbon, is absolutely delightful) and equally fine food, made with the freshest, highest-quality ingredients and with some kind of pleasant surprise in every dish. And unlike most other New York restaurants, it has plenty of space between tables. It is expensive but worth the money. The room is large, so while reservations are recommended, this is one upscale restaurant where it's usually possible to reserve at short notice.
points_of_interest.address: on the 2nd floor of the Langham Place Hotel, 400 5th Av. between 36th and 37th Sts.
points_of_interest.hours: Breakfast daily 7-10:30AM (limited menu in bar/lounge only Sa Su); lunch daily 11:45AM-2:30PM (limited menu in bar/lounge only Sa Su); dinner Su-Th 5:30-9:30PM, F Sa 5-10:30PM; bar menu Su-Th 5:30-11:30PM, F Sa 5PM-midnight

points_of_interest.name: St Tropez
points_of_interest.description: French bistro and wine bar.

points_of_interest.name: Arturo's
points_of_interest.description: A popular local pizza restaurant with an "old-time" theme, serving coal oven pizza with a lightly charred, crispy crust and other dependable Italian-American dishes. There is live jazz there every night.

points_of_interest.name: Telly's Taverna
points_of_interest.description: Excellent seafood & Greek fare at this taverna, set on the hippest stretch of Astoria. Great grilled whole fish is what most people come for, and they also have a nice Greek wine list.

points_of_interest.name: Nathan's Famous
points_of_interest.description: Nathan's original location, opened in 1916, offers great hot dogs, fries, grilled chicken, etc. Prices are somewhat high, with a hot dog costing $3.25. On July 4th, they host their world-famous hot dog eating contest.

points_of_interest.name: Bonnie's Grill
points_of_interest.description: Serves the best burger in Park Slope, and quite possibly, in all of Brooklyn (it matches Peter Luger's burger). The burgers are spiced nicely, and served alongside nice fries that go well with chipotle mayo. Bonnie's buffalo wings are also something worth savoring.

points_of_interest.name: Grimaldi's
points_of_interest.description: Located near Fulton Ferry Landing and DUMBO, only serves its coal-fired pizza by the pie, not the slice, and does not accept credit cards. Some people still consider it worth it, while others think it's a tourist trap. That said, for best results, line up before opening time, when their oven is at its hottest.

points_of_interest.name: Taj Mahal Indian Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: A really good Indian place.

points_of_interest.name: Fong On
points_of_interest.description: 宏安 This family-run shop has been serving elaborate Chinese-style tofu pudding since 1933. Sweet or savory toppings available. If you've never tried tofu pudding before, it's worth having: surprisingly flavorful and different from other kinds of tofu you might be more familiar with. The shop also sells other Chinese snacks and drinks like sticky rice cakes, grass jelly, and herbal tea. Nearly everything is vegan (you can ask them to leave off the dried shrimps from the savory pudding).

points_of_interest.name: Somtum Der
points_of_interest.description: This is a branch of an Isaan restaurant headquartered in Bangkok. Expect spicy food unless you request for it to be made milder, and also be aware that items marked on the menu as including fermented fish have a very strong rotten-fish taste, which is authentic but may or may not meet with your approval. Among their best items are the ''gaeng om kai'' (Isaan-style chicken soup in a large bowl with cabbage and herbs, though you may want to ask for it with "less salt"), ''sa poak kai tod der'' (Der-styled deep fried chicken thigh), ''moo ping kati sod'' (grilled coconut milk-marinated pork skewers) and ''tum mangsavirat'' (vegetarian papaya salad). The restaurant is mellower at lunch, when the lights are on and Quincy Jones Band albums from the 1960s play on their sound system. At night, the low lights, techno music and crowds of young customers may make you think you should be dancing at a club. The restaurant is more crowded since Michelin gave it a locally-controversial star, but if you are a small party, you are unlikely to have a long wait except perhaps at peak hours on Saturday night.

points_of_interest.name: Tao
points_of_interest.description: Trendy Asian cuisine; reservations required. Beautiful decor.

points_of_interest.name: Bryant Park Grill
points_of_interest.description: New American food in elegant dining room behind the public library, with a view over the park.

points_of_interest.name: Babbo
points_of_interest.description: The most famous of the restaurants formerly owned by Mario Batali, and especially well-known for its pasta tasting menu. Reserve a month in advance or stand on line before opening time (5:30PM on weekdays and 5:00PM on Sundays) to try to get a seat at the bar or one of the tables kept open for walk-ins. Babbo is one of the hardest restaurants to get a reservation at in New York, which should indicate something about its popularity. Do not expect a cheap meal, but this is one you don't have to dress up for.

points_of_interest.name: Trattoria L'Incontro
points_of_interest.description: Surprisingly high-end Italian fare for the neighborhood in terms of atmosphere, service and price, this Italian dinner spot focuses on Roman cuisine and has a wide range of truly delicious pasta and risotto dishes (risotto con pere e gorgonzola is especially nice) and seafood dishes like zuppa di pesce.

points_of_interest.name: JUQI
points_of_interest.description: Probably what you're looking for out here: authentic and good Chinese food, but for a price. Your servers won't speak English, and your bizarre digital menu is in a confusing half Chinese/half English mix, but just get the classics: the duck is fantastic, of course, as are the lamb dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Randazzo's Clam Bar
points_of_interest.description: This is a classic Italian-American seafood specialist right across the street from the water in Sheepshead Bay, in operation since 1932. It's consistently good, the portions are large, and the atmosphere is informal and convivial. The marinara sauce comes in mild, medium and hot varieties.

points_of_interest.name: Geido Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Excellent sushi bar in Prospect Heights.

points_of_interest.name: Peter Luger Steak House
points_of_interest.description: Rated New York's No. 1 Steak House for 23 years in a row by Zagat! Located near the entrance to the Brooklyn side of the Williamsburg Bridge, this over 100-year-old establishment offers what many connoisseurs consider the best steak in America and it is priced as such. Reservations recommended. ''Does not accept any national credit cards; debit cards OK.''

points_of_interest.name: Juliana’s Pizza
points_of_interest.description: From the website: "Juliana’s heralds the return of Patsy & Carol Grimaldi—not only to the NYC restaurant scene, but to the original location under the Brooklyn Bridge where they founded Grimaldi’s Pizzeria. Unbeknownst to many, Pat & Carol ended their association with Grimaldi’s more than a decade ago when they sold the business (along with the name) to a customer." So you could say that this is the real Grimaldi's. New Yorkers skip the lines at Grimaldi's and get their coal-fired pizza here.

points_of_interest.name: Tanoreen
points_of_interest.description: Palestinian, Middle Eastern, and Mediterranean cuisine by chef Rawia Bishara. They started in a smaller ten-table location nearby in 1998, but good word-of-mouth and press led them to move to this larger location. Don't miss out on the flavorful appetizers/meze (hot and cold) and the succulent entrees. It'll be hard, but try to leave room for the yummy desserts.

points_of_interest.name: Great NY Noodletown
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant, which is open late, has the feel of a Chinese diner. It can be very crowded at peak hours. Try the noodle soups ($5.25-7.95) and congees ($2.50-8.50), the ginger-scallion lo mein ($5.50), the barbecued items, and the salt baked dishes, but don't neglect the less inexpensive specials, like the dishes with chives or pea shoots (around $11.95-15.95, with different charges depending on choice of beef, chicken, shrimp, scallops, etc.).

points_of_interest.name: Tim Ho Wan
points_of_interest.description: This is a branch of a Hong Kong-based dim sum chain. It serves dim sum all day, and it's very popular, so you are best off going close to opening time, or at least for weekday lunch, and figure on the possibility of having a drink at a nearby bar while you wait for them to text you. They do dim sum right, with thin wrappers and excellent ingredients, and it's very tasty.

points_of_interest.name: VietHaven
points_of_interest.description: Very nice Vietnamese restaurant with full bar. Nice food and decent prices. Try seafood combo.

points_of_interest.name: Boqueria
points_of_interest.description: Modern, Barcelona-style tapas are served in a warm environment alongside many other meat and seafood dishes with fresh, Spanish ingredients and authentic meals.

points_of_interest.name: Celsius
points_of_interest.description: Indoor and outdoor seating in the winter overlooking the skating rink. Good food and service, a little pricey but reasonably for the location (open seasonally).

points_of_interest.name: Bill’s Bar & Burger
points_of_interest.description: Bill’s serves a wide range of American fare and burgers.
points_of_interest.hours: Su - Tu 11:30AM-midnight, W 11:30AM-1AM, Th 11:30AM-2AM, F Sa 11:30AM-4AM

points_of_interest.name: Blue Hill
points_of_interest.description: An upscale American restaurant known for its fresh ingredients and subtlety. Call ahead for reservations.

points_of_interest.name: Tournesol
points_of_interest.description: Fun traditional French bistro in the heart of LIC's Vernon Boulevard restaurant strip with excellent versions of all the standards like steak frite and snails. Especially worth trying are the pan-seared skate with mustard sauce or the pastry of hake and clams with leeks.

points_of_interest.name: Henan Feng Wei
points_of_interest.description: Nothing fancy, but quite authentic. Get the stir-fried cumin lamb biang biang noodles. The lamb soup is excellent as well.

points_of_interest.name: Tatiana Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: This Russian restaurant has beach-view tables on the boardwalk. There's a Vegas-style floor show. Tatiana's Grill is a few doors down.

points_of_interest.name: Ghenet
points_of_interest.description: Delicious Ethiopian food. Try kitfo or the gored-gored, or, if raw meat isn't to your taste, try any of the more conventional Ethiopian offerings. They have set plates that are good, but can be somewhat limiting.
points_of_interest.hours: M 5PM-10PM, Tu-Th 5PM-10:30PM, F 5PM-11PM, Sa noon-11PM, Su noon-10:30PM

points_of_interest.name: SEA
points_of_interest.description: In a spacious and lively setting, complete with a reflecting pool and Buddha statues, you'll find what some consider among the best Thai fusion food, especially for the money, though sticklers for authenticity complain the food is too sweet. All of the curries are highly recommended, as are the emerald vegetable dumplings with black plum sauce and the green salad with mesclun, bean sprouts, taro chips and peanut dressing. DJs join the fray in the evenings.

points_of_interest.name: Junior's Restaurant and Bakery
points_of_interest.description: Sure, you can eat their famous cheesecake in Grand Central, but why not try the original? With an ad announcing loud and clear that this is it, it's one of the first places you'll see coming off the Manhattan Bridge if you're driving on the Flatbush Ave Extension. Home to what is known as "the most fabulous cheesecake," and also featuring New York deli items like tongue sandwiches, this restaurant has been a Brooklyn favorite for decades. The gracious waiters, dressed immaculately in suits and ties, are part of the atmosphere.

points_of_interest.name: Il Colosseo
points_of_interest.description: Old-school Italian-American food. Made with fresh, quality ingredients, and delicious.

points_of_interest.name: Joe's Shanghai
points_of_interest.description: This is the most famous of the Shanghainese restaurants in Chinatown, but not the best. Like most every other Shanghainese restaurant, it serves the popular "soup dumplings" (xiaolong bao in Chinese) which contain either pork or crab+pork with soup all within a dumpling. However, due to its popularity, here are some tips: Don't wait on line, go only at odd hours and order adventurously (get things like eel).

points_of_interest.name: Ukrainian East Village
points_of_interest.description: This big dining room has a pleasant, somewhat faded Old World elegance, with parquet floors and chandeliers, and unlike most other restaurants in New York, it has high ceilings and somewhat of a sense of spaciousness. Tango classes are offered in an adjoining room in back of the restaurant twice a week.

points_of_interest.name: Delegates Dining Room
points_of_interest.description: Located on the 4th floor of the UN General Assembly, this high-class dining hall lets you eat alongside delegates, ambassadors, and celebrities at the heart of international politics. The menu changes every day, providing a unique international buffet every day as you sit with a gorgeous view of the East River. Reservations should be made at least 24 hours in advance. Do note that with security concerns, you'll be escorted to and from the dining room. Dress attire is business casual.

points_of_interest.name: Lex Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Restaurant with an array of classic, cozy Italian-American cuisine. Classic dishes such as French onion soup, penne alla vodka, seafood risotto and spinach and ricotta ravioli, are all delicious at this restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Cho Dang Gol
points_of_interest.description: A slightly upscale Korean restaurant that specializes in dishes made with artisanal tofu, several varieties of which are made on premises.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Bagel & Coffee Company
points_of_interest.description: Commanding a loyal following, this bagel place is noted for its huge, filling bagels with a heaping spread of cream cheese (or one of the many other spreads available).

points_of_interest.name: Joe's Pizza
points_of_interest.description: A very popular corner pizza joint that serves huge, thin crust slices fresh out of the oven. This is classic New York fast food - service is quick but the place is tiny, so you'll want to take your slice outside to eat.

points_of_interest.name: Amy Ruth's
points_of_interest.description: Classic, tasty soul food, friendly service.

points_of_interest.name: Martha's Country Bakery
points_of_interest.description: Rated as the one of the top bakeries in Queens, this place has some of the best desserts in Astoria. Expect long lines during the holiday season.

points_of_interest.name: Maxi's Noodle
points_of_interest.description: A must-go for the wontons and dumplings. It is often full on weekends, so be prepared to wait.

points_of_interest.name: Totonno's
points_of_interest.description: A family pizzeria that's been continually operating since 1905. The crust produced in their coal-fired oven is one of the very best around - thin, crisp, and charred with a sweet sauce. Whole pies only, no slices. A few blocks from the Coney Island boardwalk. Cash only.

points_of_interest.name: Yamato
points_of_interest.description: Similar to Oshima, although their rolls are different.
points_of_interest.hours: M-Th noon-3PM and 5PM-11PM, F noon-3PM and 5PM-midnight, Sa noon-midnight, Su 1PM-11PM

points_of_interest.name: Roberta's
points_of_interest.description: Some of the best pizza in the entire city. Great inside and outside. Ingredients taken from rooftop farms around Brooklyn and Queens.

points_of_interest.name: Mile End Deli
points_of_interest.description: A Montreal-inspired deli serving up poutine and smoked meat that has gained a huge following since it opened a few years ago.
points_of_interest.hours: Breakfast and lunch M-F 8AM-4PM, brunch Sa-Su 10AM-4PM, dinner 6-11PM

points_of_interest.name: Lioni Italian Heroes
points_of_interest.description: Choose from over 150 hero varieties, most named for Italian-American celebrities past and present. Each differs by the selection of cold cuts, cheeses, and toppings. Deli salads and other appetizers can accompany your sandwich.

points_of_interest.name: iM Star Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Small restaurant decorated with caricatures of Hong Kong celebrities on the walls. If you hit the morning stream of customers, you'll definitely have to wait for a seat since their breakfast is... to die for! Extremely cheap! This restaurant is the best restaurant to eat at if you're looking for something similar to the diners in Hong Kong. A mix of Chinese and American tastes. Definitely try their French toast, pan fried rice noodle, and iced milk tea!

points_of_interest.name: Veniero's
points_of_interest.description: A fun little Italian pastry shop. You can eat in the dining room or purchase items to go at the counter.

points_of_interest.name: Franchia Vegan Café
points_of_interest.description: Asian fusion. Try the fruit teas and the fried cauliflower.

points_of_interest.name: Papaya King
points_of_interest.description: One of the best hot dog joints in the city, Papaya King was also the originator of the papaya drink/hot dog combination, which has inspired similar chains around Manhattan, although this, their flagship location, is as of August 2020 the only location of this former chain. A classical counter-service restaurant, it's great for travelers on a budget. If hot dogs aren't your thing, then they also have other classic items such as frankfurters and onion rings.

points_of_interest.name: Don's Bogam
points_of_interest.description: Pleasant restaurant with real decor and ambiance, specializing in Korean barbecue - especially meat marinated in hot sauce - among other things. Don's Bogam and Madangsui (see listing below) are widely considered to be the best Korean BBQ specialists in Manhattan.

points_of_interest.name: Cafeteria
points_of_interest.description: The name is a misnomer; it's a hip restaurant -- a few blocks south on 7th for a broad range of stuff, nicely presented, with sidewalk dining.

points_of_interest.name: John's Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: A classic New York pizza place - a gritty joint with coal-fired brick oven, thin crust pizza. The lines are often long but the service is fast. Whole pies only, no slices.

points_of_interest.name: El Malecon
points_of_interest.description: A Dominican restaurant famous for its ''pollo a la brasa'' (rotisserie chicken) has its flagship in this neighborhood. Go there and enjoy the food, the fresh-squeezed juice, and the Latin music on the jukebox.

points_of_interest.name: 39 Kings Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Delicious dim sum all day as well as a full menu. Come for the dim sum, stay for the specialty drinks with fun names.

points_of_interest.name: Five Leaves
points_of_interest.description: One of Greenpoint's most popular new restaurants. Great, original food, place with vintage feel and a cocktail bar across the street. Coffee to go sold out the window. This place is very popular, so prepare to wait a little.

points_of_interest.name: Yemen Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Serves as an informal community center for the local Yemeni community, but don't be put off by the social club atmosphere; the staff are very friendly and welcoming, and the food (especially the lamb) is very tasty and inexpensive (two people can pig out for about $40). Note: This is a halal establishment that serves no alcohol and would not be an appropriate place to bring your own. Have the spiced tea, instead.

points_of_interest.name: Mommas Noodle House
points_of_interest.description: Our chefs specialize in authentic and delicious Cantonese food. The staff at Mama's Noodle House is devoted to serving customers mouthwatering dishes that feature the highest quality ingredients available. Pad Thai Noodle, Basil Chicken Ho Fun and Minced Pork Noodle are all prepared quickly and delivered to you right away.

points_of_interest.name: Noodle Village
points_of_interest.description: This is a very good restaurant and a good value. They serve their noodles nicely al dente and use good roast pork and roast duck. Their vegetables are fresh, too. Excellent rice dishes and casseroles, too — for example, they make a delicious spicy curried oxtail rice dish.

points_of_interest.name: Veselka
points_of_interest.description: Half-century-old Ukrainian diner now has a snazzier decor and hipper clientele but still offers traditional Eastern European fare like pierogi, blintzes, and stuffed cabbage.

points_of_interest.name: Williamsburg Pizza
points_of_interest.description: Fresh, classic New York pizza slices.

points_of_interest.name: Han Bat
points_of_interest.description: Han Bat has the feel of a Korean diner, though with some surprisingly nice decor. Their forte is Hyaemul Dolsot Bibimbap (rice cooked in a stone pot with mixed seafood, herbs, Korean hot sauce, etc.). Some of their other dishes are very salty.

points_of_interest.name: Sullivan Street Pizza
points_of_interest.description: f/k/a Co. This pizzeria features baker Jim Lahey's famous no-knead pizza dough. They offer a handful of classic pizzas as well as many more unique choices.

points_of_interest.name: Lupa Osteria Romana
points_of_interest.description: This is another restaurant previously associated with Mario Batali, but the Executive Chef is Diego Negri and the current owner is Joe Bastianich. This is a good and sometimes very good, relatively informal, mid-priced eatery, with a good and fair-priced wine list. Every fan has their own favorite dishes. First-timers may want to share several smaller dishes instead of having full meals, in order to sample the cuisine, but the ''primi'' and ''secondi'' are also worthy. The excellent Tartufo is their best dessert. Reservations recommended; otherwise, you may have a long wait.
points_of_interest.address: 170 Thompson St. between West Houston and Bleecker Sts

points_of_interest.name: Lechonera La Isla Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: This is a great Puerto Rican luncheonette, serving excellent pollo a la brasa (roast chicken), glazed with a tasty sauce and cooked till tender, with garlic sauce available to add to taste. They are also known for their pernil (pork shoulder) and serve various daily specials. If you like spicy food, try their "hot sauce", which is actually a delicious slaw of lightly pickled sliced onions, tomatoes and hot peppers. This place is a throwback, with nothing but several stools at the counter. Service is friendly. Open hours are until the closing time or whenever they run out of food.

points_of_interest.name: Hunan House
points_of_interest.description: Authentic, very tasty and spicy Hunanese food in a quiet, historical part of Flushing about a half mile from the subway stop. Expect to spend about $20/person for a large dinner, and to leave with your mouth buzzing.

points_of_interest.name: Kabob Shack
points_of_interest.description: Shockingly cheap for New York, even in Brooklyn. Kabob Shack serves up a simple menu of kabobs and falafel with fries, rice, and a few other side dishes and appetizers. The cooks pay attention to the food and you can feed two people quite well for less than $20.

points_of_interest.name: L'Appartement 4F
points_of_interest.description: Antique paintings adorn the upstairs seating area of this little bakery specializing in French pastries and bread. Come early before the good stuff is gone.

points_of_interest.name: Villabate Alba
points_of_interest.description: Wonderfully delicious Italian pastries - particularly Sicilian ones - and helpful, unaffected service. No place to sit, so get some items to go. Very inexpensive, too: A couple of pastries will cost you about $5.50.

points_of_interest.name: New Sheng Wang
points_of_interest.description: This is a very cheap place to eat, as you can easily fill up on a single dish. For example, their standout dish is 10 steamed pork dumplings for $3. Some dumpling connoisseurs consider Sheng Wang's dumplings the best in Chinatown today. Most of the rest of their dishes are noodle soups with hand pulled or peeled noodles made in house, and be warned that for a single person, trying to eat an order of dumplings plus a bowl of noodle soup is likely to be quite excessive. Also, one type of tripe they use in soups can be overly chewy. But you can't beat the value.

points_of_interest.name: Dim Sum Palace
points_of_interest.description: Delicious Cantonese dim sum; one of six locations, all in Manhattan.

points_of_interest.name: Van Leeuwen Ice Cream
points_of_interest.description: Upper East Side branch of this increasingly large New York chain of ice cream shops, albeit pretty good ones that have vegan flavors as well as regular soft-serve. They also sell coffee.

points_of_interest.name: Havana NY
points_of_interest.description: Well-priced Cuban casual restaurant & bar for lunch and dinner. They serve a variety of daily specials, including Plantain Soup and Suckling Roast Pork.

points_of_interest.name: Dos Caminos
points_of_interest.description: Authentic and upscale Mexican cuisine, including fresh guac. and margaritas.

points_of_interest.name: Mamoun's Falafel
points_of_interest.description: A hole in the wall place that serves arguably the most famous falafels in New York City.

points_of_interest.name: Sushi Village
points_of_interest.description: Asian restaurant which makes a little pricey sushi and other Asian goods, but all keeps it nice. Service is kinda slow. Think the restaurant's full? Think again! This restaurant has a tiny staircase that brings you down to the basement, where the service is obviously slower. Those are the good and bad about Sushi Village. Try the Kamikaze Roll if you want a hint of spice!
points_of_interest.hours: Monday-Thursday 11AM - 10:30PM, Friday 11AM - 11PM, Saturday noon-11PM, Sunday noon-10:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Smorgasburg
points_of_interest.description: Open from spring to fall on Saturdays, this large outdoor food fair is in East River Park with many different gourmet food vendors.

points_of_interest.name: Krispy Pizza
points_of_interest.description: You're in Brooklyn. Skip the chain pizza joints. This family pizzeria has been here since 1967. They offer over 15 varieties of pizza, including their specialty pie, Grandma’s Pizza, a thin crust Sicilian with fresh mozzarella, fresh tomatoes, extra virgin olive oil and a touch of basil. Other popular options include fresh mozzarella pie, vodka sauce pizza, and a chicken parmesan pie. You can also get appetizers, salads, calzones, rolls, heroes, and pasta. Even vegetarians won't go hungry.

points_of_interest.name: Spicy Village
points_of_interest.description: 大福星, previously known as He Nan Flavor This very informal eatery across the street from Sara Delano Roosevelt Park serves food from the province of Henan. All items are good, but the highlight is the Spicy Big Tray Chicken ($12.95), a very large soupy, stewy bowl of flavor, including cumin seeds and a generous helping of potatoes, that's not quite like any other style of Chinese food. Take at least one friend with you if you can, so you can share the chicken and some cold dishes. The proprietress is very nice.

points_of_interest.name: Cafe Mogador
points_of_interest.description: Serves Moroccan, French, and Middle-Eastern cuisine, all dependably good. The cafe is especially popular for weekend brunch, but a very good breakfast/brunch is available every day of the week. More dishes are on the brunch menu on weekends, but you are likely to wait a half hour or more for weekend brunch during peak hours.

points_of_interest.name: Xi'an Famous Foods
points_of_interest.description: Local branch of an increasingly large New York chain of authentic Xi'an-style noodle shops, using recipes by a Xi'an native. The name of this place certainly doesn't lie – even Anthony Bourdain, world-renowned chef, praised this restaurant, and for good reason. They make a variety of rich, hearty noodle dishes topped with carefully picked spices.

points_of_interest.name: Keens Steakhouse
points_of_interest.description: A New York chophouse with excellent steaks and great bar for pre & post dinner drinks or just drinks. Fine dining in comfortable surroundings. Founded in 1885, the restaurant has an interesting ceiling covered in 90,000 clay pipes which the customers used to smoke after dinner. Pipes were left at establishments, as they were too brittle to transport!

points_of_interest.name: Elmo
points_of_interest.description: A very trendy spot. Filled with chic comfort food, delicious cocktails, and beautiful people. They have a main floor dining room as well as a downstairs lounge perfect for any event and complete with a DJ booth, sound system and full bar.

points_of_interest.name: Murray's Bagels
points_of_interest.description: This is a place that believes in the pure New York bagel — which means no toasting. Don't even bother asking. But the bagels are so fresh that it doesn't matter. It's often packed with long lines and the service is chaotic, but they give you a healthy amount of spread and toppings.

points_of_interest.name: Mike's Bagels
points_of_interest.description: Fresh bagels made in-house daily.

points_of_interest.name: Bagel Oasis
points_of_interest.description: Often regarded as the best bagels in Queens, with an excellent variety of cream cheese spreads and sandwiches available. Inexpensive. Small store with no seating. It is a little far from anything of tourist interest. From Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing, take the Q17 bus toward Jamaica. Ride about 20 minutes. Get off at 183rd Street. The bus stop is almost directly in front of Bagel Oasis.

points_of_interest.name: Two Boots Pizza
points_of_interest.description: The Williamsburg location of the New York-based Italian-Cajun fusion pizzeria.

points_of_interest.name: La Bella Marketplace
points_of_interest.description: This neighborhood supermarket offers all the basics if you're self-catering, including prepared meals to heat at your lodging. On-the-go options include hot homemade savory items and pastries. They have an entire aisle devoted to Italian imports. La Bella isn't a large store, but if you're not in search of a specific brand, you should be able to fill most needs.

points_of_interest.name: Tai Pan Bakery
points_of_interest.description: This bakery store offers numerous Chinese breads, delicacies, and both hot and cold beverages/snacks. It shares its name with a popular bakery store chain in Hong Kong.

points_of_interest.name: Ippudo NY
