points_of_interest.description: This is a branch of a ramen-specialist chain that's well-known in Japan. They are best known for tonkotsu ramen, but also make nice spicy ramen. Some of their appetizers are really good and very much worth getting. No reservations, and there could be a long wait; your best bet is to show up, give them your cell phone number, and hang out at a local bar while waiting for them to contact you.
points_of_interest.hours: Lunch: M-Sa 11AM - 3:30PM, Su 11AM - 5PM; dinner: M-Th 5-11:30PM, F Sa 5PM-12:30AM, Su 5-10:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Café Fledermaus & Café Sabarsky
points_of_interest.description: Café Sabarsky is in a beautiful room with wood furnishings on the ground floor, across from Central Park, and Café Fledermaus has tiled floors and is inspired by the Cabaret Fledermaus in Vienna but is in the basement and has no view; however, the two cafes have the same lunch/dinner menus. These cafes are not cheap, and part of what you're paying for is the location and the decor/atmosphere, but you also get value, in the form of genuine Viennese cuisine and pastries. These cafes are a good option if you're visiting the Metropolitan Museum and prefer to eat something nearby that's better than the merely OK food at the Met's Snack Bar. You may have a significant wait for a table at peak hours, but it's worth a try.

points_of_interest.name: Madangsui
points_of_interest.description: Serves Korean barbecue accompanied by a generous (8 dishes) and delectable banchan (complimentary side dishes), plus a bowl of dwenjang jigae (soupy stew made with fermented bean paste). According to some reports, it is no longer anything special.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Sichuan Chelsea
points_of_interest.description: Excellent Sichuan cuisine, for those who like it hot. Stick with the Sichuan and Hunan menus and special menus like the Prodigal Daughter's menu. Do not get "lunch specials" or order from the American-Chinese or Cantonese menus, and do not get Shanghainese "Soup Dumplings" (xiaolong bao) unless you want typical American-Chinese takeout food and dishes made better elsewhere. Get reservations if you are going during peak dinner hours on any day; this location is really popular, and you may have to wait a long time for a table if you just show up.

points_of_interest.name: Percy's Pizza
points_of_interest.description: Pizza for minimalists. Percy's is a favorite among the collection of one-dollar pizza slice joints in the city. Inside is a cozy little room with about eight seats and a nice pizza cook. Know what you want when you step up to order and avoid trying to sit with any large groups; you'll quickly fill up the whole place.
points_of_interest.hours: M 11AM-2PM, 6-10PM; Tu 10AM-2PM, 6-8PM; W 11AM-1PM, 6-9PM, 11PM-midnight; Th 11AM-midnight; F 11AM-3AM; Sa 2PM - 3AM; Su 1-2PM, 6-7PM, 10-11PM

points_of_interest.name: Patsy's Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: This is great old-school New York coal-oven pizza. Don't go overboard on the toppings, which are not the reason why you should go there. Get a plain pizza, and enjoy the wonder of a thin, nicely charred crust with delicious sauce and cheese that aren't heaped on but applied judiciously in a style that derives clearly from its origins in Naples. A couple should be able to down a pie or two with some salad without trouble for a meal, because the crust is so thin, but note that you can also get slices for takeout.

points_of_interest.name: The Sandwich Bar
points_of_interest.description: If you like "make your own", this is your place. Choose from seven types of ''schnitzel'' (or any of the other entrees or salads); then select sauces and toppings to your taste. Order something different every time; it won't get boring. Kosher.

points_of_interest.name: Peter Pan Donut & Pastry Shop
points_of_interest.description: This is a time capsule of a 1950s donut shop with delicious pastries.

points_of_interest.name: Mama Rao's
points_of_interest.description: A "red-sauce" trattoria in the Brooklyn tradition. It features Italian classics, including antipasto, pasta, and entrées.

points_of_interest.name: Cafe Hong Kong
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant was opened in 2013 by personnel from the defunct South China Garden, which used to be around the corner on Mott St. The portions are large and the food is delicious. This is in the estimation of many people the best Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown right now, and best to go to with at least a couple of friends and a big appetite, so that you can share a few dishes. If you like chicken, get the garlic fried chicken, which is one of their standout dishes.

points_of_interest.name: John's of 12th Street
points_of_interest.description: This old-school Italian-American red-sauce place has friendly service, ample portions, loads of atmosphere and a century's worth of history. Expect to pay around $40-50/person for a 3-course meal with a glass of wine. Appetizers are often served family-style.

points_of_interest.name: Felice 83
points_of_interest.description: Felice 83 isn't just another Italian restaurant, but instead provides delicious and rustic Tuscan cuisine with fresh dishes, particularly carbonaras and omelettes, and a bounty of wine. Be sure to get there early as it's a favorite among locals, and for good reason, with the classicly romantic atmosphere

points_of_interest.name: 2nd Ave Deli
points_of_interest.description: This famous kosher delicatessen, which used to be on 2nd Av. and 10th St., reopened at its new location a few years ago. The place is a real throwback, which really feels like an old-school Jewish deli. The menu is more extensive than old-school delis were, however, and includes what used to be considered "appetizing" (i.e., pareve - neither meat nor milk) foods. Try their tongue, corned beef, pastrami, and kasha varnishkes, and enjoy their freebies of artisanal cole slaw, pickles, and gribenes (chicken fat cracklings). The food may be bad for the heart, but it's good for the soul.

points_of_interest.name: Malibu Diner
points_of_interest.description: Traditional American diner in the middle of NYC.

points_of_interest.name: Red Bamboo
points_of_interest.description: Excellent vegetarian soul food, organic wines.

points_of_interest.name: Red Rooster
points_of_interest.description: The new restaurant of Marcus Samuelsson, who is from Ethiopia with adoptive Swedish parents. The cuisine is a mix of different influences, with nods to traditional soul food, classic Swedish fare, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia. Tables can be hard to come by without a reservation, and you might not get a friendly hostess, but the restaurant by itself is reason enough to take the trip uptown.
points_of_interest.hours: Brunch Sa Su 10AM-4PM; dinner M-W 5:30-10:30PM, Th-Sa 5:30-11:30PM Su 5-10PM; lunch M-F 11:30AM-3PM

points_of_interest.name: Parkway Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Neighborhood restaurant serving diner-style food. Breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Burgers, salads, wraps, soups, Greek specialities, and desserts. Soft drinks, beer, and wine available.

points_of_interest.name: Eileen's Special Cheesecake
points_of_interest.description: Some of the best cheesecake in the city, with individual-sized slices so that you can sample multiple flavors.

points_of_interest.name: Malai Marke
points_of_interest.description: This Indian restaurant has the most complex flavors of any Indian restaurant in the neighborhood, and your food can be spicy, but depending on your taste, you may find everything too sweet. Two main dishes plus bread or rice feeds a couple amply, and one main plus a "small" plate and bread or rice would probably be adequate for a couple with a moderate appetite.

points_of_interest.name: Heidelberg Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: German-style schnitzel and beer at an authentic 1936 beer garden in Yorkville, the historically German neighborhood of Manhattan's Upper East Side. Gulasch, sauerbrauten, sausage, schnitzel, and schweinebraten can be found here.

points_of_interest.name: 11 Madison Park
points_of_interest.description: Has one of the most beautiful rooms of any restaurant in New York. Long well-liked for its upscale American cuisine and helpful service, it has in the last few years been graced with a new chef who has been getting rave reviews from many quarters. Call ahead for reservations.

points_of_interest.name: Momoya
points_of_interest.description: A traditional Japanese/sushi menu with a vibrant fusion touch to it.

points_of_interest.name: Strip House
points_of_interest.description: Strip House is a privately owned fine dining chain of steakhouses. All locations have smaller, separate rooms for private dining and a gift card program. Strip House Next Door is next door at 11 East 12th Street. Similar hours and menu but closed Sunday & Monday.

points_of_interest.name: 8th Avenue
points_of_interest.description: Third Chinatown Stretching from 50th Street to 62nd Street, the avenue holds its own against Canal Street and Flushing. Fancy gourmet restaurants to alleyway noodle shops, Malaysian to Vietnamese and fare from every Chinese province, the neighborhood has it all. The area is particularly known as a nexus for immigrants from Fujian province.
points_of_interest.address: 806 56th Street, Brooklyn, New York 11220, United States

points_of_interest.name: Hop Kee Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: A decades-old Cantonese restaurant with classic dishes (Roast Pork Lo Mein, etc.) Open late on weekends (until 4AM), but like many other Chinatown restaurants, cash only.

points_of_interest.name: Oda House
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant serves Georgian food - not barbecued ribs or grits, but khinkali, pkhali, khachapuri, and other food from the former Soviet Republic of Georgia, accompanied by good Georgian wine, if you so choose. The food is generally flavorful and pleasant, but may be oversalted. The place can get crowded on weekends, so if you are sure of when you plan on coming, you might want to get reservations.

points_of_interest.name: Levain Bakery
points_of_interest.description: Levain is chock full of classic desserts such as double chocolate cookies and banana bread with chocolate chips. However, don't expect your average bakery here, as specialty yet finger-licking items are sold for fairly moderate prices here.

points_of_interest.name: Casa Mono
points_of_interest.description: A delightful Spanish wine bar and restaurant by Mario Batali. The food is smashing.

points_of_interest.name: Murray's Bagels Chelsea
points_of_interest.description: This is a place that believes in the pure New York bagel — which means no toasting. Don't even bother asking. But the bagels are so fresh that it doesn't matter. It's often packed with long lines and the service is chaotic, but they give you a healthy amount of spread and toppings.
points_of_interest.hours: M 7AM-8:30PM, Tu W 7AM-9PM, Th F 7AM-10PM, Sa Su 7AM-7PM

points_of_interest.name: Tea and Sympathy
points_of_interest.description: Describes itself as "a quintessential corner of England in the heart of Greenwich Village", typically English meals are available here (perfect for the Anglophile or homesick Brit!).

points_of_interest.name: Sister's Cuisine
points_of_interest.description: Anglo-Caribbean.

points_of_interest.name: La Isla Cuchifritos
points_of_interest.description: La Isla Cuchifrito Restaurant has been one of the most popular quick serve Latin establishments in Brooklyn for over 50 years. Puerto Rican food.

points_of_interest.name: Lombardi's Pizza
points_of_interest.description: The establishment in its current incarnation was opened in 1994, but describes itself as a continuation of "America's first pizzeria" (established in 1905). Their coal oven pizza is served by the pie, not the slice. Many New Yorkers think it has coasted off its prior reputation for years, but tourists can sometimes be seen lined up outside the door.

points_of_interest.name: Sundaes and Cones
points_of_interest.description: Expensive but good ice cream shop, with a variety of different flavors to choose from, including many Asian flavors.

points_of_interest.name: Uva Winebar
points_of_interest.description: An Italian winebar that has excellent Italian food including house made pastas. The special wines are worth a try and the wait for the table. Also well worth going to for special Meatball Mondays and delicious, fresh pasta dishes on other days with all sorts of meats, noodles, sauces, and rich desserts.

points_of_interest.name: Dos Caminos
points_of_interest.description: One of four up-market Mexican restaurants in Manhattan by the same name and under the same ownership (the other's are in SoHo, Chelsea, Midtown East) Sticky, saucy ribs and guacamole to die for.

points_of_interest.name: Pepe Giallo
points_of_interest.description: Reliable place for panini and pasta, priced fairly.

points_of_interest.name: Delice & Sarrasin
points_of_interest.description: French vegan crepes and galletes in a cozy setting.

points_of_interest.name: Pacificana
points_of_interest.description: Cantonese and Hong Kong cuisine, specializing in dim sum. In the heart of Sunset Park's Chinatown, this "palace" is popular with the locals and attracts visitors from farther afield.

points_of_interest.name: Ping's Seafood
points_of_interest.description: Good seafood restaurant especially the seafood pan-fried noodles & calamari. Also has dim sum. This place can get very crowded during weekend dinner.

points_of_interest.name: Szechuan Mountain House
points_of_interest.description: This Sichuan-style restaurant is the Manhattan branch of an establishment that began in Flushing. It's in the former Grand Sichuan St Marks space, accessed by climbing an outdoor staircase to the 2nd floor. They redid the decor to make it much fancier, but the main difference is the food, which is much more refined. Some of it is quite spicy and some of it is not, but either way, the flavors are very well balanced and the ingredients are high-quality. Good service, too. The restaurant is quite small and very popular, so either go for a weekday lunch — better yet, at odd hours (e.g. 3-4PM), or if you go for dinner, come on the later side or show up, give your name and then go somewhere else while you wait for as long as 90 minutes.

points_of_interest.name: Barbaresco
points_of_interest.description: Classic, elegant Italian restaurant that lures locals and tourists alike with brick-lined walls and delicious Italian pasta dishes.

points_of_interest.name: Gramercy Tavern
points_of_interest.description: Thought of as Danny Meyer's flagship restaurant, serves upscale American food at higher prices than 11 Madison Park. Expect to pay over $100/person for dinner in the main dining room. The tavern is more informal and more moderately priced. Gramercy Tavern is known as one of the more difficult reservations to obtain in Manhattan.

points_of_interest.name: Rocket Pig
points_of_interest.description: Tiny sandwich shop that serves one kind of sandwich and a variety of sides (chips, cookies, pickles, cole slaw). The sandwich is sliced pork, onion jam, and mustard sauce served on a ciabatta roll. There is no seating, but there are a couple of counters to lean on if eating in.

points_of_interest.name: Tacos El Bronco
points_of_interest.description: Since Sunset Park is home to many Mexicans and Mexican Americans, you will find authentic south-of-the-border cuisine here. If you like street food, check out their truck on 5th Ave between 37th and 38th Sts.

points_of_interest.name: Shanghai Cafe Deluxe
points_of_interest.description: Can make the best Shanghainese food in Chinatown, but has some consistency problems. Many young Chinese-American couples have dates there. Do not be shocked if the check is delivered to you unbidden, but don't feel that it must be paid right away. It's easy to have a sizable meal here for around $15 and possible to eat here for less. "Temporarily closed for renovations" per their website as of June 2024.

points_of_interest.name: Uluh
points_of_interest.description: Describing themselves as a "modern Chinese restaurant and tea house," they serve a variety of regional Chinese cuisines. Their food is delicious and they are very popular, especially with Chinese people, doing a brisk eat-in business and sometimes having waits of an hour or more for takeout. Standout items include their thin, light scallion pancakes ($7); woodear mushroom salad ($10); Sichuan beef jerky, which is somewhat chewy with a fragrant, spicy, tangy and sweet sauce ($17); steamed chicken with sesame in chili sauce ($15); Nanjing salted duck ($19); and vegetarian dry pot ($36).

points_of_interest.name: The Carlyle Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Restaurant located in a classy boutique hotel, with elegant dishes made with care and precision from very fresh ingredients. Serves breakfast, brunch, lunch and dinner menus.
points_of_interest.hours: Breakfast: M-Sa 7AM-10:30AM, Su 8AM-10:30AM; brunch: Su noon to 2PM; lunch: daily noon to 2PM; dinner: daily 6-10PM

points_of_interest.name: Penelope
points_of_interest.description: Cafe/restaurant/bakery with a cozy, inviting atmosphere. Homestyle food and casual but friendly service. Inexpensive. Wine and beer served. Long lines for weekend brunch.

points_of_interest.name: Tacos Matamoros
points_of_interest.description: A neighborhood Mexican restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Nyonya
points_of_interest.description: This restaurant is part of a small chain with other Nyonya and Penang restaurants and is popular and crowded on weekends. Their roti canai is good. One word of warning, though: If you are looking for food like you had on your visit to Kuala Lumpur, for the most part, you won't get it here. Instead, you are likely to get very watered-down, Americanized versions of most of their Malaysian dishes. Expect to spend around $25/person for dinner.

points_of_interest.name: Hearth
points_of_interest.description: An upscale American restaurant strongly influenced by Italian cuisine. Hearth is open for dinner only. Expect to pay roughly $80/person, including wine. Reservations recommended.

points_of_interest.name: Lady M Cake Boutique
points_of_interest.description: It's a very refined (bordering on pretentious) bakery, but the desserts are exceptional, with excellent cheesecake, and decadent crêpe cakes and eclairs to give this bakery its own flair. If sweets aren't your style either, then you can certainly try the flavorful salads and sandwiches, of which there are many choices.

points_of_interest.name: Saravanaas Bhavan
points_of_interest.description: Excellent South Indian food at good prices. This is a vegetarian kosher restaurant and a branch of one in Chennai (Madras), India. Expect to wait a half hour or so on weekends.

points_of_interest.name: Txikito
points_of_interest.description: Basque tapas restaurant which serves delicious food and wine in a bustling atmosphere. The charges add up quickly for all those small plates, so it is far from a cheap restaurant, but it is fun and a fair value.
points_of_interest.hours: lunch Tu—F noon-3PM; dinner Su—Th 5-11PM and F Sa 5PM-midnight; brunch Sa Su 11:30AM-3:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Terry's
points_of_interest.description: Deli popular with local students.

points_of_interest.name: 120 Bay Cafe
points_of_interest.description: formerly Cargo Cafe Laid back eatery. Cool decor. Excellent appetizers and burgers. Great beers on tap. Entertainment weekly!

points_of_interest.name: Dim Sum Go Go
points_of_interest.description: More expensive than the average Chinatown restaurant and catering to a mixed clientèle of Chinese and non-Chinese, it is many connoisseurs' favorite spot for dim sum in Chinatown. All the food is made to order; no carts. Some of their non-dim sum items are also good. Dumplings are mostly excellent — tasty, with a good texture and thin wrapper — but there have been some problems in the past with overly doughy buns that then got mushy from condensation, so you might consider avoiding those.

points_of_interest.name: Maya
points_of_interest.description: Fine Mexican, creative, seafood-laden menu, turning classic Mexican dishes into elegant, vibrant dishes full of meat and spices.
points_of_interest.hours: Brunch: Sa Su 11:30AM-4:30PM; dinner: M-W 5-10PM, Th F 5-11PM, Sa 5-11PM, Su 5:30-10PM; bar and lounge: daily 3PM-midnight

points_of_interest.name: Shake Shack
points_of_interest.description: Awesome roadside food stand in Madison Square Park serving hot dogs, burgers, frozen custard, beer, and wine. Though reputed for their burgers, they also serve what is widely regarded as the best Chicago-style hot dog in New York.

points_of_interest.name: Poseidon Bakery
points_of_interest.description: Serves wonderful Greek pastries, savory and sweet alike. There is no place to sit, but the staff are very friendly and helpful, and you can have a delicious, cheap meal for takeout.

points_of_interest.name: Shorty's
points_of_interest.description: Cheesesteak restaurant

points_of_interest.name: Denino's Pizzeria & Tavern
points_of_interest.description: It is reasonably priced and has tasty dishes besides pizza.

points_of_interest.name: Golden Unicorn
points_of_interest.description: Occupies a few floors. There is a bit more decor than at Jing Fong and the prices are a bit higher. Unfortunately, the food is mediocre.

points_of_interest.name: Orsay
points_of_interest.description: Classic French restaurant with elegant beef and fish dishes garnished with fresh ingredients and sauces.
points_of_interest.hours: Brunch: Sa Su 11AM-3:30PM; lunch: M-F noon-3PM; dinner: M-Sa 5:30-10:30PM; Su 5:30-9:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Union Square Café
points_of_interest.description: One of New York's best-loved restaurants, serving great American and Italian cuisine with flair and crisp style. Osso buco, tuna burgers, roast vegetables and corn pudding are fine examples of the dishes created using the best local and seasonal produce from the café's neighbor, the Union Square Farmers' Market. Mains in excess of $30 average. Reservations recommended.
points_of_interest.hours: Lunch M-Sa noon-2:15PM; dinner Su-Th 6-10:15PM, F Sa 6-11:15PM

points_of_interest.name: The Halal Guys
points_of_interest.description: An extremely popular and affordable food stand that is probably the only Mediterranean stand in Manhattan that was given a name. This is the original location and since it started in 2008, it has begun a chain and opened 5 more throughout Manhattan and Bergen County, New Jersey. Delicious gyros, wraps, and falafel, and each dish comes with rice and pita bread. There's also an incredible white sauce that's worth trying. If you want some on a weekend, you're going to have to get there early because there is guaranteed to be a long wait.

points_of_interest.name: Rockwell's
points_of_interest.description: Independent eatery since 1995.

points_of_interest.name: Goodfella's
points_of_interest.description: Famous for their vodka pizza, the recipient of several awards.

points_of_interest.name: Jing Fong
points_of_interest.description: It used to be housed in a huge eating hall on Elizabeth St. but moved into smaller quarters in 2021. The quality of the food is generally acceptable, if not refined, but it is best when fresh from the kitchen. They also have a new branch as of 2022 at 380 Amsterdam Ave at 78th St. on the Upper West Side, but do not assume the food is the same there.

points_of_interest.name: Vatan
points_of_interest.description: A prix-fixe vegetarian Indian restaurant with wonderful food. The decor is a little hokey, but the food makes it worthwhile.

points_of_interest.name: The Boathouse
points_of_interest.description: Held in the Loeb Boathouse on the Lake, the Boathouse includes a sit-down restaurant with tables overlooking the lake, a sit-down bar area outside, and an express cafe with counter service for quick takeout and eat-in food.
points_of_interest.address: on Park Drive North on The Lake
points_of_interest.hours: Cafe: daily 8AM–8PM (winter 8AM-4:30PM). Outdoor bar: April–November daily 11AM-11PM (weather permitting). Restaurant: lunch M-F noon-4PM; brunch Sa Su 9:30AM-4PM; dinner April–November M-F 5:30PM-9:30PM, Sa Su 6PM-9:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Joe And Pat's
points_of_interest.description: Specializes in an extraordinarily thin pizza that is one of the best slices in the city. Uniquely thin without too much cheese, Joe and Pat's slices are some of the lightest in the city. Try the eggplant fries.

points_of_interest.name: Nom Wah Tea Parlor
points_of_interest.description: Nom Wah was the first dim sum parlor in New York, opening in 1920. In 2011, they renovated, sprucing up the interior but leaving most of the old-fashioned feeling intact. A few new dishes were added, but the core of Nom Wah's menu remains Cantonese. They serve dim sum all day. Unfortunately, the quality of the items is not consistent.

points_of_interest.name: Empanada Mama
points_of_interest.description: Popular 24-hour joint with an extensive selection of empanadas ranging from classic to creative, as well as other Latin American dishes. The focus is on Colombian flavors but there's quite a bit of fusion. Excellent vegan options. A second location at 200 W 40th St near Times Square is mainly for takeout, with a smaller menu and slightly more limited hours.

points_of_interest.name: d Elici
points_of_interest.description: Sandwiches

points_of_interest.name: Le Pain Quotidien
points_of_interest.description: A branch of this local chain of sit-down restaurants with organic options like handmade bread and vegan ice cream. Pre-packaged picnic boxes are also available.
points_of_interest.address: in the Mineral Springs Pavilion at the northern end of the Sheep Meadow

points_of_interest.name: Pizzeria Giove
points_of_interest.description: A small pizzeria known for its authentically Italian thin crust pizza. Unlike New York pizza, it is cooked in a wood-fired oven. It has been featured on the TV show ''Throwdown with Bobby Flay''.

points_of_interest.name: Ariana Afghan Kabob
points_of_interest.description: Very good food, which of course includes kebabs, but also peppery ''Aush'' (a type of beany noodle soup), ''Badinjan Burani'' (a fried eggplant appetizer garlic and yogurt, served with bread), etc. Salads, which come with main dishes, have a dressing which includes mayonnaise. Ask for no dressing and put the green hot sauce on them yourself.

points_of_interest.name: Tavern on the Green
points_of_interest.description: This iconic restaurant has appeared in dozens of films as one of New York's most famous dining spots. The historic building once served as a sheep paddock before being converted to a restaurant in 1934, soon becoming a favorite destination for New Yorkers' special occasions. Although the setting is as lovely as it's always been, the restaurant itself has developed a reputation for providing overpriced food that isn't all that good.

points_of_interest.name: Ralph's Italian Ices
points_of_interest.description: The original store of the successful chain of stores serving light, refreshing ices. The chain has numerous other locations in the New York Metro, including a handful in other Staten Island neighborhoods. They are in New Dorp, Great Kills, Eltingville, Huguenot, and Pleasant Plains. The full list can be found [http://www.ralphsices.com/locations.htm here].

points_of_interest.name: Bill’s Bar & Burger
points_of_interest.description: Burger spot also known for disco fries (with gravy & cheese), beer & alcoholic shakes.

points_of_interest.name: Bay House Bistro
points_of_interest.description: One of the best Asian take outs going. Focus on the appetizers, heavily influenced by Southeast Asian cuisine, particularly Malaysian. Try the roti canai or the curry veggie pies.

points_of_interest.name: Dos Caminos
points_of_interest.description: Dos Caminos' fifth New York City location. Designed by Brooklyn-based company, hOmE, spanning two floors, and featuring a 40-seat mezcal and margarita bar on the street level and a guacamole bar on the subterranean level. Expanded menu of Chef Ivy Stark’s healthy Mexican dishes as well as a selection of 120 premium tequilas.

points_of_interest.name: Halal Cart
points_of_interest.description: Good chicken, veggies, lamb with rice combos for lunch. Coffee and bagels in the mornings.

points_of_interest.name: Taqueria Gallo Azteca
points_of_interest.description: The cemitas are to die for, a sandwich with your choice of meat, with avocado, chipotle peppers, quesillo, and beans. One of the best sandwiches you'll ever have.

points_of_interest.name: Joe's Shanghai
points_of_interest.description: Try their famous "soup dumplings", listed on the menu as "steamed buns", and their other delicious Shanghai specialties. Pricier than the Chinatown location.

points_of_interest.name: Bill’s Bar & Burger
points_of_interest.description: Classic American fare, includes handmade griddle burgers, milkshakes and a wide beer selection.

points_of_interest.name: Italian Ice Lady
points_of_interest.description: Late Spring to early Fall only.

points_of_interest.name: Burrito Bar
points_of_interest.description: Fun Tex-Mex restaurant with generous portions, bar is on the lower level, and restaurant is upstairs.

points_of_interest.name: John's Pizzeria
points_of_interest.description: A popular pizza option with a lovely and spacious atmosphere and brick oven, coal fired, thin crust pizzas. Whole pizzas, no slices. Many fans, however, consider that the pizza at this location is not nearly as good as at their original Greenwich Village location. Also, pre-theater, it can be absolutely mobbed, with wait times of an hour or more.

points_of_interest.name: Watermark
points_of_interest.description: Stylish restaurant overlooking the East River

points_of_interest.name: Fruit Stands
points_of_interest.description: Spring to Fall only.

points_of_interest.name: Beso
points_of_interest.description: Spanish restaurant with live music occasionally. Tapas and sangria bring some much needed class to the neighborhood. A short walk from the ferry and a great place to eat.

points_of_interest.name: Vice Versa
points_of_interest.description: Simple, but tasty Italian fare.

points_of_interest.name: The Taco Stand
points_of_interest.description: A popular stand with good tacos. Nights only.

points_of_interest.name: Real Madrid
points_of_interest.description: A restaurant with authentic Spanish food.

points_of_interest.name: Westway Diner
points_of_interest.description: Real New York diner, excellent place for good value breakfast. Very good service.

points_of_interest.name: Absolute Bagels
points_of_interest.description: A true New York bagel shop with a fanatical following, often ranking among the very best bagels in the city. There's usually a long line out the door, but it tends to move quickly. Lots of spread and sandwich options are available.

points_of_interest.name: Lakruwana
points_of_interest.description: One of the more elegant eateries. Its fine decor and delicious meals belie the outrageously inexpensive prices. Sundays offer a lunch and dinner buffet.

points_of_interest.name: Wondee Siam
points_of_interest.description: Small restaurant, so expect to wait on line at peak hours (e.g., Friday and Saturday nights); generally considered to be one of the best Thai restaurants in Manhattan. Food ranges in spiciness from mild to very spicy, not always consistent with what you ask for, but staff are happy to provide extra dried red pepper flakes on the side. Consistently tasty food, especially if you stick with the items on the "secret Thai" menu card on the table and ask for everything to be "very spicy and Thai style, not sweet."

points_of_interest.name: O'Hara's
points_of_interest.description: Irish restaurant

points_of_interest.name: New Asha Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: Offers many of the same items at competitive prices. Has been named #1 by the Village Voice Cheap Eats in the past. Featured on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations. Try a mutton roll! There are several Sri Lankan groceries that dot the street about a 15-20 minute walk from the ferry.

points_of_interest.name: Yakitori Totto
points_of_interest.description: This is a great and very popular place for yakitori, which is Japanese food on sticks. If you're ordering drinks, be careful: their tea is very good but charged by the cup and the sakes are very expensive. However, the food is a very fair value.
points_of_interest.hours: Lunch: daily noon-4PM; dinner: Su-Th 5:30-10:30PM, F Sa 5:30-11:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Nara Sushi/Kumo
points_of_interest.description: Cozy sit-down sushi joint.
points_of_interest.hours: M-Th 11:30AM–9:30PM, F 11:30AM-10PM, Sa noon-10PM, Su noon–9:30PM

points_of_interest.name: El Malecon
points_of_interest.description: A Dominican restaurant known as one of the best places for ''pollo a la brasa'' (rotisserie chicken) in Manhattan. They also serve a number of daily specials for lunch and dinner.

points_of_interest.name: Nobu
points_of_interest.description: World-renowned Japanese restaurant requiring reservations well in advance. For an alternative, try Nobu Next Door which doesn't require a reservation and serves the same creative, delicious food. May not be worth ''all'' the hype, but certainly worth some.

points_of_interest.name: Flor de Mayo
points_of_interest.description: This is a Peruvian-Chinese restaurant, owned and staffed by Peruvian immigrants of Chinese descent. However, because there are way more Dominicans than Peruvians in the area, they have catered to the Criollo taste. They have long been known in the neighborhood for reliably tasty pollo a la brasa (rotisserie chicken), served with a delicious garlic sauce (if they don't automatically bring it for you, ask for it). They also offer specifically Peruvian dishes, which are well worth your trying if you are not in the mood for the chicken. Their Chinese dishes are in a style similar to the American-Chinese restaurants of the 1970s - perfectly acceptable, though perhaps a bit oily. They have another location at 484 Amsterdam Ave, between 83rd and 84th Sts, which some people prefer.

points_of_interest.name: Blue Fin
points_of_interest.description: Sushi bar, bar and lounge area, communal table and expanded private dining room options.

points_of_interest.name: Gray's Papaya
points_of_interest.description: One of the best hot dog joints in Manhattan (the "Recession Special" is a popular favorite), Gray's also serves up some excellent tropical drinks.

points_of_interest.name: The Heights
points_of_interest.description: Tex-Mex. The bar is the best part. A rooftop terrace is open on warm days for al fresco dining.

points_of_interest.name: Fogo de Chão Brazilian Steakhouse
points_of_interest.description: This Brazilian steakhouse is renowned for its ''churrasco''/''rodízio'' experience, wherein servers bring various fire-roasted meats to your table. It's all-you-can-eat and includes an extensive salad bar and ''feijoada''—a black bean and pork stew—as well as various sides such as ''pão de queijo'' (cheese bread).

points_of_interest.name: Koronet Pizza
points_of_interest.description: A very good pizza parlor serving the Columbia University area. They specialize in large pies and large slices, amongst the largest in the city.

points_of_interest.name: Strip House
points_of_interest.description: Steakhouse with a raw bar boasts walls covered with photos of old-Hollywood stars. Part of a small chain with another location on E. 12th St. and one in Las Vegas.

points_of_interest.name: Le Monde
points_of_interest.description: Faux French food but a great international beer selection and good burgers.

points_of_interest.name: Metro Diner
points_of_interest.description: Diner with long, varied menus for all meals.

points_of_interest.name: Massawa
points_of_interest.description: One of the oldest Ethopian (Eritrean) restaurants in the city, but renovated. Good food, service, and a well stocked bar.

points_of_interest.name: Ollie's To Go
points_of_interest.description: Workday Chinese. Fast and cheap lunch or dinner, but don't expect anything close to average Chinatown quality.

points_of_interest.name: Peacefood Cafe
points_of_interest.description: Vegan food only

points_of_interest.name: Tom's Restaurant
points_of_interest.description: The restaurant from the comedy series ''Seinfeld''. This place is a shrine for many TV pilgrims; for the locals, just a diner.

points_of_interest.name: Barney Greengrass
points_of_interest.description: Barney Greengrass has been known as the "Sturgeon King" for a very long time, having opened his original store in 1908. The smoked fish that this establishment is known for is not cheap: Smoked fish platters in the restaurant range from $28-58, not counting the "deluxe platter for two," which will set you back $95. You can save some money by having eggs with a side of smoked fish; that'll still cost you between $14.50 and $20.75, but you won't regret it. This place is a real New York institution, and the only place in Manhattan that is generally considered to rival it for what's traditionally called Jewish "appetizing" (that is, pareve products that are neither meat nor milk but include fish) is Russ & Daughters on the Lower East Side.

points_of_interest.name: Manhattan Valley
points_of_interest.description: A classy Northern Indian restaurant that serves excellent food. Their lunch special is a bargain; dinner is a little more, but still a fine value.

points_of_interest.name: Pio Pio
points_of_interest.description: A Manhattan outpost of a very popular upscale Peruvian chain. Serves great rotisserie chicken, and tends to be very loud due to the large crowds of locals that come here.

points_of_interest.name: Salumeria Rosi
points_of_interest.description: The cuisine of this restaurant is based on excellent salumi (cured meats), and the other ingredients are fresh and high-quality. The "small" selection of salumi is quite substantial, and the salads are large and quite good. The antipasti, while tasty, are rather small, so they're worth getting but can add up more quickly. Good cheeses, too. The front of the shop is a counter that sells salumi and cheeses to take out. Informal atmosphere, serious cuisine, and good service. It isn't cheap, but it is a very good value, especially for the neighborhood.

points_of_interest.name: Atlantic Grill
points_of_interest.description: Seafood; sushi, oysters and simply grilled fish a la carte.

points_of_interest.name: Masa
points_of_interest.description: Probably the most expensive restaurant in New York, so go only if money is no object. Those who have been there strongly recommend that you sit at the sushi bar in order to have the best experience. Reservations necessary.

points_of_interest.name: Per Se
points_of_interest.description: The New York outpost of Chef Thomas Keller of the French Laundry in Yountville, which is in the Napa Valley of California. Chef Keller is one of the most famous and highly praised chefs in the United States. It used to be necessary to call months in advance for reservations, but same-day reservations may be worth attempting.

points_of_interest.name: Citarella
points_of_interest.description: Started out as a fish market, then added an increasingly large meat section. They also sell some prepared items. Can be pricey.

points_of_interest.name: Fairway
points_of_interest.description: Probably the best-known supermarket in New York, Fairway sells a wide variety of specialty and prepared items, in addition to usual supermarket fare, and has large produce sections. Lots of good values to be had, but watch out for elbows and aggressive shopping cart drivers at peak times. Great values in produce, but they don't take good care of their cheese. Yogurt and other products not kept in shrink-wrapped plastic are fine.

points_of_interest.name: Milano Market
points_of_interest.description: Italian products with a good deli, reasonable cheeses, and a good selection of international beers.

points_of_interest.name: Schatzie's
points_of_interest.description: Totally friendly, great meats, great butchers, order by phone, and cheaper than Citarella. And they will cook dinner for you if you like.

points_of_interest.name: Westside Supermarket
points_of_interest.description: An old neighborhood establishment gone upscale. Amazing choice of prepared foods and good fruits and vegetables. The cheese section is outstanding, as also are the meats and fish.

points_of_interest.name: Zabar's
points_of_interest.description: A very well-known store in New York, with an enormous selection of delicious (and often expensive) foods. Foodstuffs (cheeses, olives, smoked fish, prepared foods, breads, etc.) are sold on the first floor. The second floor is where you will find all sorts of devices related to cooking and food processing at price points ranging from inexpensive bargains to very expensive luxury items. As with Fairway, do not go the day before Thanksgiving, and think carefully before going on a busy weekend. They also have a small cafe at the corner of 80th St. that has quite decent offerings (for example, frozen yogurt and sandwiches with some of the good products sold in their store) and is not expensive.

points_of_interest.name: Adventurer's Family Entertainment Center
points_of_interest.address: 1842 Shore Parkway, Brooklyn, New York 11214, United States

points_of_interest.name: Deno's Wonder Wheel Amusement Park
points_of_interest.description: The highlight of Coney Island

points_of_interest.name: Diversity Plaza
points_of_interest.description: A plaza adjacent to Roosevelt Ave station and near several Desi, Tibetan, and Nepalese establishments.

points_of_interest.name: Luna Park at Coney Island
points_of_interest.address: 3055 West 10th Street, Brooklyn, New York 11224, United States

points_of_interest.name: Afrikan Poetry Theatre
points_of_interest.description: Hosts classes, activist and cultural programs, musical performances, and produces original plays.

points_of_interest.name: Black Spectrum Theatre
points_of_interest.description: Creates theatre and film that focuses on educating African American youth on racial issues, as well as highlights emerging Black artists.

points_of_interest.name: East Midwood Jewish Center
points_of_interest.description: On the State and National Registers of Historic Places and home to weekly religious services and cultural happenings.

points_of_interest.name: Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning
points_of_interest.description: The heart of Jamaica's art culture, organizing workshops, classes, exhibits, and performances in the visual and performing arts.

points_of_interest.name: The Bell House
points_of_interest.description: Old Gowanus warehouse turned into a music venue.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Cyclones
points_of_interest.description: New York Mets single-A minor league team, which plays in Coney Island right next to the Boardwalk at MCU Park. They were established to fill the void of Brooklyn's old Major League Baseball team the Dodgers, who left for Los Angeles after the 1957 season.
points_of_interest.address: 1528 Surf Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11224, United States

points_of_interest.name: IFC Center
points_of_interest.description: An art house theater showing independent films and documentaries. It is owned by the IFC network (an extension of AMC), so a lot of premiers and television broadcasts take place here.

points_of_interest.name: Rufus King Park
points_of_interest.description: Take a walk and watch locals play soccer in the field.
points_of_interest.address: 90-00 150th Street, Jamaica, New York 11435, United States

points_of_interest.name: The Brick
points_of_interest.description: A former garage, The Brick is home to cutting-edge independent theater, The New York Clown Theater Festival, and an annual themed festival each year (past themes included the Moral Values Festival and the $ellout Festival).

points_of_interest.name: Lower East Side Jewish Conservancy
points_of_interest.description: The LESJC runs private and public tours of the Jewish Lower East Side. The tours are unique as they take visitors into synagogues rather than just the outside. Buy tickets ahead of time as they sell out fast.

points_of_interest.name: Film Forum
points_of_interest.description: A stylish theater that runs two programs—contemporary independent releases and classic repertory films. While the current releases are almost always interesting and worth seeing, it's the repertory programming schedule that filmlovers anticipate eagerly.

points_of_interest.name: Quad Cinema
points_of_interest.description: One of the older independent cinemas, showing a regular schedule of independent, foreign and documentary films.

points_of_interest.name: Adventurer’s Park - Family Entertainment Center
points_of_interest.description: This amusement park for younger children is in the Gravesend neighborhood. Attractions and rides include bumper cars, ferris wheel, roller coaster, fun slide, merry-go-round, tea cups, tilt-a-whirl, go karts, mini golf, and others.

points_of_interest.name: Music Hall of Williamsburg
points_of_interest.description: Hosts larger indie rock concerts for the 18+ crowd. 600-person capacity.

points_of_interest.name: Sunshine Cinema
points_of_interest.description: This relatively new multiplex cinema, done up to look like a movie palace of old, quickly became a landmark in the neighborhood, and is an excellent place to watch a film.

points_of_interest.name: Here Arts Center
points_of_interest.description: Performing arts venue.

points_of_interest.name: Angelika Film Center
points_of_interest.description: Just down the street from Film Forum, the Angelika plays new independent and foreign films, many of which are screened in no American city but New York. The cafe upstairs is something of a hotspot as well.

points_of_interest.name: Deno's Wonder Wheel Amusement Park
points_of_interest.description: The Wonder Wheel itself is the main attraction here. Choose the swinging cars for an extra thrill. There are numerous other adult and kiddie rides.
points_of_interest.hours: Apr, May, Sep, Oct: opens noon on weekends only; Jun to Labor Day: opens noon daily; closing times vary according to weather conditions

points_of_interest.name: BAM Rose Cinemas
points_of_interest.description: A good cinema in an old opera hall. Films shown are in between arthouse and mainstream.

points_of_interest.name: Christmas Lights at Dyker Heights
points_of_interest.description: About 10 blocks, centered around the "Candy Cane House" on 84th and 12th. During the holiday season the locals bring up the most spectacular decorations-- do a Flickr or Google image search yourself and see! There's the house with the giant snowman, the house with the giant nutcrackers, the house with Winnie and Shrek, and the Toyland house with the animatronic reindeer. Go on a Friday or Saturday night, between 7 and 10. It'll put the Christmas spirit in you.
points_of_interest.address: 1201 84th Street, Brooklyn, New York 11228, United States

points_of_interest.name: The Performing Garage
points_of_interest.description: Off-Broadway theater that is the permanent home of experimental theater company the Wooster Group.

points_of_interest.name: Cinema Village
points_of_interest.description: Cinema Village specializes in showing documentaries, independent and foreign films. Often the films there will not be playing anywhere else in the country and Q&As with directors are common at opening weekends.

points_of_interest.name: Luna Park
points_of_interest.description: Named after the original 1903 Luna Park, this amusement park is bringing thrills to Brooklyn.

points_of_interest.name: Warsaw
points_of_interest.description: Music venue located inside the Polish National Home in Greenpoint. Events are 18+.

points_of_interest.name: Bargemusic
points_of_interest.description: A truly hidden gem. This barge, moored permanently just under the Brooklyn Bridge, has chamber music fare every week with cheese, wine, plush seating, a fireplace, and gentle rocking to assist in your peaceful slumber. It also has a dynamite view of the lower Manhattan skyline.

points_of_interest.name: Anthology Film Archives
points_of_interest.description: A varied program of unique films, both repertory and new, most playing for only one or two screenings. Many of the films shown here can't be seen anywhere else (for better or worse). It also plays host to several film festivals yearly.

points_of_interest.name: Atlantic Stage 2
points_of_interest.description: This is the Atlantic's 99-seat theater which they use for shows too interesting to go in their larger theater on 20th St. Listings for stage 2 shows that are part of their regular season go on their website. But this theater has many secret shows, like their acting school's semester-end performances, and staged readings during the summer. This other stuff is usually not even on nytheatre.com, but, rather publicized by Facebook and postcard only, so while some of it is open to the public, most of the audience may consist of fans, relatives, and friends of the performers. You may have the chance to hear readings by talented young authors from places like Middlebury College before they become famous. If you're invited to something here, it will probably be good and completely irreplaceable, but think twice about making critical comments in such an environment.

points_of_interest.name: Village Vanguard
points_of_interest.description: Presents a great lineup of jazz performers in a quiet room (except for the music) that has good acoustics.

points_of_interest.name: Coney Island Beach & Boardwalk
points_of_interest.description: Sandy beach, open to the public.
points_of_interest.address: 1500 Riegelmann Boardwalk, Brooklyn, New York 11224, United States

points_of_interest.name: Union Pool
points_of_interest.description: This is a bar and concert venue. In the summer, they host free live music in their back courtyard.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Academy of Music
points_of_interest.description: Home to the impressive Brooklyn Philharmonic, BAM is one of the best places in the country to attend cutting-edge new musical and dance performances. The Next Wave Festival every autumn is a much-anticipated event of the New York performance scene.

points_of_interest.name: Joyce Theater
points_of_interest.description: One of the premier contemporary dance performance spaces in the world, with modern dance and ballet.

points_of_interest.name: Blue Note
points_of_interest.description: Also has a lineup of famous jazz and blues performers. It feels a little more like a bar (with people talking during the show) and a little less like a venue that's only about the music.

points_of_interest.name: Pat Auletta Steeplechase Pier
points_of_interest.description: Fishing pier with views of the ocean.
points_of_interest.address: 2201 Riegelmann Boardwalk, New York 11224, United States

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Bowl
points_of_interest.description: This is a large and popular bowling alley that hosts concerts and other events.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Nets
points_of_interest.description: An NBA team that plays in the Barclays Center, an arena at 620 Atlantic Ave. Formerly the New Jersey Nets before 2012, the team was purchased and brought to Brooklyn by Russian oligarch Mikhail Prokhorov (though he no longer owns the team), and it's the first major league team to call Brooklyn its home since 1958, after the Dodgers left to Los Angeles.

points_of_interest.name: Russian & Turkish Baths
points_of_interest.description: Enjoy a day of self-indulgence with a very authentic Russian feel. Then nosh on bagels and cream cheese, or an authentic Russian meal in the restaurant. Maybe after all that shvitzing (that's Yiddish/New Yorkese for "sweating"): a huge bottle of seltzer, or fresh carrot juice is the thing you'll want most.

points_of_interest.name: Sleep No More
points_of_interest.description: The McKittrick Hotel Enjoy Shakespeare's ''Macbeth'' re-imagined as a Hitchcock thriller in this silent, walk-around, interactive theater production.

points_of_interest.name: Small's
points_of_interest.description: A great place to hear excellent jazz at low prices.

points_of_interest.name: Sheepshead Bay Piers
points_of_interest.description: You can catch a fishing excursion or a dinner cruise from one of the ten piers on the bay.
points_of_interest.address: Emmons Ave between Ocean Ave & E 26th St

points_of_interest.name: House of Yes
points_of_interest.description: This eclectic club hosts a variety of events from dance parties to burlesque.

points_of_interest.name: 92nd Street Y
points_of_interest.description: 92Y A full season of concerts, lectures, and other events takes place here. The Y's Kaufmann Concert Hall is one of the premiere concert halls in the city, and its lecture and concert series feature many well-known groups and individuals. Some fans particularly recommend the chamber music concerts featuring members of the New York Philharmonic. The Y also offers classes in various subjects through art, culture, and entertainment. Judaism is also a major part of the community here as well, being a Jewish-based organization with a variety of classes based on religion.
points_of_interest.hours: May Center: M-Th 5:30AM-10:30PM; F 5:30AM-9PM, Sa Su 7:30AM-8PM. Resident Office: M W 9AM-7PM, Tu Th 9AM-8:30PM, F 9AM-5PM, Sa noon-8:30PM, Su 10AM-6PM

points_of_interest.name: People’s Improv Theater
points_of_interest.description: Dedicated to the instruction, performance and development of original comedy. Wednesdays are free.

points_of_interest.name: 55 Bar
points_of_interest.description: This bar has some good blues and jazz acts, but what's so unusual about it is that it dates back to 1919 and still has a lot of the original furnishings and Beaux Arts-style lamps. Keep your drink orders simple and enjoy the atmosphere.

points_of_interest.name: Good Room
points_of_interest.description: One of the best electronic dance clubs in the city, with no pretentiousness.

points_of_interest.name: New York Islanders
points_of_interest.description: An NHL team that began sharing Barclays Center with the Nets in the 2015–16 season, but now play only about half of their home games in Brooklyn. The "Isles" have moved the remainder of their home schedule to their former home of Nassau Coliseum (now extensively renovated) in the Nassau County suburb of Uniondale. In 2021, the Isles plan to move full-time into a new arena next to the Belmont Park horse racing track in another Nassau County community, Elmont.

points_of_interest.name: Asphalt Green Upper East Side Campus
points_of_interest.description: Asphalt Green With a massive fitness and pool center in the area's signature arches, there's an endless array of activities here, including baseball, flag football, gymnastics, lifeguard training, martial arts, soccer, swimming, tennis, and yoga. On the western half of the block is a turf field that provides a vast playing field for games, playing around, and relaxing. There is a playground just north of the fitness center.

points_of_interest.name: Irving Plaza
points_of_interest.description: A popular concert venue that regularly hosts rock and hip-hop concerts as well as the occasional comedy show.

points_of_interest.name: Magnet Theater
points_of_interest.description: Magnet Theater is a performance and training space established in 2005. It is one of the most well-known improv schools and theaters in the city, offering classes and shows in various styles of comedy such as improv, musical improv, sketch, and storytelling. The theater was founded by Armando Diaz and Sean Taylor, both veteran improvisers from the Chicago comedy community. The Magnet Theater also has a touring company that performs and teaches workshops at improv festivals around the world, as well as a corporate workshops' division, the Magnet Genius Machine. Many notable performers and faculty from the theater have gone on to work on shows such as Broad City, 30 Rock, and The Colbert Report.

points_of_interest.name: ABC Times Square Studios
points_of_interest.description: Come here bright and early in the morning to be in the live audience of the network's famous morning news show, ''Good Morning America''. Walkbys can view the show in progress from the studio's street level windows and catch up on the latest news scrolling away continuously on the building's lower two message zippers.

points_of_interest.name: Bembe
points_of_interest.description: This small club spins African and Latin beats.

points_of_interest.name: Kane Street Synagogue
points_of_interest.description: Congregation Baith Israel Anshei Emes Built in 1856, on the State and National Registers of Historic Places and home to weekly religious services and cultural happenings.

points_of_interest.name: Carl Schurz Park
points_of_interest.description: Home of Gracie Mansion, the Official Residence of the Mayor of New York, Carl Schurz Park also boasts wonderful views of Hell Gate and the East River. Compared to other New York parks, Carl Schurz is extremely quiet, given that the surrounding area is almost exclusively residential. The park features two bustling dog parks, two playgrounds, a sports court, multiple fields of grass to rest in on a peaceful spring day, and a boardwalk with beautiful views of Roosevelt Island, this is a great destination for any visitor sick of the overwhelming crowds elsewhere in the city.
points_of_interest.address: East End Avenue between East 84th Street & East 90th Street

points_of_interest.name: Gramercy Theatre
points_of_interest.description: An old theater that now serves as a small rock concert venue.

points_of_interest.name: Madison Square Garden
points_of_interest.description: One of the world's most famous and busiest arenas, Madison Square Garden is home to the '''[https://rangers.nhl.com/ New York Rangers]''' NHL team, the '''[https://nba.com/knicks/ New York Knicks]''' NBA team, and the '''[https://www.redstormsports.com/sports/m-baskbl/stjo-m-baskbl-body.html St. John's Red Storm]''' college men's basketball team, as well as numerous concerts and entertainment events. In addition to most St. John's home games, the Garden also hosts three major college men's basketball events each year. At the start of the season, the Garden hosts the semifinals and finals of the '''[https://www.ncaa.com/championships/basketball-men/nit NIT Season Tip-Off]''', a prestigious early-season event operated by the country's main college sports body, the NCAA. After the regular season, the Garden then hosts the '''[https://www.bigeast.com/index.aspx?path=mbball& Big East Conference Men's Basketball Tournament]''' in early March, which determines the conference's automatic representative in the wildly popular NCAA tournament. Finally, in late March, the Garden hosts the semifinals and finals of the '''[https://www.ncaa.com/championships/basketball-men/nit National Invitation Tournament]''' ('''NIT'''), a tournament that the NCAA operates as something of a consolation prize for teams that do not make the NCAA tournament.
points_of_interest.hours: Box office: M-F 9AM-6PM, Sa 10AM-6PM; if event takes place outside regular hours, box office opens at least 1 hour before event start until 1 hour after event start

points_of_interest.name: AMC Empire 25
points_of_interest.description: This large multiplex cinema shows first-run, mainstream films on 25 screens. It also contains an IMAX cinema showing mainstream feature films.
points_of_interest.hours: First showings begin around noon, last showings begin at around 11PM

points_of_interest.name: West 4th Street Courts
points_of_interest.description: Even if you haven't heard of these basketball courts, you've probably seen them in TV commercials and movies, as "The Cage" (referring to the small, chain-link fence enclosed court) is the site of many intense, very physical pick-up games and informal "streetball" tournament matches. It's not a place to play unless you really know what you're getting into, but it's worth watching if you're interested in a more intense, physical form of basketball.

points_of_interest.name: New York Mets
points_of_interest.description: The New York Mets have been playing baseball since 1962. Many people of all ages enjoy watching baseball, eating hot dogs or other food from the stadium, drinking beer, and enjoying the weather. (Outside food and drinks are not allowed inside. Security is strict.) Games on Monday through Saturday are usually in the evening, and games on Sundays are usually in the afternoon. The New York Mets are one of two Major League Baseball teams in New York City. The New York Mets and New York Yankees have a rivalry, and almost nobody likes both teams. This stadium was built in 2009, it has excellent sight lines, and its entrance pays homage to the arched facade of Ebbets Field, the long-since-demolished ballpark of the old Brooklyn Dodgers. The entrance is named the Jackie Robinson Rotunda, honoring the first black player in modern Major League Baseball, who played for the Dodgers at Ebbets Field. A museum dedicated to the New York Mets is next to the rotunda, and it is open on game days. If the Mets hit a home run, look for the Home Run Apple rising out of the center field wall. The area surrounding the stadium has nothing to do, though.

points_of_interest.name: Schimanski
points_of_interest.description: Another large electronic dance music club.

points_of_interest.name: St. Ann's Warehouse
points_of_interest.description: A nondescript building on the corner of Water and Dock Streets, St. Ann's Warehouse delivers consistently impressive avant garde theater.

points_of_interest.name: John Jay Park
points_of_interest.description: Not many know of the peaceful nature of the area of Manhattan just by the East River, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have any special gems nearby. Just along the bustling FDR Drive is the peaceful yet impressive John Jay Park, which doesn't only include traditional benches and playgrounds for a quick rest but an outdoor pool in the summer that makes this area great for anyone looking for water sports in this area of New York City.
points_of_interest.address: Cherokee Place between East 78th Street and East 76th Street

points_of_interest.name: Chelsea Piers
points_of_interest.description: 28-acre waterfront sports village. Amenities include golf, bowling, skating, batting cages, rock climbing, fitness center, and a spa.

points_of_interest.name: Birdland Jazz Club
points_of_interest.description: This historic club (though not at the original location of W. 52 St.) — universally acknowledged as one of the top jazz venues in the city — features a great lineup of justly famous performers and has good acoustics. Expect to pay a fair price for that quality.

points_of_interest.name: Flushing Meadows Golf Center
points_of_interest.description: 18-hole public golf course with short drives. Golf club rental available. Miniature golf.
points_of_interest.hours: Open all year, if weather allows. May 15-Oct: 8AM-1AM; Oct-May 15: 9AM-sunset

points_of_interest.name: St. Catherine's Park
points_of_interest.description: A hidden gem that's been a hotspot for Upper East Side recreation since 1996. While the area may seem like any park welcoming screaming children from nearby areas and plenty of areas to exercise such as basketball courts and the running track, this park is so much more. Such a small park is so rich in history, mimicing Rome's Santa Maria Sopra Minerva church and including many Roman-influenced details few and far between. If you're in this area, be sure to pay the park a visit.

points_of_interest.name: Carnegie Hall
points_of_interest.description: If you ask a New Yorker how to get to Carnegie Hall, you may get the answer "Practice, practice!" This elegant 19th-century hall is New York's premier venue for famous recitalists and visiting symphony orchestras. The complex also includes the more intimate Weill Recital Hall slightly further east and Zankel Hall, in the basement of the side of the building facing 7th Av. near 56th St, a medium-sized venue used by jazz groups and classical concert pianists, alike.

points_of_interest.name: Kissena Golf Course
points_of_interest.description: 4,665-yard golf course.

points_of_interest.name: Hudson Theatre
points_of_interest.description: This theater is over 100 years old and remains the third oldest theater on Broadway. Located right next to the Millennium Broadway Hotel, it remained defunct as a theater for decades, acting as the hotel's event space, before reopening in February 2017.

points_of_interest.name: Wheel Fun Rentals
points_of_interest.description: Bicycle rentals. Also rents kayaks and boats on Willow Lake.
points_of_interest.hours: Noon-sunset. Opens earlier in summer and on weekends. Closed Nov-Mar.

points_of_interest.name: Kramer's Reality Tour
points_of_interest.description: For ''Seinfeld'' fans. Kenny Kramer, said to be the inspiration for the character Kramer, tells about the show, in a fun way. And guides on a tour to places seen in the show. Stop for photo outside the restaurant seen in the show.

points_of_interest.name: World Ice Arena
points_of_interest.description: Indoor ice-skating rink.
points_of_interest.hours: Sa noon-4:45PM, 8-9:50PM; Su noon-4:45PM; M-Th 10:30AM-5:15PM; F 10:30AM-5:15PM, 8PM-9:50PM

points_of_interest.name: Wicked the Musical
points_of_interest.description: An incredibly popular show which has been on Broadway for roughly ten years, Wicked is one of the highest rated shows that has ever hit Broadway. It's based on the ''Wizard of Oz'', but told from the witch's point of view instead of Dorothy's. The show runs about 2 hours and 45 minutes.

points_of_interest.name: Apollo Theater
points_of_interest.description: The legendary Apollo Theater, "where stars are born and legends made", is a source of pride for Harlem, and a symbol of American artistic achievement. The Apollo is best known for its world-famous '''Amateur Night at the Apollo''', which launched the careers of legendary artists like Ella Fitzgerald, James Brown, Michael Jackson, D'Angelo and Lauryn Hill. The Apollo remains the nation's most popular arena for emerging and established black and Latino performers.

points_of_interest.name: The Lion King
points_of_interest.description: The highest grossing stage production of all time, this musical based on the 1994 Disney animated film has won numerous awards and has been going strong since its premiere in 1997. This show runs about 2 hours and 40 minutes.

points_of_interest.name: Broadway Comedy Club
points_of_interest.description: This is one of the most respected comedy clubs in all of New York City, one that has played host to the likes of Joe Devito, Scott McFadden, Jimmy Fallon, David Letterman, and many others who have gone on to make it big in television. Tickets generally run for about $20 a night, and include a free pitcher of beer. Shows run up until as late as 11PM and are a great way for you to end your evening.

points_of_interest.name: Marjorie's Parlor Jazz
points_of_interest.description: One of the most charmingly intimate jazz venues anywhere is simply Marjorie Eliot's apartment in Harlem. It's somewhat a jam session, although there are regulars, drawing an attentive and eclectic crowd including music students from China, neighbors from the building, and everyone in between. Seating is first come, first served, so it does make sense to be there by 4PM. As friendly and hospitable as it gets, people will come around with cookies and juice during breaks. Note that getting off the subway at 155th St will require a long, steep climb up steps to get from lower 155th to Edgecombe.

points_of_interest.name: The Phantom of the Opera
points_of_interest.description: The longest running show on Broadway with nearly full seating at every show! A classic musical with phenomenal pieces composed by Andrew Lloyd Webber, special effects, and prodigy acting. Recommended for Broadway first-timers.
points_of_interest.hours: Regular shows: W-M 8PM, Tu 7PM, Th & Sa 2PM

points_of_interest.name: Beacon Theatre
points_of_interest.description: This is a major music performance venue for big-time solo acts and groups, and many, many famous artists have performed there, including The Rolling Stones, Jerry Garcia, Aerosmith, Michael Jackson, James Taylor, Radiohead, Queen and the Allman Brothers. Prices are not cheap, and tickets sometimes sell out well in advance.
points_of_interest.hours: Box Office hours: M-Sa 11AM - 7PM; if an event starts before 1PM, the Box Office will open 1 hour before event start time; if an event starts after 6:30PM, Box Office will remain open 30 minutes after event start time. Sunday: closed, except that if an event takes place on Sunday, the Box Office will open at noon or 90 minutes before the event start time (whichever is earlier) and remain open 30 minutes after event start time for Will Call and tickets sales for the evening's event only

points_of_interest.name: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
points_of_interest.description: The world's largest cultural complex, where you can see theater, symphonies, ballet, opera, movies, art exhibits or just wander the architecturally beautiful buildings. The buildings are modern, and even have modern chandeliers. There are two opera companies, and the famous Juilliard School of Music is also here. Also part of the complex is the New York Public Library's Library for the Performing Arts, containing circulating and non-circulating collections in music, drama, and dance, as well as special collections of priceless documents that scholars from around the world come to look at.
points_of_interest.address: between West 62nd and 66th Streets and Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues

points_of_interest.name: Ancient Playground
points_of_interest.description: Inspired by the nearby Egyptian Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this playground contains several pyramid-like play structures.

points_of_interest.name: Staten Island Zoo
points_of_interest.description: It's in West New Brighton, and is a fun destination for younger children as well as animal enthusiasts. The zoo used to have the most snake species of any zoo in the world. It no longer holds that title, but still has a substantial reptile wing.

points_of_interest.name: Billy Johnson Playground
points_of_interest.description: A rustic-themed playground, with a stone bridge, a granite slide, a gazebo, a water feature, and playground equipment constructed of white cedar.

points_of_interest.name: Heckscher Playground
points_of_interest.description: Central Park's largest playground, Heckscher is unique among Central Park's playgrounds in that it is not on the boundaries of the park. The playground has a range of play equipment, including a large water feature.
points_of_interest.address: 64-04 Center Drive, New York, New York 10000, United States

points_of_interest.name: Pat Hoffman Friedman Playground
points_of_interest.description: A small toddler playground with some beautifully fashioned gates adorned with sculptures of animals. In front of the gates stands Paul Manship's ''Group of Bears'' sculpture.

points_of_interest.name: Atrium Stadium Theaters
points_of_interest.description: Another large movie theater, the Atrium is also great for taking in a movie.

points_of_interest.name: Safari Playground
points_of_interest.description: A jungle themed playground with hippopotamus statues, a "canoe" play structure, and treehouses.

points_of_interest.name: Merkin Concert Hall
points_of_interest.description: Important and fairly prestigious venue for classical music, much of it contemporary, and various other kinds of performances. The hall seats about 250 people and has good acoustics for chamber music. This hall is near Lincoln Center but is not part of it; instead, it is part of the Kaufman Music Center, which also runs music schools for children.
points_of_interest.hours: Box office hours: Su–Th noon–7PM; F noon–3PM; Sa the Box Office opens one hour prior to curtain time

points_of_interest.name: Wild West Playground
points_of_interest.description: A Western-themed playground with a wooded fortress-like setting, canals, sandboxes, and water sprays.

points_of_interest.name: Symphony Space
points_of_interest.description: Symphony Space used to be the Symphony movie theater back in the 1970s, and it still occasionally screens films, but it is more often used, nowadays, as a performance venue. The offerings are eclectic, and though ticket prices have crept up, there are quite a few inexpensive shows, especially at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia, another former movie theater around the corner on 95 St. between Broadway and West End Ave.
points_of_interest.hours: Box Office hours: Tu-Su 1PM - 6PM, open two hours prior to performances and events.

points_of_interest.name: Miller Theater
points_of_interest.description: Miller Theater is Columbia University's main performing arts venue and is well known for its classical music performances.

points_of_interest.name: Delacorte Theater
points_of_interest.description: Home to the Public Theater/New York Shakespeare Festival in the summer.
points_of_interest.address: 81 Central Park West, New York, New York 10028, United States

points_of_interest.name: Cotton Club
points_of_interest.description: A dance club/dinner club near Columbia University. Swing dancing is on Monday nights (8:30PM-midnight, $25), with a 13-piece swing band. Friday nights at 8:30PM are taken over by Latin Dance ($20) with a live 14-piece band playing merengue and bachata, appropriately for Dominican-heavy West Harlem. Th 8PM and Sa 9PM are jazz/dinner and dancing nights ($55) for a southern cooking buffet and swing band, while Sa-Su have gospel brunches at noon and 2:30PM ($45).

points_of_interest.name: SummerStage
points_of_interest.description: A popular free concert series held in the summer.

points_of_interest.name: Smoke Jazz Club and Lounge
points_of_interest.description: Live jazz seven days a week. Performers often jam late into the night so go for the late set if you can.

points_of_interest.name: Riverside Park
points_of_interest.description: While nearby Central Park is justly famous and finds its way onto a "must see" list for most visitors to New York, Riverside Park also has its charms, as its riverfront location provides pleasant views of New Jersey and sometimes breezes off the river. Summer brings al fresco movies, plays and music to Riverside Park.

points_of_interest.name: Lincoln Square 13 Cinema
points_of_interest.description: A multiplex two blocks from Lincoln Center, showing major, first-run films on 13 screens. It also contains an IMAX cinema showing mainstream feature films.
points_of_interest.hours: First showings begin around noon, last showings begin around 11PM

points_of_interest.name: Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
points_of_interest.address: 79-01 West Drive, New York, New York 10006, United States

points_of_interest.name: Amundsen Circle
points_of_interest.description: A small park that is not much more than a clearing and some trees. A monument to the man the park was named for, Roald Amundsen, stands in the center of it.

points_of_interest.name: Lower East Side Tenement Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, located in Manhattan's vibrant Lower East Side, offers a glimpse into the lives of immigrants who shaped New York City. Housed in two historic tenement buildings, the museum explores the stories of thousands of residents who called this place home over nearly 150 years. Through guided tours and exhibits, visitors gain insight into the challenges and resilience of these newcomers. The museum also serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of tolerance and understanding, highlighting the enduring legacy of immigration in America. A must-visit for history enthusiasts and anyone curious about the city's cultural roots.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-F 11AM-6PM, Sa Su 10:45AM-6PM, M (visitor center only; no tours) 11AM-5:30PM

points_of_interest.name: Chatham Square
points_of_interest.description: At this square at the confluence of several major streets, there is a memorial archway to Chinese-Americans who died in World War II which has some interesting calligraphy. Also in the square is a statue of Lin Zexu, a Chinese scholar who opposed the opium trade in the 19th century.
points_of_interest.address: 4 Chatham Square, New York, New York 10038, United States

points_of_interest.name: Woolworth Building
points_of_interest.description: One of the oldest and most famous of New York's skyscrapers (dubbed the "Cathedral of Commerce"), the neo-Gothic Woolworth Building was completed in 1913 and was the world's tallest building until 1930. The building has a beautiful ornate lobby. Tours are offered most days. Pre-registration is required.

points_of_interest.name: Alamo
points_of_interest.description: A sculpture at the center of Astor Place. This steel cube actually rotates as you push on any side, though you may need the strength of two or three people for a complete rotation. One of its sister cubes resides on the University of Michigan campus in Ann Arbor, Michigan. This sculpture was removed in 2015 but returned to an enlarged pedestrian area in the fall of 2016.
points_of_interest.address: 26 Astor Place, New York, New York 10003, United States

points_of_interest.name: Greenacre Park
points_of_interest.description: One of New York's many "pocket parks," Greenacre is a small plot of green space and an excellent place to relax, with a nice waterfall in the back, plenty of seats and tables, and lots of shade, plus a small tea shop.

points_of_interest.name: American Irish Historical Society
points_of_interest.description: Yet another unique but rich treat on 5th Avenue, the AIHS is a non-profit organization that educates visitors on Irish American culture and history. Immersive and traditional events are held often along with exhibits showcasing the array of unique art and music. If performing and visual arts aren't your thing, you can visit the library instead with over 10,000 books, newsletters, newspapers, and pieces of literature dating back to the 1700s that feature a wide variety of otherwise unknown topics that are great for anyone interested in European culture and history.

points_of_interest.name: Consolidated Edison Building
points_of_interest.description: This landmark building, constructed as a 19-story tower from 1911-1914 and enlarged to 26 stories in 1929, is still visible from some distance away. Its greatest claim to fame is its clock tower, with a loggia above the clock and just below the roof that is beautifully illuminated at night, often in blue but sometimes in another color or changing colors. You can recognize it because the lights are partially blocked by four pillars on each side. This remains the headquarters of ConEdison, so the interior is not a tourist attraction but you can walk around the exterior, and the upper reaches of the tower are very easily viewable by looking east from Union Square Park.

points_of_interest.name: High Line Park
