points_of_interest.description: Built on a defunct elevated railway that runs 30 feet above the streets, the re-purposing of the rail line as a park has made it the focus of major development in the neighborhood. There are plenty of plantings and art installations along the park as it winds its way between (and through!) buildings, and walking the stretch offers some pretty unique views over the streets of Manhattan. No dogs or bicycles. There are restrooms at Gansevoort St. (the southern terminus), 16th St, and 30th St.
points_of_interest.address: Runs mostly along 10th Avenue from 34th Street south to Gansevoort Street in the Meatpacking District, with access points at Gansevoort, 14th, 16th, 17th, 20th, 23rd, 26th, 28th, 30th, and 34th Streets
points_of_interest.hours: Open daily Apr–May, Oct–Nov: 7AM–10PM; June–Sept: 7AM–11PM; Dec–Mar: 7AM–7PM

points_of_interest.name: Times Square
points_of_interest.description: A place filled with video screens, LED signs, and flashing lights; a world wonder or a tourist nightmare depending on your perspective, the "new" Times Square is a family-friendly theme park of themed restaurants, theaters and hotels, as well as a developing business district. The lights and signs can be viewed anytime, but the most enchanting experience comes when one visits Times Square at night, as all the signs and screens are ablaze with color. Times Square is also well known for its famous New Year's Eve ball drop. Those looking for the seedy Times Square of years past will find it around the Port Authority Bus Terminal, and on Eighth Avenue to the west.
points_of_interest.address: Broadway and 7th Avenue, stretching from 42nd to 48th Streets

points_of_interest.name: City Hall
points_of_interest.description: On a triangular city block between Broadway, Park Row and Chambers Street sits City Hall, a gorgeous gleaming white building completed in 1812, which still hosts the mayor's office and the New York City Council chambers. The building itself is fenced off and only accessible by tour, but there is a lovely park surrounding the building, with plenty of shady trees and a pleasant fountain just to the south of the building. Just north of City Hall and on the same block is the {{marker|type=see|name=Tweed Courthouse|lat=40.71337|long=-74.00555}}, a gorgeous government structure and the legacy of Tammany Hall boss William M. Tweed, who used the courthouse project to embezzle large sums of money from the city budget and was convicted in a courtroom in this building.
points_of_interest.address: 1 City Hall, New York, New York 10007, United States

points_of_interest.name: The Wall
points_of_interest.description: Gateway to Soho A 1973 piece of minimalist artwork — actually, ranging for 8 stories, quite large rather than minimal — by Forrest Myers graces the blind wall of the building at 599 Broadway. It has actually been removed and rebuilt in the 2000s because of its impact on the wall it is placed on, placed higher to allow for street-level advertising below it. Because of its prominent location at the intersection of Broadway and Houston Street, it is often referred to as marking the ''Gateway to Soho''.

points_of_interest.name: Ansonia
points_of_interest.description: Formerly the Ansonia Hotel This pretty 17-story Beaux Arts building was completed in 1904 and designed to be New York City's first air conditioned hotel. It was a residential hotel, and housed a number of very famous people, including the Hall of Fame baseball player, Babe Ruth; the Italian tenor, Enrico Caruso; the modernist composer, Igor Stravinsky; the Italian conductor of the NBC Symphony, Arturo Toscanini; and writers Theodore Dreiser and Isaac Bashevis Singer. The building is now a condominium.

points_of_interest.name: The Cloisters
points_of_interest.description: Located on four acres overlooking the Hudson River in Fort Tryon Park, the building incorporates elements from five medieval French cloisters – quadrangles enclosed by a roofed or vaulted passageway, or arcade – and from other monastic sites in southern France. There are various artworks on display in the museum, with the Unicorn Tapestries being the most famous.
points_of_interest.address: 99 Margaret Corbin Drive, Fort Tryon Park
points_of_interest.hours: Mar–Oct: daily 10 AM–5:15 PM; Nov–Feb: daily 10 AM–4:45 PM (closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year's Day)

points_of_interest.name: Arsenal
points_of_interest.description: A picturesque brick building that actually predates the park. It was built in 1851 to serve as a munitions supply depot for the New York State National Guard, and was designed to look like a medieval fortress, with battlements overlooking the area. Today the building holds a refreshment stand and WPA murals depicting park activities.

points_of_interest.name: Forest Park Carousel
points_of_interest.description: The Forest Park Carousel, located in Queens, New York City, is a historic treasure and one of the oldest carousels in the U.S., crafted by Daniel Carl Muller around 1903. Housed in a charming pavilion, it features 52 hand-carved figures, including horses with intricate details like glass eyes and real horsehair, along with menagerie animals and chariots. Accompanied by a vintage band organ, the carousel offers a delightful experience. Part of the Forest Park Carousel Amusement Village, it has been beautifully restored and is both a National Register of Historic Places listing and a NYC landmark, making it a must-visit attraction.
points_of_interest.address: 82-74 89th Street, Woodhaven, New York 11385, United States

points_of_interest.name: King Manor Museum
points_of_interest.description: King Manor Museum, located in Rufus King Park, is a historic house museum in Jamaica, Queens. This 18th-century home, once the estate of Rufus King, a U.S. Founding Father, offers a glimpse into the region's rich history. The museum showcases period furnishings and hosts various exhibits and programs, making it a fascinating destination for history enthusiasts.

points_of_interest.name: Museum of the Moving Image
points_of_interest.description: A museum devoted to, literally, moving images, so visitors will find exhibits on zoetropes and video games in addition to film and television. They also put on a terrific screening program, with films showing continuously throughout the day.

points_of_interest.name: Flushing Meadows–Corona Park
points_of_interest.description: Flushing Meadows–Corona Park is a sprawling green oasis offering a serene escape from the city bustle. The park features two picturesque lakes, meandering walking paths, and expansive grassy areas ideal for picnics. Visitors can unwind, enjoy nature, and take in the scenic beauty. Spanning 897 acres, the park is perfect for those who love to explore on foot or by bike. Bicycle rentals are available near the north entrance, making it easy to discover all the park has to offer. Whether you're looking to relax or stay active, Flushing Meadows–Corona Park provides a welcoming space for all to enjoy.
points_of_interest.address: 17 Ederle Promenade, Forest Hills, New York 11375, United States

points_of_interest.name: Louis Armstrong House Museum
points_of_interest.description: A cultural highlight of the neighboring community of Corona is the Louis Armstrong House Museum, where the jazz legend lived from 1943 to his death in 1971. Armstrong and his wife Lucille chose to live in a modest single family house in an area that was once home to a number of African American performers and other luminaries. The museum preserves the furnishings and artwork pretty much just as Louis and Lucille left them, and also has a collection of Armstrong's recordings and other memorabilia. The adjacent garden — Louis' pride and joy and the only thing that distinguishes the house from its neighbors on the street — is occasionally used for concerts, notably on July 4 (Louis' stated birthday) and August 4 (determined after his death to be his actual birthday).
points_of_interest.hours: First tour begins at 11:30 AM, last at 3:30 PM

points_of_interest.name: Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge
points_of_interest.description: A rare bit of nature in New York. While much of the reserve has been helped along by human hands, it is still well worth visiting to see what Queens looked like before all the development. There are several walks.
points_of_interest.address: 175-04 Cross Bay Boulevard, Howard Beach, New York 11693, United States

points_of_interest.name: Gowanus Canal
points_of_interest.description: The Gowanus Canal, a 1.8-mile waterway in Brooklyn, is a complex blend of industrial history and modern transformation. Once a bustling cargo hub, it has faced significant pollution challenges due to decades of heavy industrial use. Despite its contaminated state, the canal is seeing renewed attention as part of Brooklyn’s waterfront redevelopment efforts. Designated a Superfund site in 2009, cleanup efforts began in 2013, aiming to restore this vital waterway. The canal’s proximity to vibrant neighborhoods like Gowanus, Carroll Gardens, and Park Slope highlights its potential for future revitalization, making it a fascinating, if flawed, urban landmark.
points_of_interest.address: 426 President Street, Brooklyn, New York 11231, United States

points_of_interest.name: Coney Island
points_of_interest.description: Coney Island is a vibrant Brooklyn destination known for its iconic boardwalk, sandy beaches, and rich history as a classic seaside escape. Once a booming amusement park hub in the early 20th century, Coney Island has evolved into a lively mix of nostalgia and modern charm. Visitors can enjoy thrilling rides, stroll along the waterfront, and sample classic treats like Nathan’s Famous hot dogs. The area has undergone revitalization in recent years, blending its storied past with new attractions and cultural offerings. Whether you’re here for adventure or relaxation, Coney Island’s dynamic energy makes it a must-visit Brooklyn gem.
points_of_interest.address: 2859 Stillwell Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11224, United States

points_of_interest.name: Grand Army Plaza
points_of_interest.description: The gateway to Prospect Park, laid out in 1870. The Soldiers and Sailors Arch was added in 1892 as a memorial to the victorious Union Army. The Plaza itself is a large traffic circle surrounded by trees; apartment buildings; the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, itself a large distinctive landmark building; and a memorial bust of President John F. Kennedy. Each June, Grand Army Plaza is the focus for the ''Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival'' for those who lived in the borough.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn, New York 11238, United States

points_of_interest.name: Bedford Avenue
points_of_interest.description: The area around the Bedford Avenue subway stop is one of the most lively areas and a great place to hang out and see hipsters (as well as many tourists).
points_of_interest.address: 167 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11211, United States

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Children's Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Brooklyn Children's Museum, located in Crown Heights, is the first children's museum in the United States and one of the oldest in the world. Housed in a unique multi-level underground space, it offers an engaging environment for young learners. After a major expansion and renovation, the museum reopened in 2008, doubling its size and becoming New York City's first green-certified museum. Its innovative design and interactive exhibits make it a must-visit destination for families exploring Brooklyn.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu W F 10AM-5PM, Th 10AM-6PM, Sa Su 10AM-7PM

points_of_interest.name: Cypress Hills Cemetery
points_of_interest.description: Cypress Hills Cemetery is a historic non-sectarian cemetery located in Brooklyn and Queens, New York City. Established as the city’s first non-denominational cemetery, it spans 225 acres and is divided by the Jackie Robinson Parkway. Situated in the Cemetery Belt, it offers a peaceful retreat with two main entrances on Jamaica Avenue and Cooper Avenue. Nearby, Cemetery of the Evergreens adds to the serene landscape, making this site a notable part of the area’s heritage.
points_of_interest.address: East Dolorosa, Brooklyn, New York 11208, United States

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Borough Hall
points_of_interest.description: Brooklyn Borough Hall is a notable landmark in Downtown Brooklyn, showcasing Greek Revival architecture with its Tuckahoe marble facade. Completed in 1848, it originally served as the City Hall for the independent City of Brooklyn. Following the city's merger with New York in 1898, the building transitioned into its current role as Brooklyn Borough Hall, symbolizing the borough's rich history and civic significance.

points_of_interest.name: Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help
points_of_interest.description: The Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help is a Roman Catholic minor basilica and Marian shrine located in Brooklyn, New York. This sacred site is dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary under the title of Our Mother of Perpetual Succour, drawing pilgrims and visitors seeking spiritual solace. Elevated to its status as a minor basilica by Pope Paul VI, the basilica stands as a significant place of worship and reflection, offering a serene atmosphere for those exploring Brooklyn’s rich religious heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Blue Heron Park
points_of_interest.description: Blue Heron Park, located on Staten Island's South Shore, is a serene retreat offering a mix of natural habitats, including meadows, woodlands, marshes, and kettle ponds. Part of Staten Island's Blue Belt system, the park plays a crucial role in stormwater drainage while providing a peaceful escape for visitors. The park is home to diverse wildlife, such as the namesake blue heron, along with raccoons, squirrels, and bats. A visitors center off Poillon Avenue serves as the gateway to three trails that wind through the park's varied landscapes, making it an ideal spot for nature enthusiasts and those seeking a tranquil escape.

points_of_interest.name: Lower East Side Visitor Center
points_of_interest.description: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, a National Historic Site, offers a poignant glimpse into the lives of immigrants who shaped New York City. Housed in two historic tenement buildings, the museum explores the stories of thousands of families who called this space home between the 19th and 21st centuries. The adjacent visitor center provides insights into the neighborhood's rich history and its role in the immigrant experience. Through educational programs and exhibits, the museum fosters understanding and tolerance, making it a must-visit for those interested in the city's cultural heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Columbus Park
points_of_interest.description: An excellent place to relax and people-watch. Early in the mornings, people practice their tai-chi there. If you're interested, some of these people might teach you a little bit of it. At times, there are a group of women practicing the traditional Chinese fhan dances. Also, usually in the summer time there are basketball tournaments one may either participate in or watch. In the afternoon when school is out, many adolescents hang out in this park.

points_of_interest.name: Hook & Ladder #8
points_of_interest.description: Hook & Ladder #8 is a historic firehouse turned popular tourist attraction. Known for its charming architecture and rich history in firefighting, it offers a fascinating glimpse into the past. Visitors can explore the vintage equipment and learn about its role in early fire prevention. A highlight for many is the legend of its supposedly cursed fire pole, adding a touch of intrigue to the visit. With its unique blend of history and local lore, Hook & Ladder #8 is a must-visit for those interested in firefighting heritage and quirky legends.

points_of_interest.name: Cooper Union
points_of_interest.description: Until 2014, Cooper Union was the only private, full-scholarship college in the United States dedicated exclusively to preparing students for the professions of art, architecture and engineering. It now charges tuition for regular classes but still gives free extension courses. The college, established in 1859, occupies several buildings, but the most recognizable and famous is the Foundation Building, on the block to the south of Astor Place between the two branches of Cooper Square (one being the southward extension of 3rd Av. and the other, an avenue that connects the Bowery with 4th Av. at Astor Place). The college, the legacy of Peter Cooper, occupies a special place in the history of American education.

points_of_interest.name: Paley Park
points_of_interest.description: Another pocket park which is celebrated among landscape architects and urban designers, Paley is a great place to relax, with plenty of chairs below a canopy of trees and a waterfall spanning the entire back wall of the park.

points_of_interest.name: Asia Society Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Asia Society is a unique educational organization like no other in the area promoting relationships and understanding among and of leaders, people, and organizations of Asia. It features a vast array of Asian art including art, business, culture, and education, promoting collaboration and a new, progressive understanding of Asian relations. The opportunities for discovery here are endless, with lessons about art, calligraphy, language, literature, politics, and religion.

points_of_interest.name: New York Public Library
points_of_interest.description: The main branch of the New York Public Library (the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building), this is the grand structure flanked by lions on both sides of the entrance. Inside you'll see impressive architecture, long hallways, and beautifully designed reading rooms.
points_of_interest.hours: M Th-Sa 10AM-6PM, Tu W 10AM-7:30PM, closed Su

points_of_interest.name: Poster House (Museum)
points_of_interest.description: Poster House is the first museum in the United States dedicated entirely to the art of posters. Nestled in the heart of Chelsea, Manhattan, this unique cultural destination invites visitors to explore the fascinating history and impact of posters. With a diverse collection that spans decades, Poster House offers a fresh perspective on how posters have shaped culture, advertising, and art. Whether you're a design enthusiast or just curious, this engaging museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in the power of visual communication.

points_of_interest.name: TKTS Booth
points_of_interest.description: A ticket booth selling discounted Broadway and off-Broadway shows. However, the cheaper tickets aren't the only attraction, as the back of the booth is a large, red-lit glass staircase facing Times Square, which serves as a set of bleachers and offers an excellent opportunity to get above the street and just watch the crowds and flashing signs. Above the booth is a video screen with a live feed of the top step, giving you a chance to appear (if only briefly) on one of the many signs in Times Square.
points_of_interest.hours: Booth: tickets for evening performances Tu 2-8PM, M and W-Sa 3-8PM, Su 3-7PM; tickets for matinee performances W-Th and Sa 10AM-2PM, Su 11AM-3PM

points_of_interest.name: City Hall Station
points_of_interest.description: The original subway station, and quite a marvel to witness--the chandeliers and ornate tiling are a sharp contrast to the nearby Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall station. There's one catch, though: it's been closed since 1945. However, you can see it by staying on the downtown '''6''' train after its last stop '''Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall'''; it will turn around in the old station. This is the one place in the system where this is allowed, and the announcements reflect that. The Transit Museum (in Downtown Brooklyn) offers occasional tours as well, which allow you to actually walk around the station, but you must be a museum member and a US citizen, making this an impractical choice for most visitors.
points_of_interest.address: 257 Broadway, New York, New York 10007, United States

points_of_interest.name: E. V. Haughwout Building
points_of_interest.description: One of the finest examples of the cast-iron-facade buildings that SoHo is famous for. Built in 1857, it is considered as one of the first buildings where the cast-iron structure was left uncovered and rather shaped into the ornamental form replacing a traditional brick, stone or plaster facade. Mr Haughwout ran a tableware emporium sprawling over the building's five stories, famous far beyond the city to the extent that it was there where Mary Todd Lincoln purchased new china for the White House. The emporium also provided customers with a convenience that was a world first — a passenger elevator by Elisha Otis, soon to become a ''de rigeur'' amenity of all new buildings in New York.

points_of_interest.name: Apthorp
points_of_interest.description: A beautiful early 20th-century high-rise luxury apartment building, taking up the entire square block between 78th and 79th Sts. between Broadway and West End Avenue. Its companion, the '''Belnord''', takes up the square block between 86th and 87th Sts. between Broadway and Amsterdam. Both buildings were completed in 1908, at a time when the Upper West Side was still full of wide open spaces.

points_of_interest.name: Washington Square Park
points_of_interest.description: The park and its famous arch are located in the heart of the Village. Though located in the middle of an affluent neighborhood, the park attracts a hodgepodge of people. During the warmer months of the school term, the park is a favourite hangout spot for students from nearby NYU. Part of the charm of the park is the view of the buildings across the street. All these buildings are now owned by NYU, and though there has been some controversial construction in the early 2010s, most of the stately 19th-century dwellings pictured in the classic movie ''The Heiress'' (based on Henry James' novel, ''Washington Square'') are still there for you to enjoy looking at.
points_of_interest.address: 49-57 Washington Square South, New York, New York 10003, United States

points_of_interest.name: Dyckman Farmhouse
points_of_interest.description: The former residence of William Dyckman, who owned several hundred acres of farmland covering much of what is now Inwood and Washington heights. Nestled incongruously at the otherwise unremarkable corner of 204th and Broadway, the farmhouse has been converted into a small museum of life in early Manhattan and hosts various programs for the neighborhood. The "Hessian Huts" in the back yard are a leftover from the British occupation of Manhattan during the Revolutionary War!
points_of_interest.hours: Apr–Aug: Th–Sa 11AM–4PM, Su 11AM–3PM; Sep–Oct: Th–Sa 11AM–4PM; Nov–Mar: F Sa 11AM–4PM

points_of_interest.name: Balto Statue
points_of_interest.description: In Central Park stands a bronze statue honoring Balto, a heroic Alaskan husky. This sculpture by Frederick Roth commemorates Balto's pivotal role in the 1925 serum run to Nome, where he led a team of sled dogs to deliver life-saving diphtheria antitoxin. Balto's bravery during this mission made him a celebrated figure, symbolizing resilience and determination. The statue is a charming spot for visitors to pause and reflect on this remarkable tale of heroism.

points_of_interest.name: St. John's University
points_of_interest.description: St. John's University, a private Catholic institution in Queens, New York City, was founded in 1870 by the Congregation of the Mission. Originally in Brooklyn, the main campus moved to Queens in the 1950s. The university also has a Manhattan campus and international locations in Rome, Paris, and Limerick. Known for its diverse academic offerings, St. John's provides a wide range of undergraduate and graduate programs. With a global student body and alumni network, the university is a vibrant part of New York City's educational landscape, blending tradition with modern opportunities for students from around the world.

points_of_interest.name: The Noguchi Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Noguchi Museum, located in Long Island City, Queens, is a serene destination showcasing the works of Isamu Noguchi. This museum and sculpture garden preserves and displays Noguchi's diverse creations, including sculptures, models, stage designs, and furniture. Renovated in 2004, the museum now offers year-round access, inviting visitors to explore its indoor and outdoor spaces. Situated near Socrates Sculpture Park, it's a must-visit for art enthusiasts and those seeking a tranquil retreat in the city.

points_of_interest.name: New York Hall of Science
points_of_interest.description: Built as a pavilion for the 1964 World's Fair, this science center is now full of hands-on exhibits for the public. Highlights include Sports Challenge, Rocket Park (featuring full sized Atlas and Titan tickets), and a science playground.
points_of_interest.hours: Sep-Mar: Tu-Th 9:30AM-2PM, F 9:30AM-5PM, Sa Su 10AM-6PM; Apr-Jun: M-Th 9:30AM-2PM, F 9:30AM-5PM, Sa Su 10AM-6PM; Jul-Aug: M-F 9:30AM-5PM, Sa,Su 10AM-6PM

points_of_interest.name: Kentler International Drawing Space
points_of_interest.description: Kentler International Drawing Space is a unique cultural destination that celebrates the intersection of art, mathematics, and creativity. Inspired by the Fibonacci sequence and the golden ratio, the space explores how these principles influence design, aesthetics, and human perception. Visitors can discover exhibits that showcase the Fibonacci sequence in art, architecture, and music, offering a fascinating blend of logic and beauty. This attraction is perfect for those intrigued by the mathematical foundations of creativity and seeking a thought-provoking experience.

points_of_interest.name: The Coney Island Cyclone
points_of_interest.description: Opened in 1927, the Coney Island Cyclone or (the Cyclone) is one of the world's oldest and still operating wooden roller coasters and was declared a New York City Landmark on July 2, 1988. It was also placed on the National Register of Historic Places on June 26, 1991. Although in 1927 the roller coaster cost only 25 cents to ride, it now costs $10.
points_of_interest.address: 3017 Jones Walk, Brooklyn, New York 11224, United States

points_of_interest.name: Old Stone House
points_of_interest.description: Vechte-Cortelyou House 1930s replica of a Dutch colonial farmhouse that had been constructed on the site in 1699; the original structure was buried under landfill during the regrading of the Park Slope neighborhood in the early 1900s. Features an exhibit on ''the Battle of Brooklyn'', the first and largest battle of the American Revolution.

points_of_interest.name: The City Reliquary
points_of_interest.description: The City Reliquary is a charming not-for-profit community museum and civic organization nestled in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It celebrates the history and culture of New York City's five boroughs through engaging exhibitions of cultural ephemera and artifacts. Alongside its permanent collection of NYC relics, the museum showcases rotating exhibits featuring community collections and hosts annual cultural events, making it a vibrant destination for both locals and visitors.

points_of_interest.name: Jewish Children's Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Jewish Children's Museum is the largest Jewish-themed children's museum in the United States. It aims for children of all faiths and backgrounds to gain a positive perspective and awareness of the Jewish heritage, fostering tolerance and understanding. The permanent collection features exhibits designed to be both educational and entertaining to children, often employing interactive multimedia. At the miniature golf course on the roof, for example, each hole represents a stage in Jewish life. The museum is in the Chabad-Lubavitch Chasidic community of Crown Heights near the headquarters of the Lubavitch movement. The museum is run by Tzivos Hashem, a Chabad organization dedicated to the education of Jewish children. The museum opened in 2004. In 2005, the museum was among 406 New York City arts and social service institutions to receive part of a $20 million grant from the Carnegie Corporation, which was made possible through a donation by former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

points_of_interest.name: Marine Park
points_of_interest.description: Brooklyn's largest park, which includes 530 acres of protected grassland and salt marsh.
points_of_interest.address: Shore Pkwy., Avenue U, Filmore Ave. bet. Brigham St., Gerritsen Ave., and Flatbush Ave.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Bridge
points_of_interest.description: Work started in 1870 on the first bridge crossing of the East River between Manhattan and Brooklyn. This 1,595-ft suspension bridge was finally completed in 1883 - and, as a plaque on it says, it is a "structure of beauty.".
points_of_interest.address: Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, New York 11201, United States

points_of_interest.name: Basilica of Regina Pacis
points_of_interest.description: Step into this beautiful and grand Roman Catholic church and you might think you've been teleported to Italy. Be sure to look up. The paintings on the ceiling are breathtaking.

points_of_interest.name: Clawson Playground
points_of_interest.description: This deceivingly small park has two large asphalt playgrounds, two smaller ones, a grass field, a baseball field, basketball courts, and a jungle gym. It is always peaceful and rarely crowded, as it is shared by Public School 50 during school hours.
points_of_interest.hours: Open between dawn and dusk, except for school hours

points_of_interest.name: New Museum
points_of_interest.description: Building designed by award winning Japanese office SANAA. Contemporary art - the 'I don't get it' kind. Temporary exhibitions, also a good bookshop and Sky Room with views (weekends only).
points_of_interest.hours: M Tu closed, W F Sa Su 11AM - 6PM, Th 11AM - 9PM

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Chinese in the Americas
points_of_interest.description: Exhibits on the history and culture of Chinese-Americans.

points_of_interest.name: Hudson River Park
points_of_interest.description: Hudson River Park is a scenic 4.5-mile waterfront park along Manhattan's west side, stretching from Battery Park to 59th Street. This vibrant green space offers a mix of recreational activities, including bike and pedestrian paths, sports fields, playgrounds, and dog runs. The park also features rebuilt piers along the Hudson River, perfect for taking in the views. Connecting several Manhattan neighborhoods, including Greenwich Village, Chelsea, and Midtown West, Hudson River Park is a great spot to relax, exercise, or explore. Its convenient location and diverse amenities make it a must-visit for both locals and visitors.
points_of_interest.address: 229 West Street, New York, New York 10013, United States

points_of_interest.name: East River Park
points_of_interest.description: Most of this park is on the Lower East Side (and indeed the part of the East Village this far east is often also still called the Lower East Side or Loisaida), but the portion of it in the extreme East Village contains one or two baseball diamonds, some basketball courts, a playground or two and a well-tended path along the river that provides very worthwhile views in good weather. Popular with joggers, cyclists, picnickers, ball players, kids, and people taking a stroll.
points_of_interest.address: Montgomery St. to E. 12 St., FDR Drive

points_of_interest.name: Chrysler Building
points_of_interest.description: One of the most recognizable and favored structures of New York, the Chrysler was the world's tallest building when completed in 1930, but lost that title to the nearby Empire State Building less than a year later. But what it lost in fame it makes up for in beauty, with its gorgeous, instantly recognizable Art Deco crown.

points_of_interest.name: Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum
points_of_interest.description: Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, located in the Andrew Carnegie Mansion on Manhattan's Upper East Side, is the only museum in the United States dedicated to historical and contemporary design. Part of the Smithsonian Institution, it offers a unique perspective on design aesthetics and creativity across U.S. history. Situated along Museum Mile, the museum provides a fascinating exploration of design through its collections and exhibitions. Unlike most Smithsonian museums, Cooper Hewitt charges an admission fee, making it a worthwhile stop for design enthusiasts visiting New York City.

points_of_interest.name: Flatiron Building
points_of_interest.description: An iconic building, considered the oldest remaining skyscraper in Manhattan, the Flatiron was completed in 1902. 285 ft (87 m) tall.

points_of_interest.name: Rubin Museum of Art
points_of_interest.description: Art of the Himalayas.
points_of_interest.hours: M Th 11AM–5PM, Tu closed, W 11AM–7PM, F 11AM–10PM, Sa Su 11AM–6PM

points_of_interest.name: One Times Square
points_of_interest.description: Originally the second-tallest building in the world when it opened in 1905, One Times Square was constructed to be the headquarters for ''The New York Times'', a function it would serve for less than ten years. The annual Times Square ball drop is performed from the roof of this building. And you can't miss the famous Dow Jones news and sports zipper (the first news ticker in the world) attached to its lower facade.

points_of_interest.name: Manhattan Municipal Building
points_of_interest.description: David N. Dinkins Manhattan Municipal Building With New York City growing and not enough space in the City Hall building, this 40-story structure was built to meet the space demands of the city government. Completed in 1915, it is a massive and very grand building with the gilded statue of a woman standing atop the building's spire.

points_of_interest.name: Children's Museum of the Arts
points_of_interest.description: Art and interactive exhibits geared towards children.

points_of_interest.name: Central Savings Bank building
points_of_interest.description: This building, which is occupied by Apple Bank for Savings, is a notable Italianate palazzo whose stone facades and metal-barred windows are meant to ooze a sense of security.

points_of_interest.name: Grove Court
points_of_interest.description: Grove Court is a charming, historic enclave nestled in the heart of the city, known for its stunning pre-Civil War homes. This picturesque alley offers a glimpse into the past with its beautifully preserved architecture. While it has made headlines in recent real estate news, its true allure lies in its timeless charm. The properties here boast unique details like exposed beams, fireplaces, and rooftop gardens, making them a standout for history and design enthusiasts. A visit to Grove Court provides an inviting backdrop to explore its rich history and architectural beauty.

points_of_interest.name: El Museo del Barrio
points_of_interest.description: El Museo del Barrio, located at 1230 Fifth Avenue in Upper Manhattan, is a premier cultural destination showcasing Latin American and Caribbean art. Situated near the northern end of Museum Mile, it was founded in 1969 and is the oldest museum in the U.S. dedicated to Latino art. The museum highlights works from Puerto Rico and the Puerto Rican community in New York City, offering a rich exploration of their artistic heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Bethesda Terrace and Fountain
points_of_interest.description: Bethesda Terrace and Fountain are iconic architectural features in Central Park, offering stunning views of the Lake's southern shore. The centerpiece is the Angel of the Waters statue, surrounded by a beautiful fountain. The two-level terrace is connected by grand staircases and offers a seamless path to the Central Park Mall and Naumburg Bandshell. Crafted from New Brunswick sandstone with granite accents, the terrace features intricate stonework and herringbone-patterned brick paving. This historic landmark is a must-visit for its architectural beauty and picturesque surroundings, making it a perfect spot to relax and take in the park's natural charm.

points_of_interest.name: P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center
points_of_interest.description: MoMA PS1 Supported by the Museum of Modern Art, this innovative (and cheap) contemporary art museum is in a former public school building. The conversion left most of the original features of the school - the large ex-classrooms are perfect for installations - and the bathrooms are a blast from the past. P.S.1 is a few blocks south on Jackson Avenue from the Citibank tower; the entrance is a concrete slab (how fitting) which occludes view of the school itself. P.S.1 also has a nice cafe and outdoor seats.

points_of_interest.name: Queens Museum
points_of_interest.description: A visual arts center featuring the ''Panorama of the City of New York'', a large architectural scale model of New York City. Originally built for the 1964 World’s Fair, the {{sqft|9335}} display depicts all 895,000 of the city's buildings (excluding Far Rockaway due to space limitations). It was last fully updated in 1992 and select newer buildings are added on an ongoing basis. The Twin Towers of the original World Trade Center remain in place. In addition to the ''Panorama'', the museum has several other exhibits, including items related to the 1939 and 1964 World's Fairs, Tiffany glass, and various 20th-century artworks.
points_of_interest.hours: W–F noon–5PM, Sa Su 11AM–5PM, closed M Tu

points_of_interest.name: Statue of Liberty view
points_of_interest.description: Red Hook is the only place in New York where you can get a frontal view of the Statue of Liberty from land.
points_of_interest.address: 202 Coffey Street, Brooklyn, New York 11231, United States

points_of_interest.name: New York Aquarium
points_of_interest.description: Although it looks small, the New York Aquarium is a nice place for children and adults to spend an hour or two. Highlights include a shark tank, a sea lion show, sea cliffs (with penguins, sea otters, and harbor seals), and a conservation hall (rays and eels).
points_of_interest.hours: Opens 10AM daily, closing varies by season

points_of_interest.name: Park Slope Historic District
points_of_interest.description: One of Brooklyn's most prized brownstone neighborhoods. It is predominantly residential, characterized by late 19th- and early 20th-century rowhouses with architectural significance. Street signs in the Historic District are brown rather than green.
points_of_interest.address: 315 8th Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11215, United States

points_of_interest.name: Williamsburg Art & Historical Center
points_of_interest.description: The Williamsburg Art & Historical Center, housed in the historic Kings County Savings Bank building, is a stunning example of French Second Empire architecture. Built in 1860, this landmark structure served as a bank for over a century before becoming a cultural hub in 1996. Designated as a New York City landmark in 1966 and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1980, the building showcases a rich history and architectural significance. Today, it offers a unique space for art and history, making it a fascinating destination for visitors exploring Brooklyn’s vibrant Williamsburg neighborhood.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn College
points_of_interest.description: Brooklyn College is one of the most beautiful college campuses in the New York area. It is lovingly landscaped and includes classic buildings from the 1930s and 40s. In particular, the iconic library building with its clock tower and chimes can be seen or heard from several blocks away. The best time to visit is in April, when most of the trees are in bloom. Unfortunately, the police officers who as of September 2023 guard the entrances bar entrance to anyone without a Brooklyn College ID who shows up without permission.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Historical Society
points_of_interest.description: The Center for Brooklyn History is a cultural gem in Brooklyn Heights, offering insights into the borough's rich 400-year history. Housed in a stunning Romanesque Revival building, it's a must-visit for history enthusiasts. The center features rotating exhibits and a vast collection of historical materials. It also plays a significant role in the community by providing educational programs for students and teachers, making it a hub for learning and exploration.

points_of_interest.name: Green-Wood Cemetery
points_of_interest.description: Green-Wood Cemetery is a 478-acre historic cemetery in Brooklyn, offering a peaceful escape from the city. Established in 1838, it was a rural cemetery that became Brooklyn's first public park by default, inspiring the design of Central Park. This National Historic Landmark features stunning architecture and is the final resting place of many notable figures. Visitors can explore its beautiful grounds, historic structures, and enjoy the serene atmosphere. A must-visit for history buffs and nature lovers alike.

points_of_interest.name: Freshkills Park
points_of_interest.description: Only in the first stages of development, this mega-park is set to be 2,200 acres—three times the size of Central Park. It will cover the wild areas of the Fresh Kills, and the former Fresh Kills Dump. The first section of the park, '''Schmul Park''', in Travis, features a large and colorful playground for kids, along with basketball courts, handball courts, and an open grass field.

points_of_interest.name: East River Park
points_of_interest.description: This park is a little rough and ready, but there are nice views from the Promenade, and if you are in the neighborhood on July 4, this is where you want to go to see the fireworks if you can't get invited to someone's roof and are too late to get onto the elevated FDR Drive. Just make sure your view isn't blocked by a tree.
points_of_interest.address: Montgomery St. to E. 12 St., FDR Drive

points_of_interest.name: Museum at Eldridge Street
points_of_interest.description: The museum, a non-sectarian cultural organization based in the restored 1887 National Historic Landmark Eldridge Street Synagogue, presents the culture, history and traditions of the great wave of Jewish immigrants to the Lower East Side drawing parallels with the diverse cultural communities that have settled in America. The museum offers guided tours of the synagogue, new exhibits and programs -- including concerts, neighborhood walking tours and film screenings.

points_of_interest.name: Tribeca Film Center
points_of_interest.description: The Tribeca Festival is a premier annual event in New York City, celebrating film, culture, and creativity. Founded in 2002 by Robert De Niro, Jane Rosenthal, and Craig Hatkoff, the festival was established to revitalize Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 attacks. Each spring, it offers a diverse lineup of films, talks, music, and immersive experiences, attracting thousands of attendees. The festival also honors innovative storytelling through juried competitions, making it a must-visit for film enthusiasts and culture lovers alike.

points_of_interest.name: Grace Church
points_of_interest.description: A lovely neo-Gothic Episcopal church, seemingly inspired by the Sainte-Chapelle in Paris. Free guided tours every Sunday at 1PM, or just walk past and look. Of course, there are also masses, and a concert series is given, too.

points_of_interest.name: Citigroup Center
points_of_interest.description: The Citigroup Center, a striking skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan, is known for its unique design and rich history. Completed in 1977, the 915-foot-tall tower features a sloped roof and four giant stilts at its base, creating a distinctive silhouette. The building was originally designed for Citibank and has since become a landmark in the city. Its public spaces, including a sunken plaza and shopping concourse, offer convenient access to the Lexington Avenue/51st Street subway station. The tower also overlooks St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church, a granite structure integrated into its base. A notable feature of its design, the building was strengthened shortly after completion due to a structural vulnerability. Today, it stands as a blend of modern architecture and urban convenience.

points_of_interest.name: Frick Collection
points_of_interest.description:
The Frick Collection is a renowned art museum located in a stunning Beaux-Arts mansion on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Established in 1935, it showcases a diverse collection of 14th- to 19th-century European paintings and decorative arts, including works by artists such as Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Goya. The museum is housed in the former residence of industrialist Henry Clay Frick, offering a unique blend of art and historic architecture.

In addition to its permanent collection, the Frick hosts temporary exhibitions and cultural events, making it a must-visit for art lovers. Its intimate setting and world-class works create an unforgettable experience.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Sa 10AM-6PM (until 9PM first Friday of the month, except January), Su 11AM-5PM

points_of_interest.name: Clock Tower Building
points_of_interest.description: formerly Metropolitan Life Home Office building A lovely building with a tall clock tower just across Madison Ave from Madison Square Park. The first 11 stories were completed in 1893, with the clock tower being added in 1909.

points_of_interest.name: Whitney Museum of American Art
points_of_interest.description: Founded in 1931 and now in a stunning building in the Meatpacking District, the Whitney Museum is known for displaying contemporary American art even more up-to-date than the Museum of Modern Art. It is most famous for its long-standing tradition of hosting a biennial art show that displays many lesser-known artists new to the American art scene.

points_of_interest.name: Rockefeller Center
points_of_interest.description: The Christmas Tree, the Skating Rink, NBC Studios, the shops and hubbub - you can't miss it. The Christmas Tree and the Skating Rink are naturally not year round, but in the summer, the complex is a hub for touristy operations. Within the striking Art Deco buildings of the complex are several dining establishments overlooking the area and many stores.
points_of_interest.address: 32 West 49th Street, New York, New York 10020, United States

points_of_interest.name: Wall Street
points_of_interest.description: The historic heart of the Financial District and the home of the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street is a metonym for American big business, stock trading and the entire financial industry, although most New York financial firms are no longer headquartered on the street itself, but housed nearby in new offices, and some have moved to Jersey City. A narrow street running downhill from Broadway to the East River, Wall Street was named for the wall that was built here in 1652 to keep Manhattan's indigenous peoples out of the growing Dutch settlement. The wall was demolished by the British in 1699. By the late 18th century, traders and speculators would gather under a buttonwood tree at the foot of Wall Street to trade informally - this was the origin of the New York Stock Exchange that was established in 1817.
points_of_interest.address: 52 William Street, New York, New York 10005, United States

points_of_interest.name: New York City Fire Museum
points_of_interest.description: Closed until further notice. Housed in a restored 1904 firehouse, the NYC Fire Museum covers the history of fire fighting in the United States from the 18th century to the present. Displays include antique aparatus, uniforms and equipment, as well as an apartment fire simulator.

points_of_interest.name: Dakota Building
points_of_interest.description: This massive apartment building has been (and is!) home to many celebrities. Probably best known was the former Beatle John Lennon, who was gunned down outside the building on December 8, 1980, by a crazed fan. Lennon had been living at the Dakota with his second wife, Yoko Ono, who still resides in the building. A memorial to the former Beatle exists nearby in Central Park. The building has become a popular place of pilgrimage for many who admire Lennon.

points_of_interest.name: Stonewall National Monument
points_of_interest.description: Stonewall National Monument, located in New York City's West Village, is a significant cultural landmark. It encompasses the Stonewall Inn, Christopher Park, and surrounding streets, where the 1969 Stonewall riots ignited the modern LGBTQ+ rights movement. Designated by President Barack Obama in 2016, it stands as the first U.S. national monument honoring LGBTQ+ history and rights. This site is a poignant symbol of resilience and a cornerstone of the fight for equality, offering a meaningful experience for those interested in history and civil rights.

points_of_interest.name: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
points_of_interest.description: Built in 1802 (and physically shifted from its original location), this was the home of Alexander Hamilton, one of the founding fathers and the first Secretary of Treasury.

points_of_interest.name: Central Park Zoo
points_of_interest.description: Small and gem-like, New York's "oldest, newest zoo" opened in its current guise in 1988, although animals in various zoo incarnations have resided here since the 1860s. This zoo is fairly small and doesn't have as many large animals as you might expect, but this zoo does include sea lions, penguins, polar bears, monkeys, red pandas, and exotic birds in pleasant exhibits. Next door is a children's zoo, covered in the cost of admission, which has a barnyard animals you can pet, a duck pond, and lots of play areas for kids.
points_of_interest.hours: Nov-Mar: Daily 10AM-4:30PM, Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa-Su, holidays 10AM-5:30PM

points_of_interest.name: SculptureCenter
points_of_interest.description: SculptureCenter is a contemporary art museum located in Long Island City, Queens, New York City. Established in 1928 as The Clay Club, it has evolved into a leading institution dedicated to showcasing innovative sculpture and other media. The museum offers a dynamic space for artists and visitors to engage with cutting-edge works, making it a must-visit for art enthusiasts in NYC.

points_of_interest.name: Queens Theatre
points_of_interest.description: Queens Theatre, originally known as the Boulevard Theatre, is a historic venue in Jackson Heights, Queens. Opened in 1926, it once hosted Broadway-bound productions and vaudeville acts. Over the years, it transitioned into a movie house and later a triplex theater. After closing in the 1980s, the building was revitalized with community support and transformed into a vibrant cultural space. Today, it serves as a dinner theater and event venue, offering plays, concerts, and international films. The restored entrance and lobby now house a restaurant and bar, while the auditoriums continue to entertain audiences, celebrating the area's diverse heritage.
points_of_interest.address: 14 United Nations Avenue South, Corona, New York 11368, United States

points_of_interest.name: Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge
points_of_interest.description: The Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge is a historic vessel turned floating museum, offering a unique glimpse into maritime history and culture. Located on a restored 1914 barge, the museum features exhibits that highlight the region's rich maritime heritage and industrial past. Visitors can explore the ship's deck and interior while learning about its fascinating history. The museum also occasionally offers themed cruises and educational programs, making it a great destination for both history enthusiasts and families looking for an engaging experience. Step aboard to discover the stories of the waterways and their significance to the region.

points_of_interest.name: Jackie Robinson and Pee Wee Reese Monument
points_of_interest.description: Statue of Jackie Robinson, first African American to play in Major League Baseball in the modern era when he played for the Brooklyn Dodgers. Pee Wee Reese was a strong supporter of his. These two Hall of Fame players were on the Dodgers together from 1947 to 1956.

points_of_interest.name: Prospect Park South
points_of_interest.description: The lesser-known historic district on the other side of the Park. It was developed at the turn of the 20th century by Dean Alvord as one of the first suburbs.
points_of_interest.address: 125 Argyle Road, Brooklyn, New York 11218, United States

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Brewery
points_of_interest.description: The brewery has grown to buildings on both sides of 11th, and they offer tours on both weekends and weekdays. The tour is a lot of fun and educational, and you get tokens to sample some of the delicious brew. They don't have a kitchen, but some great local pizza places deliver to the brewery -- it may seem odd but it's encouraged. There are some no reservation tours on Saturday and Sunday, with reservations required for smaller, more private tours Monday through Thursday. On Friday there are no tours, but it's a popular hangout. More information on tours can be found at their website.

points_of_interest.name: Federal Building and Post Office
points_of_interest.description: This neo-Romanesque fairy castle was built in 1891, and a northern addition in very similar style was built in 1933. The older building is a busy post office serving Downtown Brooklyn and the northern addition houses the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of New York.

points_of_interest.name: Harbor Defense Museum
points_of_interest.description: A collection of military artifacts relating to the defense of America's harbors located inside still-working Fort Hamilton. Since the museum is located within an active US Army post, '''foreign visitors are not permitted'''. All visitors '''must have an ID'''.

points_of_interest.name: Fort Wadsworth
points_of_interest.description: Dating back to 1663, this fort was used during both the American Revolution and the War of 1812. It remained active until 1995. It is now semi-active, with its main use being local headquarters for the United States Coast Guard. Tours are available.
points_of_interest.address: 150 South Weed Road, New York 10305, United States

points_of_interest.name: Sara Delano Roosevelt Park
points_of_interest.description: Shared with Chinatown. The part of the park between Delancey and Houston Sts. has a soccer field and some basketball courts, so in addition to some relaxing greenery, you may see people playing sports or do so yourself in good weather. Watch out for the rats after dark, though they are unlikely to be of any danger to you, while they get their wind sprints in and look for food.

points_of_interest.name: Italian American Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Italian American Museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the history and culture of Italian Americans. Located in the heart of the city, this museum celebrates the rich heritage and contributions of Italian Americans, from their migration journeys to their lasting impact on society. Explore exhibits that highlight the waves of immigration, the challenges faced by early settlers, and the vibrant cultural traditions that have shaped American society. Discover how Italian Americans have influenced art, cuisine, and more, making this a must-visit destination for anyone interested in cultural history and the Italian American experience.
points_of_interest.hours: Opening in its new home in Oct 2024; previously at 155 Mulberry

points_of_interest.name: Washington Market Park
points_of_interest.description: Great place for kids to play, to enjoy a nice picnic, or just sit back and relax. There is plenty of playing equipment for children, as well as organized games and arts and crafts. Hosting birthday parties is very popular in this park for those who are interested in renting out the gazebo. In the summer, bands will often play music in the gazebo for the older generations. The park is small and safe.
points_of_interest.address: bounded by Greenwich, Chambers and West Streets

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space
points_of_interest.description: MoRUS A very small museum, that illustrates the history of activism in the neighborhood. Tours of legendary historic neighborhood sites and of community gardens are proposed every Saturday and Sunday at 3PM.

points_of_interest.name: Daily News Building
points_of_interest.description: This Art Deco design classic, completed in 1930 to a design by Raymond Hood, was made famous by the ''Superman'' films; to be admired are the extreme verticality of the design, the understated setbacks and functional design. The newspaper no longer holds offices here, but the foyer is well worth a visit if passing, if only to see the newspaper's giant globe sculpture and wall weather stations.

points_of_interest.name: Jewish Museum
points_of_interest.description: Containing artifacts spanning 4,000 years of art and Jewish culture, with a collection of 26,000 objects – paintings, sculpture, works on paper, photographs, archaeological artifacts, ceremonial objects and broadcast media. The museum also hosts the annual SummerNights concert series and the annual [http://nyjff.org New York Jewish Film Festival].

points_of_interest.name: 200 Fifth Avenue
points_of_interest.description: This building, formerly part of the Toy Center, used to be connected to the formerly matching one that was between 24th and 25th Streets by a pedestrian bridge, by that building was torn down and substituted for with a new building in the 2010s. However, the remaining landmark building between 23rd and 24th Streets and 5th Avenue was built in 1909 and as of 2021 is occupied most prominently by Eataly, a large purveyor of foodstuffs that concentrates particularly on Italian foods that are imported or made on site.

points_of_interest.name: Gagosian Gallery
points_of_interest.description: One of sixteen gallery spaces/shops all around the world owned by Larry Gagosian. Thoughtful and important exhibitions of both modern and contemporary art.

points_of_interest.name: Radio City Music Hall
points_of_interest.description: Radio City Music Hall, nestled in Midtown Manhattan within Rockefeller Center, is a iconic entertainment venue known as "The Showplace of the Nation." Home to the renowned Rockettes, it showcases stunning Art Deco design by Edward Durell Stone and Donald Deskey. Once destined for an opera house, it opened in 1932 and became a landmark in 1978 after a restoration. Today, it hosts a variety of events, from concerts and stage shows to televised ceremonies. Its rich history and vibrant events make it a must-visit destination for any traveler seeking a memorable experience in New York City.

points_of_interest.name: New York Stock Exchange
points_of_interest.description: NYSE A historic site, not least because of the Black Thursday crash of the Exchange on 24 October 1929 and the subsequent sell-off panic which started on Black Tuesday, 29 October, precipitating the worldwide Great Depression of the early 1930s. The present Exchange building opened in 1903, recognized from the first as an example of masterful architecture, with the six massive Corinthian columns across its Broad Street facade imparting a feeling of substance and stability and, to many, seeming the very embodiment of America’s growth and prosperity. The building has been closed to the public since 9/11.

points_of_interest.name: Sonnabend Gallery
points_of_interest.description: Specializes in contemporary art including paintings, sculptures, and photography by American and European artists. Past artists have included: Lawrence Beck, Robert Feintuch, Jeff Koons, Grazia Toderi, Philip Haas, Barry Le Va, Anne and Patrick Poirier, and more.

points_of_interest.name: Deutsche Bank Center (formerly the Time Warner Center)
points_of_interest.description: Has the Mandarin Oriental Hotel for dining, drinks, and Chihuly chandeliers. It also has a small, ultra-high-end mall with luxury shops and Botero sculptures. In the basement is a large Whole Foods Market, and there is seating for eating their prepared food and salad bar items (cheaper than eating in a restaurant). Or better yet, on nicer days, pick up a prepared meal to go and venture across the street to Columbus Circle or Sheep's Meadow in Central Park for a nice outdoor meal.

points_of_interest.name: Hispanic Society of America
points_of_interest.description: The Hispanic Society of America is a museum and library dedicated to the arts and cultures of Spain, Portugal, and their former colonies. Founded in 1904 by philanthropist Archer M. Huntington, it is housed in a stunning 1908 Beaux Arts building in Manhattan's Washington Heights. The complex, a National Historic Landmark since 2012, features sculptures by Anna Hyatt Huntington and Berthold Nebel. In 2021, the museum expanded into an adjacent building, offering even more space to explore the rich cultural heritage of the Hispanic world. A must-visit for art and history enthusiasts.
points_of_interest.hours: The East Building Gallery is open Th-Su, noon-6PM for special exhibitions on a rotating basis and the Main Building is closed for renovations, as of January, 2022

points_of_interest.name: Dairy
points_of_interest.description: Built in the 1870s as a dairy farm, with a structure designed to resemble a country church. Today it is a visitor center and gift shop for the park, housed in a beautiful structure. Next door is the '''Chess & Checkers House''', another visitor center and the volunteer headquarters, with a number of chess and checkers tables under a shady pergola.

points_of_interest.name: Socrates Sculpture Park
points_of_interest.description: Socrates Sculpture Park, located in Astoria, Queens, is a unique outdoor museum and public park that showcases large-scale sculptures and multimedia installations. Situated near the Noguchi Museum, the park serves as a creative space for artists to produce and display their work. It also offers a variety of programs, including arts education and artist residencies, making it a vibrant cultural destination for visitors and locals alike.

points_of_interest.name: Queens Zoo
points_of_interest.description: An 11-acre zoo featuring over 40 wildlife species including bison, mountain lions, and bears.
points_of_interest.hours: Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa Su 10AM-5:30PM; Nov-Mar: 10AM-4:30PM daily

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Museum
points_of_interest.description: Housed in a 560,000-square-foot, Beaux-Arts building, the Brooklyn is the 2nd largest art museum in New York City and one of the largest in the USA. Its world-renowned permanent collections include more than one million objects, from ancient Egyptian masterpieces to contemporary art, and represent a wide range of cultures. It is a 30-minute subway ride from Midtown Manhattan, and has its own subway station (renovated in 2019-20), the museum is part of a complex of 19th-century parks and gardens that also includes Prospect Park, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and the Prospect Park Zoo. On the first Saturday of each month, the museum is open until 11PM with free admission and special events.

points_of_interest.name: The Bushwick Collective
points_of_interest.description: The Bushwick Collective is a vibrant outdoor art gallery in Bushwick, New York, showcasing works by local and international street artists. Founded in 2012, the collective transformed empty walls into a dynamic display of urban art. Notable contributors include Buff Monster, Phlegm, and Olek. The collective also hosts an annual block party, featuring live music and performances, such as past appearances by Ice-T and Ghostface Killah. This cultural hub has even expanded its reach with events in cities like Melbourne, Australia, making it a must-visit destination for art lovers and fans of street culture.
points_of_interest.address: 22 Saint Nicholas Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11237, United States

points_of_interest.name: Manhattan Bridge
points_of_interest.description: The Manhattan Bridge, just a bit to the east of the Brooklyn Bridge, with signposted access from Jay St. slightly over 4 blocks north (toward the river) of Tillary St., can also be crossed by pedestrians and cyclists, but if you do so, you will be rattled by passing subway trains that traverse the bridge, your view will be partly obstructed by mesh, and you won't be in a position to see much to the north of the bridge (so no great views of the Midtown skyline like you get from the Brooklyn Bridge walkway). It's still worth doing if you have enough time, though, partly because of the views of the Brooklyn Bridge that you can see from the Manhattan Bridge. As of November 2021, construction is taking place on the bridge; it narrows the path pedestrians and cyclists share in places, but access is otherwise unimpeded.
points_of_interest.address: Manhattan Bridge, New York, New York 10007, United States

points_of_interest.name: Living Torah Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Living Torah Museum is a group of Orthodox Jewish museums that opened in 2002 and drew approximately 600,000 visitors in the first twelve years. Originally a separate museum that opened in 2008, an exhibit on animals of the Bible and Talmud, known as the Torah Animal World merged with the main museum in 2014. It is also home to examples of Biblical and Talmudic archaeological artifacts and antique Judaica and Jewish books. From 2005-2016, the museum was home to the world's oldest known example of a stone tablet inscribed with the Ten Commandments until it was sold at auction for $850,000 in November 2016.

points_of_interest.name: Miller Field
points_of_interest.description: Miller Field was an airfield run by the U.S. Army from 1919 to 1969. Completed in 1921, it was the only Air Coast Defense Station on the east coast. Coast Artillery soldiers manned defenses during World War II. During the Cold War, Army aircraft including helicopters called Miller Field home. Miller Field was deactivated by the U.S. Army in 1969. It was the last grass runway in New York City.
points_of_interest.address: 38 Miller Field, Staten Island, New York 10306, United States

points_of_interest.name: Kehila Kedosha Janina Museum
points_of_interest.description: Museum inside the only Romaniote (Greek-speaking) synagogue in the Western Hemisphere, telling the story of Greek Jews. Designated a NYC Landmark in 2004.

points_of_interest.name: Ottendorfer Library
points_of_interest.description: The oldest continuously existing free lending library in New York, it was designed in 1884 as a "Freie Bibliothek u. Lesehalle" (free library and reading hall) when this neighborhood was part of Kleindeutschland (Little Germany) and now serves as a branch of the New York Public Library. Another part of this lovely red brick building, constructed as a "Deutsches Dispensary," features reliefs of heroes of German culture such as Goethe but stopped functioning as a clinic several years ago.
points_of_interest.hours: M W 10AM-6PM, Tu Th 10AM-8PM, F Sa 10AM-5PM

points_of_interest.name: Empire State Building
points_of_interest.description: A legend from the moment it was finished in 1931, the Empire State Building was easily the tallest building not just in New York, but the entire world for many years before being overtaken by another New York landmark - the twin towers of the World Trade Center. With the destruction of those two buildings, the Empire State Building was once again the tallest building in the city, but that lasted less than eleven years. But even though it's no longer the tallest, it remains iconic and one of the city's biggest tourist attractions. Expect ''long'' lines, and a lot of them - you'll have to wait in line to pass through a security checkpoint, wait in line to get tickets, wait in line for the elevators, and then make your way through the crowd on the outdoor observation deck on the 86th floor. One way to deal with the lines is to buy an express line ticket, which will bring you to the front of any line, but it will more than double the cost of your ticket. Another option is to visit very early in the day or late in the evening, when the lines will be considerably shorter. Despite the long lines and inevitable tourist kitsch, the views are excellent and the experience of being outdoors on top of New York City is a great one. Hawkers outside the building may try to tell you there is a very long line inside and that they can get you tickets to cut the line for some exorbitant price; before believing them, go inside and check the actual wait time which is clearly written on the electronic boards.

points_of_interest.name: Mount Vernon Hotel Museum
points_of_interest.description: Hidden in the small pocket of the very southeast Upper East Side, this rustic site dates back to 1799 as a carriage house, and was converted into a hotel in 1826. Sitting on land historically owned by Abigail Adams Smith, daughter of John Adams, it is home to beautiful historic gardens, halls, and taverns.

points_of_interest.name: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace
points_of_interest.description: A designated National Historic Site, Roosevelt lived at this site from his birth in 1858 until the age of 14 years. The building is not the original - that was demolished in 1916 - but a reconstruction erected by admirers three years later in 1919 after Roosevelt's death, and subsequently furnished with many of the original fittings and memorabilia of the 26th U.S. President by Roosevelt's wife and sisters.

points_of_interest.name: Matthew Marks Gallery
points_of_interest.description: Modern and contemporary art shown through a variety of mediums including: sculpture, photography, painting, drawing, film, prints, drawings, and installation art.

points_of_interest.name: Top of the Rock Observation Deck
points_of_interest.description: On the 70th floor of the GE Building (better known by some as "30 Rock") is this narrow observation deck, built to resemble the deck of a cruise ship. The deck affords uninterrupted views over Central Park to the north and across Midtown to the south.

points_of_interest.name: Fearless Girl
points_of_interest.description: This statue of a defiant young girl was originally unveiled facing the ''Charging Bull'' sculpture in 2017, as a symbol of women's roles in corporate leadership and the importance of gender diversity. It was also a publicity stunt for an index fund focused on gender-diverse leadership – a fact not lost on the ''Bull'''s sculptor, who complained that the ''Girl'' was an advertising trick that detracted from his sculpture. Nonetheless, the statue's popularity has kept it on Wall Street; the ''Girl'' was moved in 2018 and now faces the New York Stock Exchange.

points_of_interest.name: New York Earth Room
points_of_interest.description: Designed by Walter De Maria for the Dia Art Foundation, the Earth Room is a whole floor filled with 250 cubic yards of dirt.

points_of_interest.name: The San Remo
points_of_interest.description: The historic building with the distinctive, iconic twin towers and a star-studded housing cooperative board. Built in 1930 in a vaguely Art Deco style to the design of Emery Roth, the San Remo actually has two separate addresses, lobbies and sets of shafts, each for a half of the building topped with a tower.

points_of_interest.name: Morris-Jumel Mansion
points_of_interest.description: Built in 1765, this is the oldest house on Manhattan Island. It served as George Washington's headquarters in 1776. Now a museum set on a 1.5-acre park, it features a decorative-arts collection representing the colonial and Revolutionary War periods. Washington's office is among the 12 restored rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Friedsman Carousel
points_of_interest.description: A vintage carousel built in 1908 and situated on this spot since the 1950s, it's the fourth carousel to inhabit this location and is beautifully painted.
points_of_interest.hours: Apr-Oct: Daily 10AM-6PM (weather permitting); Nov-Mar: hours vary, check ahead

points_of_interest.name: Steinway & Sons Pianos
points_of_interest.description: Tours suspended as of March 2024. They offer free guided tours during fall and spring to see the skilled craftsmen at work. Phone ahead, a month in advance is recommended, to reserve a place on these popular tours, and to check the days and times. Otherwise, take the online factory tour on their website.

points_of_interest.name: Unisphere
points_of_interest.description: The Unisphere is an iconic symbol of Queens, standing 140 feet tall in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. This stunning globe is surrounded by a beautiful fountain, creating a striking visual display. Originally built for the 1964 World's Fair, the Unisphere has become a beloved landmark, representing global unity and the park's rich history as the site of two World's Fairs (1939 and 1964). Its grandeur and historical significance make it a must-see attraction for visitors to the area.
points_of_interest.address: Avenue of Africa, Corona, New York 11368, United States

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Botanic Garden
points_of_interest.description: The garden is 52 acres and the layout was well planned. It is definitely worth a visit. Designed by the Olmsted Brothers in 1910 and open to the public since 1911, the garden includes an authentic Japanese garden, a Children's Garden, and the Cranford Rose Garden. The garden has the largest cherry blossom trees in one place outside of Japan. There are 42 gorgeous varieties. The Brooklyn Botanic Garden hosts various festivities throughout the year, including Hanami Sakura in May and the Chile Pepper Festival in October.

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts
points_of_interest.description: The Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts, located in the vibrant Fort Greene neighborhood of Brooklyn, is a groundbreaking cultural institution. As the first museum of its kind in New York, it celebrates the rich cultural heritage and contemporary expressions of the African diaspora. Visitors can explore dynamic exhibitions, educational programs, and community events that showcase the diversity and creativity of African diasporan art. This unique space is a must-visit for art enthusiasts and anyone interested in exploring the intersection of culture, identity, and contemporary art.

points_of_interest.name: Owl's Head Park
points_of_interest.description: The park is good for a walk, and you can follow the path toward the water which takes you to the pier and a bunch of park stuff along the water towards the Verrazano Bridge. Those are all really refreshing walks.

points_of_interest.name: Great Kills Park
points_of_interest.description: This park is home to a large woodland and a number of beaches. A small portion of the beach is closed for radiation screenings.
points_of_interest.address: 205 Buffalo Street, Staten Island, New York 10308, United States

points_of_interest.name: St. Marks Place
points_of_interest.description: The eastward extension of 8th St./Astor Place past 3rd Ave. There are many bars, restaurants, and shops (many with a street vending presence) on the block between 2nd and 3rd Aves. There's always quite a mixture of folk walking up and down the street and within the area not to mention the slew of students from Cooper Union and NYU, which has plenty of dormitories and facilities nearby. Be warned that it can be unpleasantly crowded with slow-moving tipsy people at times, but it is a good place for people-watching.
points_of_interest.address: 38 Saint Marks Place, New York, New York 10003, United States

points_of_interest.name: MetLife Building
points_of_interest.description: Since it was built it has been probably ''the'' most hated building in New York, mostly because it rises up over Grand Central Station, completely blocking the view up Park Avenue, but it is a good example of modern architecture.

points_of_interest.name: Neue Galerie New York
points_of_interest.description: Museum for German and Austrian Art A vast collection of early-20th century Austrian and German art and design including famous artists such as Pablo Picasso and Vincent Van Gogh alongside less-well known, equally fascinating decorative and fine artists.

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Sex
points_of_interest.description: The Museum of Sex is a unique cultural destination in Manhattan, New York City, dedicated to exploring the history, evolution, and cultural significance of human sexuality. Through engaging exhibitions, artifacts, and interactive displays, the museum offers a thought-provoking and insightful look at a topic that shapes human experience. Whether you're interested in art, history, or science, this attraction provides a fascinating and approachable way to explore a universal aspect of life.

points_of_interest.name: Chelsea Arts Tower
points_of_interest.description: A 21-story commercial condominium in the heart of the gallery district. Built in 2006, this is Manhattan's first art gallery condominium. This building features the Marlborough Chelsea gallery, Tina Kim Gallery, the Flag Art Foundation gallery, Joan Mitchell Foundation, and even the Calvin Klein Studio. This is the perfect place to spend an afternoon with all of its galleries and amazing views. The Chelsea Arts Tower is also home to The Glass Houses on floors 14 and 21. This is one of the most premier spaces for over-the-top parties and events in NYC.

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Modern Art
points_of_interest.description: MoMA One of the greatest and most popular collections of modern art, on a par with the Tate Modern in London or Paris's Centre Georges Pompidou. Exceedingly popular so be warned: queues for tickets start early and stretch long. To avoid the crowds, turn up at the door ''at least'' a half hour before opening, then take the elevator to the top floor and work your way down. The building is as much a draw as the outstanding collection; possessing arguably the best collection of modern masterpieces world-wide, MoMA houses important art works from Van Gogh, Picasso, Monet, Matisse, Salvador Dalí, Paul Cézanne, Frida Kahlo, Piet Mondrian, and works by leading American artists such as Jackson Pollock, Jasper Johns, Edward Hopper, Andy Warhol, and Chuck Close. MoMA also holds renowned art photography and design collections. In addition to being the crown jewel of modern art museums, MoMA puts on a terrific repertory program in a nicely renovated theater below the museum.
points_of_interest.hours: Sa–Th 10AM–5:30PM, F 10:30AM–8PM, open until 9PM on first Thursday of the month and every Thursday Jul–Aug

points_of_interest.name: 23 Wall Street
points_of_interest.description: Located across from the Stock Exchange is this imposing office building which was constructed in 1914 and served as the headquarters of JP Morgan. The Wall Street Bombing of September 16, 1920 damaged the building, with shrapnel blasting several holes in the limestone facade. The holes are still there for any to see.
points_of_interest.address: 26 Wall Street, New York, New York 10005, United States

points_of_interest.name: American Folk Art Museum
