points_of_interest.description: The American Folk Art Museum, located on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is a premier destination for exploring the diverse world of folk art. Showcasing a collection of over 8,000 works from the 18th century to the present, the museum highlights both traditional folk art and contemporary pieces by self-taught artists. With rotating exhibitions and engaging programs, it celebrates the creative expressions of individuals without formal artistic training. Admission is free, making it an accessible and inspiring stop for art enthusiasts and casual visitors alike.
points_of_interest.hours: Tu-Sa noon-7:30PM, Su noon-6:30PM, closed M

points_of_interest.name: Museum of the City of New York
points_of_interest.description: Rather large, interesting museum with all kinds of documentation of events in the 400-year history of this city and delightful artifacts of life in earlier periods, such as the extensive collection of 19th-century dollhouses complete with miniature furniture.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Army Plaza
points_of_interest.description: A public square at the southeast corner of the park which marks one of the primary entrances to Central Park. The square is named for the Union Army of the Civil War and sports a gilded bronze statue of Union General William Sherman and the Pulitzer Fountain, which is crowned with a bronze figure of Pomona, the Roman goddess of fruit.

points_of_interest.name: Gantry Plaza State Park
points_of_interest.description: Gantry Plaza State Park, located on the East River in Long Island City, Queens, is a 12-acre green space that blends industrial history with modern beauty. Once a bustling dockyard and manufacturing hub, the park now features remnants of its past, including iconic gantries that once transferred railcars between Queens and Manhattan. Stroll along the riverfront, enjoy stunning views of the Manhattan skyline, and explore the park's unique blend of history and natural scenery. It’s a peaceful retreat in the heart of the city, perfect for both history buffs and those seeking a relaxing escape.
points_of_interest.address: 47-40 Center Boulevard, Long Island City, New York 11109, United States

points_of_interest.name: USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center
points_of_interest.description: Home of the '''U.S. Open''' and also the largest public tennis facility in the world. It features 3 stadium courts, 9 indoor courts, and 14 outdoor courts that are available to the public year-round.
points_of_interest.address: 122-12 Roosevelt Ave, Corona, New York 11368, United States

points_of_interest.name: Prospect Park
points_of_interest.description: Established in 1867 and laid out by Olmsted and Vaux, the designers of Manhattan's Central Park.
points_of_interest.address: Center Drive, Brooklyn, New York 11215, United States

points_of_interest.name: New York Transit Museum
points_of_interest.description: A self supporting arm of the MTA, it is housed in the Subway's former Court Street Station, on a spur line from the current A and C lines. Closed to passengers in 1946, it was reopened in 1976 as the New York Transit Exhibit and was popular enough to be made permanent. The museum is made up of two underground levels: the Mezzanine, which hosts exhibits on the construction of the subway, surface transportation in New York, fare collection and rotating exhibits on various transit-related subjects; and the station platform, which houses about 20 retired subway cars dating as far back as 1903 and a working signal tower. The museum sponsors events throughout the year, including simple art projects, walking tours on the subway, and rides on the museums' fleet of retired trains. There is also an annex of the museum in Grand Central Station in Midtown Manhattan.
points_of_interest.address: corner of Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street
points_of_interest.hours: Tu–F 10AM-4PM, Sa Su noon-5PM, closed Mondays and major holidays

points_of_interest.name: Sunset Park
points_of_interest.description: This is the park after which the neighborhood is named. It offers breathtaking views of the neighborhood and the Manhattan skyline, even as far as New Jersey. There are basketball courts, an outdoor swimming pool, walking paths, and urban wildlife.
points_of_interest.address: 4200 7 Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11232, United States

points_of_interest.name: The Greenbelt
points_of_interest.description: A humongous collection of woodlands and parks (2,800 acres!), the Greenbelt is a collection of nature you wouldn't expect to see in any major city, let alone New York. The Greenbelt covers much of the Mid-Island, so it's best to know which part you want to go to beforehand. A good place to start is the '''[http://sigreenbelt.org/nature-center/ Greenbelt Nature Center]''' an educational facility in the center of the park. The park is a great place for hikers, and a map of hiking trails can be found [http://sigreenbelt.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/2012trailmapcroppedfinaljpeg.jpg here]

points_of_interest.name: Stuyvesant Street
points_of_interest.description: Stuyvesant Street is one of Manhattan's oldest and most unique thoroughfares, nestled in the East Village. This charming street runs diagonally, eastbound, from 9th Street at Third Avenue to 10th Street near Second Avenue. Its unusual orientation sets it apart from Manhattan's typical grid system, offering a glimpse into the area's historic past. Much of the street is part of the St. Mark's Historic District, adding to its architectural and cultural significance. Visitors can enjoy its distinctive character and proximity to nearby landmarks, making it a worthwhile stop for those exploring the neighborhood.
points_of_interest.address: 26 Stuyvesant Street, New York, New York 10003, United States

points_of_interest.name: Park Avenue Armory
points_of_interest.description: The Park Avenue Armory is, again, a site not to be missed. The Armory is a venue for unconventional performing and visual arts with a vast array of unique storytelling methods and programs.
points_of_interest.hours: There are no specific opening and closing hours. Instead, the Armory is open at any time of Armory programming, so check the website to see program dates.

points_of_interest.name: National Museum of Mathematics
points_of_interest.description: MoMath Don't be turned off by the name – this museum isn't trying to teach you arithmetic or algebra, but is instead about exploring the fun side of math, with interactive artistic and mechanical exhibits and puzzles. Knowledgeable staff are happy to explain the mathematical underpinnings if you're interested, but if not, you can enjoy the surprises, creativity, and beauty of the structures and insights on display.

points_of_interest.name: Visio Dell'Arte
points_of_interest.description: Visio Dell'Arte, established in Paris in 2007, has a second gallery in Chelsea. They feature fine art paintings from masters such as Rasikh Akhmetvaliev, Anatoli Bourykine, Kaloon Chhour, Cosmina, Ene, Anik Legoupil, Helene Modebadze, Oliver Valli and Petre Velicu. All artists are exclusively represented by Visio Dell'Arte.

points_of_interest.name: Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum
points_of_interest.description: The aircraft carrier ''Intrepid'' is docked here and loaded with spacecraft and aircraft, including the very cool Blackbird spy plane and the prototype Space Shuttle ''Enterprise''. On the other side of the dock is a guided-missile submarine and a Concorde, both of which you can tour also, and some tanks.
points_of_interest.hours: April–October: M–F 10AM–5PM, Sa Su 10AM–6PM; November–March: Tu–Su 10AM–5PM

points_of_interest.name: 40 Wall Street
points_of_interest.description: Trump Building A very impressive skyscraper with a green spire which was completed in 1930 and surpassed the height of the nearby Woolworth Building (see Manhattan/TriBeCa#See), making it the tallest building in the world until the Chrysler Building was completed just a month later (which in turn lost that title to the Empire State Building less than a year later). The building was leased by Donald Trump in 1995, hence its current name.

points_of_interest.name: American Museum of Natural History
points_of_interest.description: Holding a remarkably large collection, each of the 5 floors of this massive building has expansive and well-designed exhibits devoted to astronomy, biology, geology, anthropology, climatology, and paleontology. You will want to allow a full day if you hope to see the entirety of the museum. Some of the highlights are the '''Rose Center for Earth and Space''' on the northeast corner of the building, which contains a seven-story glass cube holding the Hayden Planetarium, a huge sphere suspended above the exhibit halls below and holding a "cosmic pathway" exhibit; the numerous '''habitat diorama''' halls on the first, second and third floors, with recreations of African, Asian, North American, and ocean plants and animals, including a full-size model of a Blue Whale suspended above the Ocean Life Hall; a '''Hall of Minerals and Gems''', which contains many rare and beautiful specimens, including the largest star sapphire in the world and a chunk of a massive meteorite; extensive '''anthropology halls''' on the first, second, and third floors, with exhibits devoted to people of Asia, Africa, Central America, the Pacific, and Native Americans; and the '''natural history halls''' on the fourth floor, with one of the largest collections of dinosaur skeletons in the world.
points_of_interest.address: Central Park West between 77th and 81st Streets (entire block)

points_of_interest.name: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture
points_of_interest.description: A main research branch of the New York Public Library, this is a repository of priceless documents and also has various exhibitions on themes related to black history and culture.
points_of_interest.hours: M Th–Sa 10AM–6PM; Tu W 10AM–8PM; closed Su

points_of_interest.name: The Pond
points_of_interest.description: Near Grand Army Plaza, the Pond offers a tranquil setting just within the boundaries of the park. A rustic wood structure, "Cop Cot," overlooks the pond from an outcrop near the Sixth Avenue entrance.

points_of_interest.name: Bowne House
points_of_interest.description: The John Bowne House was built by John Bowne in 1661. It is the oldest building in Queens, and it is one of the oldest buildings in New York City. John Bowne was a Quaker who advocated religious freedom, which was later written into the Bill of Rights. John Bowne's great-grandson, Robert Bowne, strongly advocated for the end of slavery in America. The house was the home of several generations of the Bowne House until 1945, when it was donated and converted into a museum.

points_of_interest.name: Long Meadow
points_of_interest.description: Lode is a charming village in East Cambridgeshire, situated on the edge of The Fens, just 8 miles northeast of Cambridge. The village is named for its location at the southern end of Bottisham Lode, an artificial water channel believed to date back to Roman times. Part of the parish, the smaller hamlet of Long Meadow lies to the east along the B1102. Lode is a relatively new civil parish, having been separated from Bottisham in 1894. Its peaceful setting and historical waterways make it a lovely spot to explore for those interested in the region's natural and cultural heritage.
points_of_interest.address: 32 West Drive, Brooklyn, New York 11215, United States

points_of_interest.name: Lemon Creek Park
points_of_interest.description: This park is home to the creek that shares its name, as well as a variety of wildlife. One of the most notable is the purple martin. The park has one of the very few colonies in the New York Metro.

points_of_interest.name: Tompkins Square Park
points_of_interest.description: Not much to see, but a nice park nonetheless and historically significant for its long reputation of political demonstrations and radical thought. The Grateful Dead played their first East Coast show here in 1967, and the first Hare Krishna gathering outside of India took place here in 1965. The park has a curfew — it closes at 1 AM.
points_of_interest.address: btwn 7th St., 10th St., Avenue A, and Avenue B

points_of_interest.name: United Nations Headquarters
points_of_interest.description: The UN HQ sits on an 18-acre site between 42nd and 48th Streets, and between First Avenue and the East River. It is noted for its gardens and outdoor sculpture. There is a charge for the tours of the General Assembly and Secretariat but you can visit the Visitor's Lobby for free (although you do have to pass through a security checkpoint). There are two levels to the lobby area which includes a gallery, a gift shop, and a bookshop. If you're just visiting the lobby, don't join any queues - just find your way around. There is little in the way of signs to tell you where you can go - this is the UN, well-meaning but not well organized. Outside the building is a display of national flags which represent the 193 sovereign states that are members of the UN. Highlights include the 116-kg Japanese Peace Bell, where the bell is traditionally rung twice a year in honor of world peace.
points_of_interest.hours: M-F 9AM-4:30PM, Sa Su 10AM-4:30PM (no guided tours on Sa and Su)

points_of_interest.name: Society of Illustrators
points_of_interest.description: The Society of Illustrators is one of the many off the beaten path museums in New York City, and while it may not have as many visitors, it certainly isn't a place to miss. Certainly don't miss the art of illustration featured here, with countless historical galleries since the museum's opening in 1901. It's even the origin of the famous "I Want You For U.S. Army" poster of World War I and II.

points_of_interest.name: Union Square
points_of_interest.description: An important and historic intersection in New York City, situated where Broadway and the Bowery came together in the early 19th century. Union Square Park (3.5 acres) is known for its impressive equestrian statue of George Washington, erected to Henry Kirke Brown's design in 1856. In April 1861, soon after the fall of Fort Sumter, Union Square was the site of a patriotic rally that is thought to have been the largest public gathering in North America up to that time. A newer addition, added in 1986, is a statue of Mahatma Gandhi in the southwest corner of the park. Union Square is also known for its Greenmarket and for its history as a focus for political demonstrations, including protests at the 2004 Republican National Convention. Following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, Union Square became a primary public gathering point for mourners and those seeking information about missing loved ones. People created spontaneous memorials in Union Square, and the square was the setting for vigils held to honor the victims of the attacks.
points_of_interest.address: 69 East 17th Street, New York, New York 10003, United States

points_of_interest.name: Vessel
points_of_interest.description: Re-opened in October 2024 with steel-mesh safety nets and an unusual rule: No solo visitors. Plan to bring a friend when you visit this 16-story honeycomb-like structure at the core of the new Hudson Yards development project on Manhattan's West Side. Its 154 flights of stairs and 80 landings offer great views of the surrounding area, the Hudson River, and the structure's intricate framework. Buy admission tickets online in advance. Elevator service is available to three floors, usually with a long wait. No baby strollers, bicycles, skateboards, food, pets, or emotional support animals.

points_of_interest.name: Madame Tussauds New York
points_of_interest.description: Madame Tussauds New York, located in the heart of Times Square, offers a unique and interactive experience for visitors. This iconic wax museum, part of the global Madame Tussauds brand, features lifelike sculptures of famous figures from the worlds of entertainment, history, and pop culture. A must-visit for families and fans of celebrity culture, the attraction provides an engaging and fun way to get up close to your favorite icons. With its vibrant location in Midtown Manhattan, Madame Tussauds New York is a standout destination for anyone exploring the city.
points_of_interest.hours: Sept–May: daily 9AM–10PM; June–August: Su–Th 9AM–10PM, F Sa 9 AM–midnight

points_of_interest.name: Federal Hall
points_of_interest.description: On this site on April 30, 1789, George Washington stood on a balcony overlooking Wall Street and was inaugurated as the first president of the United States. The old building on the site had been used as New York's city hall and had hosted some of the first congregations of the colonies in the lead-up to the American Revolution, such as the Stamp Act Congress. After the revolution the building, now Federal Hall, briefly housed Congress, the Supreme Court, and Executive Branch offices before the national capital moved to Philadelphia. The current building dates to 1842 and was used first as a Customs House, then later the US Sub-Treasury (millions of dollars of gold and silver were kept in the basement vaults). Today the building is maintained by the National Park Service as a museum dedicated to the history of the site. Guided tours of the building are available, or you can just walk in and look up at the rotunda and view some of the artifacts, such as the bible Washington used in his inauguration ceremony.

points_of_interest.name: New York Historical Society
points_of_interest.description: Americana including Audubon’s watercolors of birds.

points_of_interest.name: Studio Museum Harlem
points_of_interest.description: The Studio Museum in Harlem, located on West 125th Street, is a premier destination celebrating artists of African descent. Since its founding in 1968, the museum has been a cornerstone for African, African American, and diasporic art. It offers dynamic exhibitions, an esteemed Artist-in-Residence program, and engaging educational initiatives. Currently undergoing expansion, a new building is set to open in 2025, promising enhanced cultural experiences. This vibrant institution continues to inspire and educate, making it a must-visit for art enthusiasts in New York City.

points_of_interest.name: Sheep Meadow
points_of_interest.description: A spacious green lawn that was originally home to a herd of sheep, which grazed in the meadow and tended to in their nearby pen - a Victorian style building which today is the '''Tavern on the Green''' restaurant (see Eat below).

points_of_interest.name: Flushing Town Hall
points_of_interest.description: Flushing Town Hall is a historic town hall built in 1862. At different times in its history, it was used as a government office, a social meeting place, a courthouse, a bank, and a jail. Today, Flushing Town Hall has a 308-seat concert hall/theater, a gallery, and a garden.
points_of_interest.hours: M-F noon-5PM and for scheduled events

points_of_interest.name: Vale of Cashmere
points_of_interest.description: Nestled within Brooklyn's Prospect Park, the Vale of Cashmere is a serene and picturesque destination that offers a peaceful retreat from the city. This natural gem features meandering walking trails, lush greenery, and a tranquil atmosphere, making it a perfect spot to unwind. Visitors can explore the area's scenic beauty, enjoy a leisurely stroll, or simply sit and take in the surroundings. The Vale of Cashmere is a must-visit for anyone looking to connect with nature while still being close to the urban bustle of New York City.
points_of_interest.address: 31 East Drive, Brooklyn, New York 11225, United States

points_of_interest.name: Mount Loretto Unique Area
points_of_interest.description: Nature preserve on the South Shore with hiking trails and shoreline access. Fishing is permitted along the beach or the freshwater pond inside the area. Most of the land is minimally developed, and is an excellent place to observe wildlife. An abandoned orphanage on-site, after which the area was named, burnt down in 2000.
points_of_interest.address: 6541 Hylan Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10309, United States

points_of_interest.name: Grand Central Terminal
points_of_interest.description: Walk in and see the main concourse, a cavernous room often filled with people and elegantly detailed, with arched windows, a lovely clock, and an astronomical ceiling.

points_of_interest.name: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum
points_of_interest.description: Probably the most famous of the Guggenheim foundations (others found in Bilbao and Venice), which hold avant-garde modern art by artists such as Kandinsky and Mondrian, the New York branch is housed in a unique and famous building designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and rendered in a rounded, organic form and completed in 1959. Be sure to take the elevator to the top floor, then follow the spiral viewing floors downwards to the street level. One of eight buildings by Wright to be listed as a world heritage site.

points_of_interest.name: Madison Square Park
points_of_interest.description: A lovely small park which offers beautiful views of the Flatiron, Clock Tower, 500 Fifth Avenue, and Empire State Buildings. There is also a popular Shake Shack kiosk that serves burgers and shakes in the southern end of the park.
points_of_interest.address: 2 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10010, United States

points_of_interest.name: Miniature World
points_of_interest.description: A very large miniature world.

points_of_interest.name: Trinity Church
points_of_interest.description: An Episcopalian (Anglican) church and parish was first established on this site in 1697 under charter by King William III. The present Neo-Gothic Revival church building (the third incarnation) dates from 1846 and remains a significant landmark within Downtown. The original burial ground at Trinity Church includes the graves and memorials of many historic figures, including Alexander Hamilton, William Bradford, Robert Fulton, and Albert Gallatin.
points_of_interest.address: 76 Trinity Place, New York, New York 10006, United States

points_of_interest.name: Nicholas Roerich Museum
points_of_interest.description: Nicholas Roerich Museum is dedicated to the life and work of the renowned Russian painter, philosopher, and cultural activist. The museum showcases Roerich's captivating paintings, which often explore spiritual and mystical themes. A true Renaissance man, Roerich was also a writer, archaeologist, and advocate for peace, earning him multiple Nobel Peace Prize nominations. His legacy includes the Roerich Pact, an international treaty for the protection of cultural heritage. Visitors can delve into his artistic journey and philosophical ideas, gaining insight into his global influence and enduring impact on art and culture. A must-visit for art lovers and history enthusiasts.

points_of_interest.name: James Bailey House
points_of_interest.description: Street built by architect Samuel Burrage Reed. A major mansion owned by circus entrepreneur Anthony Bailey - joined with showman Phineas T. Barnum in 1881 to form the Barnum & Bailey circus. Now Known to the children of Harlem as the Beauty and the Beast house.

points_of_interest.name: Strawberry Fields
points_of_interest.description: So named in 1981 in memory of John Lennon, the former Beatle, who was murdered close by outside his home in the Dakota building. Lennon's widow Yoko Ono, who still lives in the Dakota, subsequently donated $1 million to upgrade the area with hundreds of tree and flower species, including strawberries. The area serves as a Garden of Peace and includes a memorial floor mosaic (donated by the Italian city of Naples) that says simply "Imagine", referring to the title of one of Lennon's evocative songs.

points_of_interest.name: Kingsland Homestead
points_of_interest.description: Kingsland Homestead is a historic home, built by Charles Doughty around 1774. It is now a museum with exhibits about the Victorian era, the slavery in Queens, and how Queens was affected by World War II.

points_of_interest.name: Boathouse/Audobon Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Prospect Park Audubon Center is a partnership between Audubon New York and the Prospect Park Alliance, forged in 2000. The first urban-area Audubon Center in the nation, it is a place of active discovery with hands-on exhibits, live animals and the Alliance’s innovative programming for children and adults. The Prospect Park Audubon Center is housed in the park’s historic Boathouse, a landmark building surrounded by acres of carefully restored natural habitat and trails.
points_of_interest.address: 101 East Drive, Brooklyn, New York 11215, United States

points_of_interest.name: South Beach & Boardwalk
points_of_interest.description: This beach is a pleasant place to relax. The water is safe enough to swim in, but it's not the best you can get (you'd get a better deal down the Jersey Shore or on Long Island). The boardwalk, one of the longest in the United States, is great for running or biking.
points_of_interest.address: 640 Father Capodanno Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305, United States

points_of_interest.name: St. Patrick's Cathedral
points_of_interest.description:
St. Patrick's Cathedral, a prominent landmark in Midtown Manhattan, stands as a beautiful Gothic Revival cathedral. As the seat of the Archbishop of New York, it serves both as a place of worship and a significant cultural icon. Designed by James Renwick Jr., it is the largest Catholic cathedral of its style in North America.

Constructed from 1858 to 1878, the cathedral features stunning marble cladding, intricate stained glass, and bronze entrance doors. Its towers rise to 329.5 feet, housing nineteen bells, while the interior boasts two pipe organs and several chapels.

Consecrated in 1910, it has undergone restorations in the 1940s, 70s, and 2010s to preserve its grandeur. A must-visit attraction in New York City, it offers a serene escape amidst the bustling city.

points_of_interest.name: Temple Emanu-El of New York
points_of_interest.description: This temple traces its lineage to the founding of the Reform Jewish community in New York in 1845, although this building itself dates from 1929. The building is an important and impressive landmark, and the congregation numbers among its members many of the pillars of the Jewish community in New York, including major philanthropists, businesspeople, and politicians. If you don't arrange to visit the interior, it's worth just walking past the building and looking at the decorations on its exterior.
points_of_interest.hours: Visitors are welcome Su-Th 10AM-4:30PM — except in the occurrence of a holiday or funeral service (call ahead to make sure the temple is open when you plan on going). You can also visit the temple to pray, such as on the Sabbath, if you so choose

points_of_interest.name: Gramercy Park
points_of_interest.description: A private park open only to immediate area residents and guests at hotels on the perimeter who have access to keys to the gate. However, anyone can walk around the park, look in through the fence and look at the beautiful old buildings across the street from it on every side.
points_of_interest.address: 124 Gramercy Park South, New York, New York 10003, United States

points_of_interest.name: Saint Thomas Church
points_of_interest.description: Saint Thomas Church, located at 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan, is a stunning example of French High Gothic Revival architecture. Designed by renowned architects Ralph Adams Cram and Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue, the church has been a spiritual and cultural landmark since its completion in 1914. It is home to the Saint Thomas Choir of Men and Boys, one of the world’s premier choral ensembles, which performs traditional Anglican music during services and concerts. Visitors can also explore the church’s rich history and admire its intricate stone carvings and soaring vaults.
points_of_interest.hours: M–F approximately 7:30AM–6:30PM; Sa mornings and afternoons (hours vary week to week); Su 7AM–6PM (Sep-May), 7AM–1PM (Jun–Aug)

points_of_interest.name: Bowling Green
points_of_interest.description: A small park at the foot of Broadway which is the oldest public park in the city and is the site of the ''Charging Bull'' sculpture created after the 1987 stock market crash. Bowling Green is also the origin point for the Broadway ticker-tape parades; if you walk up Broadway, you can view plaques in the sidewalk honoring the people or events celebrated in these parades.
points_of_interest.address: 5 Beaver Street, New York, New York 10004, United States

points_of_interest.name: Children's Museum of Manhattan
points_of_interest.description: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan, located on the Upper West Side, offers a vibrant space for families to explore and learn. Known for its interactive exhibits, the museum focuses on art, science, and culture, making it a great destination for kids of all ages. With a commitment to education and creativity, it has been a neighborhood staple for decades. The museum is currently planning an exciting expansion to a larger location on 96th Street and Central Park West, promising even more opportunities for discovery and fun.

points_of_interest.name: Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center
points_of_interest.description: Once the '''Audubon Ballroom''' where Malcolm X was assassinated with 21 gunshots. Only a part of the facade of the original building remains (Columbia University demolished the building in 1992). The location now houses a memorial to Malcolm X and Betty Shabazz, with a stated goal of advancing human rights and social justice. It also features a 63-foot mural depicting Malcolm X's life.

points_of_interest.name: Metropolitan Museum of Art
points_of_interest.description: The Met One of the world's largest and most important museums of art and world culture, you'll have to devote several hours; nay, an entire ''day'' (if not more!), if you want to do this place justice. This massive neo-Gothic building, originally opened in 1872 and with numerous expansions added on over time, holds literally hundreds of rooms on its two floors, containing thousands of art pieces from across human history and around the world, covering virtually every field of art in existence, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Along with the numerous permanent exhibit halls mentioned below are several changing exhibit halls.

points_of_interest.name: Latimer House
points_of_interest.description: The Lewis H. Latimer House is a Queen Anne-style of home, built around 1888. Between 1903 and 1928, it was the home of African-American inventor Lewis Howard Latimer. Today, it is a museum dedicated to his life and achievements, as well as those of other African-American scientists.

points_of_interest.name: LeFrak Center at Lakeside
points_of_interest.description: Nestled in the heart of Brooklyn, the LeFrak Center at Lakeside offers a vibrant destination for outdoor enthusiasts. This picturesque spot is part of the expansive Prospect Park, a 526-acre urban oasis designed by the renowned Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux. Visitors can enjoy a variety of activities, including boating on the 60-acre lake, skating, and biking. The center is a hub for community events and outdoor concerts, making it a lively spot year-round. Whether you're looking to relax by the water or engage in some active fun, the LeFrak Center at Lakeside provides a welcoming and scenic escape within the city.
points_of_interest.address: 171 East Drive, Brooklyn, New York 11225, United States

points_of_interest.name: Von Briesen Park
points_of_interest.description: Von Briesen Park is a charming green space named after Arthur von Briesen, a notable lawyer and philanthropist. Once the president of the Legal Aid Society from 1889 to 1916, von Briesen's legacy is celebrated in this peaceful retreat. The park offers a relaxing escape with its lush surroundings, perfect for a stroll or a picnic. It’s a great spot to unwind and enjoy the outdoors, making it a local gem for both residents and visitors alike.
points_of_interest.address: North Road, Staten Island, New York 10305, United States

points_of_interest.name: Waldorf-Astoria Hotel
points_of_interest.description: The Waldorf Astoria is Hilton Worldwide's flagship luxury hotel brand, renowned for its exceptional service and world-class amenities. Known for its timeless elegance and sophistication, the Waldorf Astoria offers unforgettable experiences across its global portfolio. With properties in 15 countries and territories, each location combines rich local culture with the brand's signature luxury, ensuring a unique and memorable stay for discerning travelers.

points_of_interest.name: Ukrainian Institute of America
points_of_interest.description: If you want to get away from the bustling historical galleries along 5th Avenue, then be sure not to miss this gem hidden in plain sight. The Ukrainian Institute has a plethora of history on the culture-ridden Eastern European country of Ukraine, promoting the variety of art, music, and literature from the past centuries. In fact, you can not only be educated on but learn the Ukrainian language here. Art exhibits, concerts, films, lectures, literature readings, poetry, and even educational programs for both adults and children all contribute to the education of this fascinating yet too often forgotten culture.

points_of_interest.name: Bryant Park
points_of_interest.description: Located behind the Main Library, this shady park is an excellent spot to relax and get some good views of the surrounding skyscrapers. The park has free wireless internet, a children's carousel, several food and drink kiosks, and seasonal shows such as Fashion Week.

points_of_interest.name: The Paley Center for Media
points_of_interest.description: formerly the Museum of Television & Radio Dedicated to preserving and collecting television programs as a service to the public, the museum consists of two museum branches in Los Angeles and New York City; combined they hold over 100,000 television programs that are available to the public, providing a historical, artistic and cultural perspective to television and radio. You may use their library here for the price of admission. They have lots of old shows and a database so you can see if they have what you want.
points_of_interest.hours: W F–Su noon–6PM; Th noon–8PM; closed M Tu

points_of_interest.name: Battery Park
points_of_interest.description: At the southern tip of Manhattan, Battery Park is a waterfront green space, named for the artillery batteries which were installed here to protect the settlement of New York when it was under Dutch, then British rule. In the lead-up to the War of 1812, {{marker|type=see|url=http://www.nps.gov/cacl/|name=Castle Clinton|lat=40.70343|long=-74.01682}} was constructed as a fort to protect the city, and is now operated as a small museum. There are several memorials in the park, including {{marker|type=see|name=The Sphere|lat=40.70387|long=-74.01727}}, a public art piece originally housed on the World Trade Center site which survived the events of September 11 and was moved to Battery Park. Ferries departing to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island (see below) depart from here.
points_of_interest.address: Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, New York, New York 10004, United States

points_of_interest.name: Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine
points_of_interest.description: The world's largest neo-Gothic cathedral, the place has been a work in progress for over a century! There are also resident peacocks on campus, and many songbirds stop by during their seasonal migrations.

points_of_interest.name: Strivers Row
points_of_interest.description: Strivers' Row, also known as the St. Nicholas Historic District, is a charming enclave in Harlem, Upper Manhattan. This historic district, stretching across West 138th and 139th Streets, features stunning row houses designed in the late 19th century. The architecture varies across three distinct sections, showcasing Georgian Revival, Colonial Revival, and Italian Renaissance Revival styles. These homes, designed by prominent architectural firms, are celebrated as masterpieces of urban design. The district earned landmark status in 1967 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1975. Its name reflects its proximity to St. Nicholas Park, adding to its historic charm.

points_of_interest.name: Belvedere Castle
points_of_interest.description: Sitting on Vista Rock, one of the highest points in the park, the castle provides excellent views of Central Park, particularly to the north. It is a popular spot for photography and contains a visitor center and a nature conservatory. Just below the castle to the north is '''Turtle Pond''', a small, swamp-like pond holding various fish, frogs, insects, and birds.

points_of_interest.name: Old Quaker Meeting House
points_of_interest.description: The Old Quaker Meeting House is a historic Quaker house of worship, built in 1694. It is the oldest house of worship in New York City and one of the oldest continuously active places of worship in North America. Quakers continue to use the building for worship, at 11am on the first Sunday of each month, and everyone is welcome to join in worship.

points_of_interest.name: Willowbrook Park
points_of_interest.description: Willowbrook Park, located in Staten Island’s Willowbrook neighborhood, is a 164-acre green space within the Staten Island Greenbelt. This expansive park offers a variety of recreational activities, including baseball fields, a playground, and a serene pond. Visitors of all ages can enjoy the charming carousel, which was added in 1999. The park also provides a glimpse into the area’s history, as the former Staten Island Hotel is visible from its grounds. With its mix of natural beauty and family-friendly amenities, Willowbrook Park is a delightful destination for both locals and visitors exploring Staten Island.
points_of_interest.address: Eton Place at Richmond Avenue or Victory Boulevard at Morani Street

points_of_interest.name: The Morgan Library
points_of_interest.description: Once J. Pierpont Morgan's private library, this building houses his art collection, a Gutenberg Bible, and a first printing of The Star Spangled Banner. The bookshelves lining the walls include books by Dante, Dickens, Einstein, Twain, and several First and Second Folios.

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Broadway
points_of_interest.description: Opened on November 15, 2022, this interactive museum utilizes technology to convey the history of Broadway, complete with props from past shows, costumes, and other artifacts. You can learn about how a Broadway show is made, and there is a gift shop selling not only their own merch, but also products from current Broadway shows and Broadway in general.

points_of_interest.name: National September 11 Memorial & Museum
points_of_interest.description: World Trade Center site - note that the term 'Ground Zero' is never used by New Yorkers On the site of the former World Trade Center towers, the memorial consists of two enormous waterfalls and reflecting pools set within the footprints of the twin towers, lined with bronze panels with the names of the nearly 3,000 victims of that fateful day inscribed. The surrounding plaza holds a grove of trees. The museum, which sits underground right next to the memorial, contains exhibits which explain the events of 9/11 and their aftermath, with remnants of the original towers and artifacts from that day. If you see a white rose on one of the names, it's because today is that victim's birthday.
points_of_interest.hours: Memorial: 7:30AM-9PM daily; museum: Su-Th 9AM-8PM, F Sa 9AM-8PM, last museum entry 2 hours before closing

points_of_interest.name: Riverside Church
points_of_interest.description: Riverside Church is a historic interdenominational church in Manhattan's Morningside Heights, near Columbia University and Grant's Tomb. Designed in the Neo-Gothic style, the church features a striking 392-foot tower with a 74-bell carillon, the heaviest in the world. Conceived by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Harry Emerson Fosdick, Riverside Church has long been a hub for social justice and activism, reflecting its mission as an inclusive, interracial, and international community. A designated city landmark since 2000, the church is a must-visit for its architectural grandeur and historical significance.

points_of_interest.name: Theresa Tower
points_of_interest.description: This New York City landmark started accepting black guests in 1940, becoming one of the few hotels in the city to do so. This led it to become a mixing point for notable African Americans of the time, and through the 40s and 50s it was the center of black Harlem social community. It also gained notoriety when Fidel Castro chose to stay here for the 1960 UN General Assembly. Its ornamentation makes it one of the most visually striking buildings in Northern Manhattan.
points_of_interest.address: 2082-96 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard (7th Av.)

points_of_interest.name: Conservatory Pond
points_of_interest.description: Most well known as the Model Boat Pond, visitors can often see a racing regatta between members of the Model Yacht Club, or rent a model boat from a boathouse and cafe on the pond. Just to the north of the pond is the '''Alice in Wonderland''' sculpture depicting the Tea Party scene, and on the west side of the pond is the '''Hans Christian Andersen''' sculpture, which shows the writer seated on a bench reading a book to his ''Ugly Duckling'' character.

points_of_interest.name: Queens Botanical Garden
points_of_interest.description: Large garden and arboretum featuring a variety of plants, and also a Victorian-style wedding garden.

points_of_interest.name: Wolfe's Pond Park
points_of_interest.description: Wolfe's Pond Park, located on Staten Island's South Shore, is a sprawling green space offering a mix of natural beauty and recreational activities. The park is split into two distinct areas: the eastern half features Wolfe's Pond, playgrounds, sports courts, walking and biking paths, and a small beach along Raritan Bay. The western half is more tranquil, with woodlands and ponds. A highlight for visitors is the annual 4th of July fireworks display, complete with live entertainment and food vendors, drawing crowds from across Staten Island. This park is a perfect spot for both relaxation and active fun.
points_of_interest.address: Hylan Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305, United States

points_of_interest.name: One World Trade Center
points_of_interest.description: The One World Trade Center skyscraper rises 1,776 feet above the street and is the tallest building in the United States (and for that matter, the Western Hemisphere). Despite its colossal size, its simple design allows it to blend remarkably well into the Lower Manhattan skyline. An observation deck on the top floors offers 360-degree views of the city.
points_of_interest.hours: Daily 9AM-8PM, open daily until midnight in the summer months; last ticket sold 45 min prior to close

points_of_interest.name: Columbia University
points_of_interest.description: Columbia University, a prestigious Ivy League institution, is the oldest college in New York and the fifth-oldest in the U.S. Founded in 1754 as King's College, it moved to its current Morningside Heights campus in 1896. The university is renowned for its academic excellence, groundbreaking research, and historic contributions to fields like science and journalism, including the Pulitzer Prize. Visitors can explore its beautiful campus, featuring iconic buildings and a mix of modern and historic architecture. As a hub of innovation and learning, Columbia attracts scholars and tourists alike, offering a glimpse into its rich history and intellectual legacy.
points_of_interest.address: 535 College Walk, New York, New York 10027, United States

points_of_interest.name: Fort Tryon Park
points_of_interest.description: One of New York's most beautiful parks, an expanse of rolling hills high above the Hudson, contains some of the highest natural elevations on the island and is a great place to picnic or stroll in good weather and look at the great views of the New Jersey Palisades across the river.
points_of_interest.address: 4565 Broadway, New York, New York 10040, United States

points_of_interest.name: Great Lawn
points_of_interest.description: At the center of Central Park, the Great Lawn is a large clearing with lawns and ballfields, perfect for ballgames, sunbathing, and picnicking. Just to the east of the Lawn is the '''Obelisk''', a 71-foot tall structure which is the oldest man-made object in the park, having been erected in Heliopolis, Egypt, around 1500 BC.
points_of_interest.address: 75 Great Lawn Oval, New York, New York 10028, United States

points_of_interest.name: Voelker Orth Museum
points_of_interest.description: This is historic home that was built by local businessman James Bouton in 1891. Eight years later, Conrad Voelcker bought the house, and the Voelcker family lived in the house for three generations. Today, it is a museum, and there is a Victorian garden and a bird sanctuary outside.

points_of_interest.name: Alice Austen House
points_of_interest.description: The Alice Austen House, also known as Clear Comfort, is a charming museum located in the Rosebank section of Staten Island. Once the home of pioneering photographer Alice Austen, this historic site now showcases her remarkable work and offers a glimpse into her life. As the first NYC site dedicated to a woman to be recognized by the LGBT Historic Sites project in 2021, it holds significant cultural importance. Managed by the Friends of Alice Austen, this welcoming destination invites visitors to explore its rich history and celebrate Austen's enduring legacy.

points_of_interest.name: St Paul's Chapel
points_of_interest.description: Built in 1766, the chapel is an active part of the Parish of Trinity Church and is Manhattan's oldest public building in continuous use. It is the only remaining colonial church in New York City and was George Washington's place of worship after he was inaugurated as president. Since 2001, the chapel has been known for surviving the events of 9/11 without even a broken window - despite being across the street from the World Trade Center - and for its role as a place of refuge for the WTC recovery workers in the days that followed.

points_of_interest.name: Barnard College
points_of_interest.description: Barnard College, a private women's liberal arts college in Manhattan, is part of the historic Seven Sisters and affiliated with Columbia University. Founded in 1889, it offers a rigorous education with access to Columbia's resources, including libraries, clubs, and NCAA Division I athletics through the Columbia-Barnard Athletic Consortium. The 4-acre campus in Morningside Heights is across from Columbia's main campus. Barnard alumnae have achieved distinction in various fields, earning prestigious awards like the Pulitzer Prize and Emmys, reflecting the college's commitment to empowering women leaders.
points_of_interest.address: 3011 Broadway, New York, New York 10027, United States

points_of_interest.name: The Lake
points_of_interest.description: The lake is a fine setting for a serene afternoon in the park. Rental boats are available from the '''Loeb Boathouse''' (on the eastern side of the lake) for a ride on the water. The '''Bow Bridge''', a Central Park landmark, spans the middle of the lake.
points_of_interest.address: 72 Terrace Drive, New York, New York 10023, United States

points_of_interest.name: Conference House
points_of_interest.description: Dates back to 1680, and held an abortive peace conference during the Revolutionary War.

points_of_interest.name: New York by Gehry
points_of_interest.description: A 2011 addition to the Lower Manhattan skyline, this 76-story residential skyscraper by the noted Frank Gehry has a distinctive rippled, "wavy" facade that is quite eye-catching. It is best viewed from City Hall Park and the Brooklyn Bridge.

points_of_interest.name: Teachers College
points_of_interest.description: Affiliated with Columbia, Teacher's College is an architectural gem with its block length Beaux Arts and neo-Gothic façades.

points_of_interest.name: Inwood Hill Park
points_of_interest.description: Inwood Hill Park contains the last tracts of virgin forest in Manhattan. Many arrowheads and other artifacts of the former Native American occupants of Manhattan Island have been found in this park.

points_of_interest.name: The Ramble
points_of_interest.description: A sort of mini forest, described by its designer as a "wild garden," the Ramble is sculpted out of a wooded hillside, with winding paths, rocky outcrops, secluded glades, and a tumbling stream. If one travels through the ramble when the trees are full, it is easy to lose sight of the city's skyscrapers; it's as if you're no longer in Manhattan. The Ramble is also an excellent place to bird watch, with over 250 species of birds that stop here on their migration.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Bridge
points_of_interest.description: From its intersection with Park Row (just east of City Hall) you can walk (takes about 20-30 minutes each way), bike, or drive across the historic and iconic bridge to Brooklyn. The view from the bridge is quite lovely, with excellent views of Lower Manhattan and Downtown Brooklyn and good views of Midtown and the New York Harbor in the distance.
points_of_interest.address: Brooklyn Bridge, Manhattan, New York 10273, United States

points_of_interest.name: Juilliard School of Dance, Drama, and Music
points_of_interest.description: The Juilliard School, located at Lincoln Center in New York City, is one of the world’s most prestigious performing arts conservatories. Founded in 1905, it offers programs in dance, drama, and music, with a focus on rigorous training and artistic excellence. Known for its highly selective admissions, Juilliard attracts talented students from around the globe. The campus features state-of-the-art facilities, including performance halls and a renowned library. Juilliard’s alumni have achieved extraordinary success, earning numerous Grammy, Tony, Emmy, and Academy Awards. Visitors can experience the school’s vibrant performances throughout the year, showcasing the next generation of artistic talent.

points_of_interest.name: Muscota Marsh
points_of_interest.description: An elevated walkway and jetty provides access to the only natural salt marsh remaining in Manhattan, and expansive views of the Hudson River and the cliffs of Spuyten Duyvil in the Bronx across the river.

points_of_interest.name: The Reservoir
points_of_interest.description: Constructed between 1858 and 1862, the Reservoir is a vast urban lake that covers 106 acres of Central Park and is the largest body of water within Manhattan. Renamed the "Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir" in 1994, the Reservoir is probably best known for the 1.58 mile track that runs around its edge and which is a favorite for joggers, who can both run and enjoy the spectacular views of the city skyline.
points_of_interest.address: 110 97th Street Transverse, New York, New York 10025, United States

points_of_interest.name: Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art
points_of_interest.description: American woman Jacques Marchais had a dream of traveling to Tibet. While she never made it, her extensive collection of Tibetan artifacts was made into a museum in 1947. The museum now holds over 120 pieces of beautiful Tibetan art. The museum's authenticity was praised by the Dalai Lama.

points_of_interest.name: Irish Hunger Memorial
points_of_interest.description:
The Irish Hunger Memorial is a poignant 0.5-acre park located in Battery Park City, Manhattan. Dedicated to commemorating the Great Irish Hunger (An Gorta Mór), the memorial honors the over one million lives lost between 1845 and 1852. It also acknowledges the nearly one million Irish immigrants who arrived in New York during that decade, reshaping the city’s population.

Designed by artist Brian Tolle, landscape architect Gail Wittwer-Laird, and 1100 Architect, the memorial features stones, soil, and native Irish vegetation. A restored 19th-century Irish cottage stands as a powerful symbol of the era and the resilience of those who emigrated.
points_of_interest.address: Vesey Place, New York, New York 10282, United States

points_of_interest.name: Manhattan School of Music
points_of_interest.description: Another conservatory of music.
points_of_interest.address: 3081 Broadway, New York, New York 10027, United States

points_of_interest.name: Marcus Garvey Park
points_of_interest.description: Mount Morris Park One of the oldest parks in Manhattan. The elegant brownstones on the western and southern sides of the park hint at the former grandeur of the neighborhood (many were built in the 1880s). The ''Acropolis'', a lookout seventy feet above street level gives views of the Empire State Building, the George Washington Bridge, and Yankee Stadium. The Firetower, a landmark 1857 building (closed off for reconstruction as of 2019), is the only surviving example of 19th-century fire watchtowers. This park is very popular with locals and has a relaxed vibe. There is a dedicated Drum Circle area of the park and others come with sound systems to play old-school soul and funk, dance, ride bikes, etc. It also has a swimming pool.
points_of_interest.address: 6316 Mount Morris Park West, New York, New York 10027, United States

points_of_interest.name: Charles A. Dana Discovery Center
points_of_interest.description: On the north shore of the Harlem Meer, the Discovery Center holds education and community programs and seasonal exhibits, as well as offering a popular place for catch-and-release fishing.

points_of_interest.name: Staten Island Children's Museum
points_of_interest.description: The Staten Island Children's Museum, located on the historic grounds of Sailors' Snug Harbor, is a must-visit destination for families. Since opening in 1976, the museum has been a cornerstone of interactive learning, offering hands-on exhibits that engage children of all ages. Outside, a striking metal sculpture of a praying mantis named Francis welcomes visitors, adding a touch of whimsy to the experience. This museum is a great spot for kids to explore, learn, and have fun in a creative environment.

points_of_interest.name: Queen Elizabeth II Garden
points_of_interest.description: The Queen Elizabeth II Garden is a serene green space in the Financial District of Lower Manhattan. This tranquil spot honors the victims of the September 11 attacks from Commonwealth nations. Opened by Queen Elizabeth II in 2010, it serves as a peaceful retreat amidst the bustling city. Visitors can enjoy its calm atmosphere and reflect on its meaningful history.
points_of_interest.address: 2 Hanover Square, New York, New York 10004, United States

points_of_interest.name: Fordham College at Lincoln Center
points_of_interest.description: Fordham College at Lincoln Center, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is a vibrant academic and cultural hub within Fordham University. This campus offers a unique blend of educational excellence and artistic expression, situated near the renowned Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Visitors can explore the campus's modern facilities while being just steps away from New York City's iconic landmarks. The campus embodies the dynamic spirit of NYC, providing students and visitors alike with a stimulating environment that fosters both learning and cultural enrichment.

points_of_interest.name: Riverside Park
points_of_interest.description: A riverfront park providing pleasant views of New Jersey and sometimes breezes off the river. Summer brings al fresco movies and music to the park.
points_of_interest.address: west of Riverside Dr, 72nd St to 158th St

points_of_interest.name: Conservatory Garden
points_of_interest.description: A six-acre garden which is Central Park's only formal garden, representing Italian, French, and English landscape styles, with formal plantings and numerous sculptures.

points_of_interest.name: Staten Island Museum
points_of_interest.description: Staten Island Museum, established in 1881 by early environmental advocates, is Staten Island’s oldest cultural institution and the only general-interest museum in New York City. Known as a “mini-Smithsonian,” it offers a diverse collection spanning art, natural sciences, and local history. The museum features three main collections: Natural Sciences, with over 500,000 specimens, including insects and fossils; Fine Art, showcasing works from prehistory to modern times across global cultures; and History Archives & Library, housing historical documents, photographs, and ephemera dating back to the 17th century. This treasure trove invites visitors to explore Staten Island’s rich cultural and natural heritage.

points_of_interest.name: African Burial Ground National Monument
points_of_interest.description: For most of the 18th century, Africans in New York City were buried in a graveyard outside the city. The graveyard was eventually forgotten and was rediscovered in 1991. This museum and memorial site commemorate the estimated 15,000 Africans that were interred on the site of the memorial. Note that the museum is located inside of a Federal building so airport-style security should be expected.
points_of_interest.hours: Visitor Center: Tu-Sa 10AM-4PM except Federal holidays; Memorial: Daily 9AM-5PM except Federal holidays. Memorial closed November–March

points_of_interest.name: Grant's Tomb
points_of_interest.description: General Grant National Memorial General Ulysses S. Grant and his wife are buried in this imposing mausoleum, the largest tomb in North America. If you come when it is closed, you can still see the impressive facade, but coming during open hours gives you the opportunity to view the murals, the tomb and various documentation inside. Across Riverside Drive, there is a viewpoint to look across the Hudson River, a museum, gift shop and restrooms.

points_of_interest.name: Great Hill
points_of_interest.description: One of the highest points in the park, the Great Hill is a hilltop meadow surrounded by stately elm trees and serves as an excellent place to picnic.

points_of_interest.name: National Lighthouse Museum
points_of_interest.description: The National Lighthouse Museum, located in St. George on Staten Island, New York City, offers a fascinating look at the history of lighthouses and their keepers. Housed in a historic former foundry building, the museum showcases exhibits that explore the importance of lighthouses in maritime history. Visitors can delve into the stories of the dedicated individuals who maintained these beacons and learn about their significance in guiding mariners. This unique attraction is a must-visit for anyone interested in nautical history or seeking a glimpse into a lesser-known aspect of American heritage.

points_of_interest.name: Fraunces Tavern
points_of_interest.description: Fraunces Tavern, located in Lower Manhattan’s Financial District, is a historic museum and restaurant that played a significant role in American history. Once the headquarters of George Washington and a site for peace negotiations during the American Revolution, it now offers a glimpse into the past. The building, conjecturally reconstructed in the early 20th century, is believed to be Manhattan’s oldest surviving structure. Visitors can explore its museum, enjoy dining, and appreciate its designation as a National Historic Landmark. Part of the American Whiskey Trail and New York Freedom Trail, Fraunces Tavern is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and travelers alike.

points_of_interest.name: Shinran Shonin
points_of_interest.description: Staring pensively across Riverside Drive at the children playing in the park is the statue of Shinran Shonin, a 13th-century Buddhist reformer. In another life, the statue stood in Hiroshima and witnessed the devastation caused by the bomb. His New York home is between two Riverside Drive buildings right next to the '''[http://www.newyorkbuddhistchurch.org/index.html New York Buddhist Center]'''.

points_of_interest.name: Harlem Meer
points_of_interest.description: This 11 acre lake is one of Central Park's finest spots; surrounded by flowering trees and inhabited by several fish and turtle species.

points_of_interest.name: Postcards
points_of_interest.description: Postcards is an outdoor sculpture in St. George, Staten Island, New York City, United States. Built in 2004, it is a permanent memorial honouring the 274 Staten Island residents killed in the September 11 attacks of 2001 and in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. The dead include many who worked at the World Trade Center, police and firefighters who joined the rescue effort and were killed when the towers collapsed, and one passenger on United Airlines Flight 93, who died in the crash in Shanksville, Pennsylvania. One individual who was killed in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing is also represented.
points_of_interest.address: Bank Street, Staten Island, New York 10301, United States

points_of_interest.name: Museum of American Finance
points_of_interest.description: A small museum dedicated to finance and the markets, with exhibits that change periodically. Closed to find a new location as of Mar 2024.

points_of_interest.name: Soldiers and Sailors Monument
points_of_interest.description: A memorial to the Civil War dead (though, in typical New York fashion, it wasn't constructed till 1902, almost 40 years after the Civil War ended). The Hudson Warehouse stages plays (mostly Shakespeare) on the steps of the monument every summer.

points_of_interest.name: North Woods
points_of_interest.description: None of Central Park is actual virgin forest, but this is the closest any part of the park gets to feeling like genuine forest. It is beautiful and cool in hot weather. However, like a real forest, it is a mosquito habitat, so make sure to use insect repellent before walking through this part of the park.
points_of_interest.address: west side to middle of the park, north of 101st St

points_of_interest.name: Snug Harbor Cultural Center
points_of_interest.description: Snug Harbor This is the largest collection of Greek revival, temple style buildings in America. A true architectural gem featuring the Staten Island Botanic Garden, which features an authentic Chinese Scholar's garden (created by actual Chinese scholars!). There is also an art museum, the John A. Noble Collection, on the grounds. This is one of the most beautiful places in New York, a place even the most jaded New Yorker will marvel at.
points_of_interest.address: Chapel Road, Staten Island, New York 10301, United States

points_of_interest.name: Museum of Jewish Heritage
points_of_interest.description: The Museum of Jewish Heritage, located in Battery Park City, Manhattan, is a poignant tribute to the victims of the Holocaust. As a living memorial, it educates visitors about Jewish life in the 20th and 21st centuries, offering a comprehensive look at experiences before, during, and after the Holocaust. The museum’s design is symbolic, with a six-sided building evoking the memory of the six million Jews lost. An additional wing hosts educational programs and exhibitions, creating a space for reflection and learning. This cultural landmark invites visitors to explore a rich history and its enduring legacy.

points_of_interest.name: The Pool
points_of_interest.description: One of the most idyllic and tranquil landscapes in Central Park, the Pool is an excellent spot for quiet contemplation, with its grassy banks and nearby waterfalls. A stream, '''The Loch''' flows northeast from the Pool, through a stream valley called '''The Ravine'''. A trail that follows the Loch, winding under a canopy of tall trees as the stream goes over several waterfalls and passes under a couple of stone arches.

points_of_interest.name: National Museum of the American Indian
points_of_interest.description: Housed in the Alexander Hamilton US Custom House, this Smithsonian museum is the New York branch of the National Museum of the American Indian (the other branches are in Washington, D.C. and Maryland).

points_of_interest.name: New York City Police Museum
points_of_interest.description: The New York City Police Museum offers a fascinating look at the history and legacy of the NYPD. Located in Lower Manhattan, the museum honors the department's contributions while also serving as a poignant memorial to the September 11 attacks. Interactive exhibits, such as a police firefight simulation, allow visitors to gain insight into the challenges faced by officers. This unique museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in law enforcement history or seeking a deeper understanding of the brave men and women who protect the city.

points_of_interest.name: Skyscraper Museum
points_of_interest.description: Exhibits on the history of highrise and skyscraper construction.

points_of_interest.name: South Street Seaport Museum
points_of_interest.description: The South Street Seaport Museum is a historic district in Lower Manhattan, offering a glimpse into New York City's maritime past. Located on the East River, the area is home to some of the city's oldest buildings, including restored 19th-century mercantile structures and sailing ships. Once the site of the bustling Fulton Fish Market, the Seaport now blends history with modern attractions, featuring shops, dining, and entertainment options. Visitors can explore its charming cobblestone streets, enjoy river views, and experience a unique blend of history and contemporary culture in one of Manhattan's most vibrant neighborhoods.
points_of_interest.hours: Jan-Mar: F-M 10AM-5PM, Ships noon-4PM; Apr-Dec: Tu-Su 10AM-6PM

points_of_interest.name: Federal Reserve Museum and Gold Vault Tour
points_of_interest.description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, located in Lower Manhattan, is a must-visit for history and finance enthusiasts. This iconic building, designed in the early Italian Renaissance style, houses one of the world's largest gold reserves. The gold vault, situated 80 feet below street level, holds over 6,000 tons of gold. Guided tours offer a fascinating glimpse into the bank's operations and the vault's security features. The building itself is a architectural marvel, blending historic design with modern functionality. A visit here provides a unique perspective on the financial world and its rich history.
points_of_interest.hours: Tours M-F at 1PM & 2PM, except bank holidays. Arrive 30 minutes early for security screening

points_of_interest.name: Statue Cruises
points_of_interest.description: The only means of access to Liberty and Ellis Islands; the ferries depart from Battery Park at the southern tip of Manhattan or from Liberty State Park in Jersey City. Be prepared for airport like security screening with similar restrictions (no food or open liquids, no knives, etc.) before boarding the boat. One ticket is good for sailings to both islands and return to starting point. Tickets are limited in number and can be obtained on the day from the ferry company or in advance by calling the ticket office on the phone number above or [http://www.statuecruises.com/ online]. If leaving from Manhattan, you may need to arrive at Battery Park 2 hours before your timed tour to allow for security screening and ferry travel, so it is best to arrive at Battery Park early in the morning.
points_of_interest.address: 10 Battery Place, New York, New York 10004, United States
points_of_interest.hours: 8:30AM-5:15PM (hours adjusted seasonally); if you leave after 2PM, you will only be able to visit either Liberty Island or Ellis Island

points_of_interest.name: Statue of Liberty
points_of_interest.description: "Liberty Enlightening the World" One of the most famous and iconic landmarks in the USA, if not the world. A gift from the people of France to celebrate the centennial of the United States, stands upon Liberty Island and is one of the most famous symbols of the nation and has been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage list. Upon departing the ferry, you can visit the Visitor Information Station, which has a schedule of the day's events. Visitors can also meet at the Liberty Island Flagpole (behind the statue) for a ranger-led tour of the island. You can also visit the monument lobby, museum (where you'll see various exhibits on the statue, the old torch, and the famous "New Colossus" sonnet), and outside to the promenade and Fort Wood (the 11-point star-shaped structure the statue stands upon). You can also take a trip to the pedestal observation deck (though not up into the statue itself, unless you have a Reserve with Crown ticket); visitors can look upward to view the interior of the statue (there are four marked viewing locations); and the pedestal observation deck provides a 360-degree view, which includes the New York City skyline. Security checks are rigorous, so travel as light as possible. Backpacks and other large bags are not permitted on the tours but can be stored in lockers for a fee. On busy days there may be long waits. Visitors with the Reserve with Crown ticket are allowed to climb up a circular staircase from the base of the statue to the '''crown''', but tickets are very limited and should be reserved three or four months (up to one year) in advance. Children must be at least 4-feet tall, and must be able to walk up and down the stairs by themselves, and all ticket holders must show a photo ID to match the name on their tickets. The design of Lady Liberty's torch evokes the universal symbol of enlightenment, which lights the way to freedom, showing immigrants the path to liberty and justice.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Liberty Island Ellis, New York, New York 10004, United States

points_of_interest.name: Ellis Island
points_of_interest.description: Ellis Island was home to the nation's primary federal immigration station, with over 12 million immigrant steamship passengers passing through from its opening in 1892 to its closing in 1954. Today, over 40 percent of America's population can trace their ancestry through Ellis Island. The island is home to the '''[http://www.ellisisland.org/ American Family Immigration History Center]''', which contains manifests of 25 million immigrants, passengers, and crew members who entered New York Harbor. The Immigration museum at Ellis Islands has details about "Peopling of America" and if you are an avid history lover, this museum will need at least 3-4 hrs of your time. Since the ferry ride takes you to both Ellis Island as well as the Liberty Island, you will have to plan your day well.
points_of_interest.address: 1 Ellis Island Bridge, Jersey City, New Jersey 07305, United States

points_of_interest.name: Governors Island
points_of_interest.description: Governors Island has a long military history, home to headquarters and military posts of the United States Army from 1794 until 1966, then a complex for the U.S. Coast Guard before becoming a historic district open to tours.
points_of_interest.address: ferries depart from the Battery Maritime Building at 10 South St
points_of_interest.hours: Open seasonally; W-Th guided tours take place at 10AM and 1PM, F ferries leave every hour 10AM-3PM, Sa-Su ferries leave every hour 10AM-5PM, from Brooklyn ferries leave every 20 minutes

points_of_interest.name: Stray Vintage
points_of_interest.description: This is a nice store where you can find used, vintage & consignment, antiques and vinyl records.

points_of_interest.name: Bolla
points_of_interest.description: Bolla's always poppin off, bro. Whether you're looking to grab some candy, or just drink beers in the parking lot, it's just always poppin!

points_of_interest.name: The World's Borough Bookshop
points_of_interest.description: A homey bookstore that also holds community events. Stocks locally made snacks, knick-knacks, and books by BIPOC authors.

points_of_interest.name: Gateway Center Mall
points_of_interest.description: A suburban-type mall. While the mall itself is safe, use caution in the surrounding areas while you are on the bus to the mall.

points_of_interest.name: IKEA
points_of_interest.description: There is a water taxi (M-F $5, one way, Sa-Su free) from Pier 11 a few blocks north and east of the Battery in Manhattan's Financial District to the Red Hook IKEA store.

points_of_interest.name: Aji Ichiban
points_of_interest.description: Hong Kong snack shop, very popular with locals and tourists alike. The staff are friendly and give samples.

points_of_interest.name: Bellitte Bicycles
points_of_interest.description: The oldest continuously family owned bicycle store at the same location in the United States.

points_of_interest.name: Retrofret Vintage Guitars
points_of_interest.description: Retrofret Vintage Guitars shop in the Gowanus deals exclusively in vintage, antique and used musical instruments, it is reported to be the largest store of its type on the east coast. The customer base is fairly evenly divided between local/tri-state area, national and international clients. Owner and founder, Steve Uhrik, moved the business to its current location from SoHo, Manhattan in 1983.

points_of_interest.name: Asia Market
points_of_interest.description: Renovated several years ago from a dusty, old grocery store with tight aisles and rusty shelves into a brighter, more spacious store with a wider selection of goods, Asia Market supplies a variety of Asian ingredients, snacks, and drinks. Usually the difficult, hard to find Southeast Asian ingredients will most likely be available at this store. Even if something you want isn't available, the staff here is very friendly. You may leave the brand name of the product you want and they may try to order it for you. There is also a vegetable and fruit stand outside the store. Basically, this may be your one-stop store to shop for everything. One good example of the products this store has is fresh kaffir lime leaves.

points_of_interest.name: Bluestockings Radical Books
points_of_interest.description: A fun radical feminist bookstore that also has a little cafe and a regular calendar of readings and other events.

points_of_interest.name: Bangkok Center Grocery
points_of_interest.description: This modest-sized store contains a large quantity of Thai goods of various descriptions, and also sells inexpensive prepared sweet and savory items. Friendly, helpful service.

points_of_interest.name: Euromarket Astoria
points_of_interest.description: Grocery market serving many specialty European foods that are difficult to find in the US. Outstanding collections of international meats, cheeses, wines, and beers.

points_of_interest.name: Fei Long Market
points_of_interest.description: An absolutely massive shop selling all manner of Chinese ingredients, including a very good produce section. Can be extremely crowded, though, so go in the off hours.

points_of_interest.name: Moishe's Kosher Bakery
points_of_interest.description: This is an old-fashioned kosher bakery. Among their excellent offerings are their strudels, mandel bread, rugelach, black & whites, danishes, almond horns, cinnamon sticks and kichlach (big crispy sugar cookies), and their challahs are also very popular. Their hamantashen are also good. The Chinese almond cookies are good, but some of the smaller cookies are not too consistent in quality. The counterwomen are always willing to help you select items that were baked that day. Items that are in individual portion size, like black & whites, danishes, and almond horns, cost around $2.50-$3 apiece, but rugelach and mandel bread are quite a lot more expensive and must be bought by the quarter pound (minimum) or as an entire large piece, respectively. The staff will be happy to cut you a piece of strudel, and they will also slice challah for you without extra charge. Wednesdays and Thursdays are particularly good days to visit, as they have fresh chocolate and sometimes also cinnamon babka those days, and with any luck, you can get some that's still warm (unfortunately, they no longer sell it by the slice; you'll have to get half a babka or an entire one). There is no place to sit, so all business is for takeout, and they do not have napkins or utensils to give you.

points_of_interest.name: Deluxe Food Market
points_of_interest.description: This humongous store has almost anything you can think of and more, both raw and prepared. Seriously; go and see.

points_of_interest.name: Kee's Chocolates
points_of_interest.description: Kee is widely considered by chocolate-lovers to be one of the best artisanal chocolatiers in New York. Anyone who likes chocolate will find some of her creations interesting and enjoyable. Among her truffles are balsamic, fennel, smoked salt, and Thai chili, as well as less unusual flavors like almond and hazelnut praline.

points_of_interest.name: Industry City
points_of_interest.description: Old, disused factory buildings have been transformed into retail, food, creative, leisure, and office spaces along the Sunset Park waterfront. Interesting food stores include Blue Marble Ice Cream, Japan Village, Li-Lac Chocolates and Sahadi's. Several bars and cafés will help quench your thirst. Industry City includes a "makers guild" and the Brooklyn design district. Nearby but not officially part of Industry City are large national retailers such as Costco, Bed Bath & Beyond, and Cost Plus World Market.
points_of_interest.hours: General: 8AM–9PM daily; IC Food Hall: 8AM–7PM daily; Most retail shops: 10AM–7PM daily

points_of_interest.name: Malaysia Beef Jerky
points_of_interest.description: This is not a cheap snack, but their chicken and beef jerky are excellent and come in spicy and regular varieties. Unlike American-style jerky, Malaysian-style jerky is moist. Its sugar content may surprise you, so low-carb dieters, beware! There is nowhere to sit inside the store, so business is strictly for takeout.

points_of_interest.name: Pearl River Mart
points_of_interest.description: Vast store of Chinese and other Asian goods: kitchenware, traditional clothing, home furnishing, tea.

points_of_interest.name: Kerekes Bakery & Restaurant Equipment
points_of_interest.description: BakeDeco Whether you're a restaurateur or a home chef, you can find a wide array of cooking and baking supplies at Kerekes/BakeDeco. Find almost anything you need for your kitchen or dining room.
points_of_interest.hours: M–Th 9AM–6PM, Fr 9AM–1PM, Su 11AM–4PM (closed Su in Jul & Aug), closed Sa & Jewish holidays

points_of_interest.name: Uniqlo
points_of_interest.description: A Japanese clothing store for men and women. This location used to be the retail chain's only North American store.

points_of_interest.name: Super Outflation Discount
points_of_interest.description: This small neighborhood variety store manages to pack in loads of merchandise including food, housewares, health & beauty, toiletries, cosmetics, greeting cards, party supplies, and some clothing items. It's no Target or Walmart, but it's a step above Brooklyn's ubiquitous 99¢ stores.

points_of_interest.name: Aeon Bookstore
