points_of_interest.description: This subterranean bookstore is a neighborhood gem, with a carefully curated selection of books. The books are fairly prices and cover a range of topics, such as philosophy, art, culture, history, mysticism, and esoterica.

points_of_interest.name: John Varvatos
points_of_interest.description: A rather vivid example of the gentrification of the Bowery, this store is noteworthy for being the former home of CBGB, an underground nightclub that was famous for being the center of the New Wave and hardcore punk scenes in the 1970s and 80s. Today, it's a high-end men's fashion store popular for the many rock stars among its clients. Though the punk crowd is gone, the flyer-covered walls from CBGB have been preserved and rock memorabilia sits beside the store's designer jackets and shoes.

points_of_interest.name: LF Stores
points_of_interest.description: LF Stores is not very big or well known, but it carries some unique items, such that celebrities have shopped here. The prices are a little bit on the high side, depending on the item for example, shirts cost about $50-200. The service is wonderful, and the staff is very helpful. Aside from clothing, there are such accessories as jewelry, scarfs, hats, and shoes. The outside of the narrow building is tan, and there is a doorman.

points_of_interest.name: Kalinka Gifts
points_of_interest.description: Trinkets from Russia and elsewhere in the world.

points_of_interest.name: Brooklyn Superhero Supply Store
points_of_interest.description: The Brooklyn Superhero Supply Co. is your one-stop shopping destination for crime-fighting needs in the Tri-State area. Items on sale include capes, masks, secret identity kits, invisibility detection goggles, particle blasters, powdered anti-matter, deflector gauntlets, bottled justice, maps showing hotspots of good and evil, power rings, and countless other tools essential for any hard-working do-gooder. Test a cape, get devillainized, create your superhero persona and enter it in the master log - they've got it all. The BSSC is also a clever front for the 826NYC Student Writing Center, a non-profit center founded by Dave Eggers (among others) where kids aged 6-18 may receive after school tutoring, or attend a variety of creative workshops, all free of charge. Student writing is on sale in the store, along with books and other items from the McSweeney's label.

points_of_interest.name: McNally Jackson Books
points_of_interest.description: Formerly McNally Robinson Booksellers, this independent bookstore features an extensive collection of magazines, fiction, and nonfiction. The store also features a cafe, as well as a number of ongoing events, signings, book clubs and discussion groups.

points_of_interest.name: The Shape of Lies
points_of_interest.description: One of the last live/work artist store fronts in the East Village. Morphing from window art dioramas in the 80s they now showcase only local jewelry designers and artists along with their own museum replica jewelry and paintings. Screen door and original tin ceiling complete the authentic East Village look.

points_of_interest.name: Apple Store
points_of_interest.description: Located beneath a giant glass cube, this flagship Apple Store is open 24/7 and is crowded with shoppers all day long. Come here on the day the company releases a new gadget and you'll see lines that wrap around the block.

points_of_interest.name: Lola Star
points_of_interest.description: Boutique and souvenir shop on the boardwalk.
points_of_interest.address: Coney Island Boardwalk between W 12th St and Stillwell

points_of_interest.name: Beacon's Closet
points_of_interest.description: Incredibly cheap yet hip second hand store, bound to catch your attention and the change in your pocket.

points_of_interest.name: 2 Bridges Music Arts
points_of_interest.description: 2 Bridges Music Arts sells new and used records, tapes and books while staging exhibitions and events from their post in a Chinatown mall. The space is meant to host overlapping tendencies in experimental music, art and knowledge production internationally.

points_of_interest.name: Strand Bookstore
points_of_interest.description: One of the foremost used bookstores in New York, reportedly housing over 18 miles of shelf space, all of it crammed to capacity. They also carry new books and offer loads of merchandise, including stationery, book accessories, and branded tote bags and apparel sporting their famous logo. A recent renovation has opened up the space tremendously, though that will be a surprise to any newcomer, who will marvel at the wall-to-wall crowds.

points_of_interest.name: FAO Schwarz
points_of_interest.description: This three level toy store in the heart of Manhattan New York City will make you feel like a kid again. You can take a selfie with the toy soldiers and watch live demonstrations of toys given by store employees. Also a good place to stop if you need a public restroom. Many toys sold here are either rare and hard to find or exclusive to FAO Schwarz

points_of_interest.name: Topshop
points_of_interest.description: Topshop is a women's clothing store that carries all types of clothing. It carries maternity clothing, designers, boutiques, and all sizes. The clothing is really fashion forward, and there have accessories. The main warehouse is in England. You can buy online or go to the store, which has two floors and an escalator. The prices vary, but they tend to run a little bit more on the high side. Items mostly vary from around $50-$90.

points_of_interest.name: Mosvideofilm
points_of_interest.description: Russian films, books, music, and more.

points_of_interest.name: Elizabeth Center
points_of_interest.description: If you want to purchase cute Asian accessories or dolls, Elizabeth Center (also known as EC, for short), is the right place for you to shop. Once you enter, go down the escalator and all the shops downstairs sell cute Asian merchandise. If you want to take sticker pictures, EC has it too. It's on the first level in the far left corner of the building.

points_of_interest.name: ABC Carpet & Home
points_of_interest.description: A sprawling NYC department store occupying two landmark buildings, it is considered by many to be an iconic institution in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. Its offerings include furniture, rugs, lighting and accessories.

points_of_interest.name: Generation Records
points_of_interest.description: Best place in the city to buy hardcore, metal, industrial, punk, and alternative records.

points_of_interest.name: Saint-Petersburg Trade & Publishing House
points_of_interest.description: Russian books, CDs, DVDs, and more.

points_of_interest.name: Academy Records Annex
points_of_interest.description: Fairly large selection of vinyl records.

points_of_interest.name: Sahadi's
points_of_interest.description: The most famous purveyor of Middle Eastern foodstuffs in New York City. Across the street, there is another store which is open later. If you like Arab food, don't miss a trip to Atlantic Avenue.

points_of_interest.name: Tiffany & Co.
points_of_interest.description: The famous jewellers, scene of Audrey Hepburn's ''Breakfast at Tiffany's''
points_of_interest.hours: M-F 10AM-7PM, Sa 10AM-6PM, Su noon-5PM, closed Memorial Day

points_of_interest.name: Eataly
points_of_interest.description: This is a branch of an Italian shopping center, which styles itself as a place to "savor high quality traditional Italian food products and beverages along with local produce and artisanal products." Many different products are for sale, including not only produce but cheese, wine, olive oil, and sweets, and there are also several places to eat hot food. Anyone who enjoys shopping or window-shopping for food-related products is likely to enjoy walking through. The prices range from average to high.

points_of_interest.name: Chelsea Market
points_of_interest.description: The original Oreo cookie factory is now a block-sized market selling gourmet foods, flowers, and knick-knacks, and offering restaurants, bars, art space and special shows. Has free wireless Internet access throughout and smells like a slice of heaven.

points_of_interest.name: Three Lives & Company
points_of_interest.description: A local independent bookstore, this microscopic yet utterly delightful place is the essence of Greenwich Village, with an extremely knowledgeable and passionate staff.

points_of_interest.name: Earwax Records
points_of_interest.description: This record store has operated at various locations in Williamsburg since 1990.

points_of_interest.name: Blanc & Rouge
points_of_interest.description: A great small wine shop in DUMBO. They have a great selection of Burgundies as well as other wines from all over the world and a very friendly and knowledgeable staff.

points_of_interest.name: Anthropologie
points_of_interest.description: A small store selling boho-chic accessories, home decor, and womenswear.

points_of_interest.name: Kalustyan's
points_of_interest.description: A sensory experience for your nose, and probably the most complete source for Eastern Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and South Asian foodstuffs in Manhattan, though some things cost more than you'd pay at the smaller [https://dualsnatural.com/ Dual's Natural] in the East Village. While you're there, make sure to go upstairs and get some mujadara. Some of the other prepared products are just OK, but the mujadara is great. Eat in or take out. The building itself has some historic significance, as it's where one of the United States' less-remembered presidents, Chester A. Arthur, lived and took the oath of office; this history is commemorated by an unobtrusive plaque outside.

points_of_interest.name: B&H
points_of_interest.description: Perhaps the best camera and photography equipment store in New York, this is the place to go for any of the cameras and camera accessories you might want. The selection is good and the staff is knowledgeable and willing to discuss things with you. It is owned and heavily staffed by Hasidic Jews, so it is closed on Friday nights, Saturdays, and all Jewish holidays except for Hanukkah. B&H provides its holiday closing schedule [http://www.bhphotovideo.com/find/HelpCenter/HoursOfOperation.jsp here].

points_of_interest.name: Warehouse Wines and Spirits
points_of_interest.description: Generally quite inexpensive wines and liquors, good recommendations and fast service.
points_of_interest.hours: Monday-Thursday: 9AM to 8:45PM, Friday-Saturday: 9AM to 9:45PM; Sunday: noon to 6:45PM

points_of_interest.name: Beacon's Closet
points_of_interest.description: A big thrift store focusing on clothes, they buy and sell and have lots of variety for men and women. Also lots of shoes.

points_of_interest.name: Bloomingdale's 59th Street
points_of_interest.description: An enormous department store that is frequented by the glamorous and the masses. A must-visit for any serious shopper, with 9 floors filled to the brim with designer clothes, dresses, handbags, shoes, and tuxedos.
points_of_interest.hours: M 9AM to 9:30PM, Tu 8AM-6PM, Th 8AM-9:30PM, F Sa 10AM-9:30PM, Su 10AM-9PM, closed W

points_of_interest.name: Paragon Sports
points_of_interest.description: This is generally considered one of the better sporting goods stores in Manhattan. It's pretty large and has a lot of equipment you might want for your next trip. It pays to check whether anything is on sale. For example, there are often some good sales on hiking boots. The sales staff is generally helpful and will work with you to help you find what you want. They often recommend items they themselves use, and not the most expensive items.

points_of_interest.name: Purple Passion
points_of_interest.description: An adult store with selections of fetishwear & corsets.

points_of_interest.name: Shoegasm
points_of_interest.description: Fashionable shoes for men and women at affordable prices. The Chelsea location (one of five in Manhattan) boasts a unique aesthetic with antique furniture, Persian rugs, and brick walls.

points_of_interest.name: Rough Trade NYC
points_of_interest.description: The sole American branch of the London-based independent record stores. It is the largest record store in New York. Also features a live music venue, photo booth, and ping-pong table.

points_of_interest.name: Dylan's Candy Bar
points_of_interest.description: An upscale candy store started by Ralph Lauren's daughter, Dylan. Anyone with a sweet tooth must visit.

points_of_interest.name: Buffalo Exchange
points_of_interest.description: Clothing and accessories bought, sold and traded locally with the public. The inventory changes every day and includes designer labels, vintage, jeans, leather, current basics and one-of-a-kind items. They also have brand new items, clothing for both men and women and is more upscale and fashionable than an average thrift shop.

points_of_interest.name: Chang Jiang Supermarket
points_of_interest.description: This is positively the biggest Chinese supermarket in New York. There are several other large Chinese supermarkets in the neighborhood, but Chang Jiang Supermarket is by far the best for most purposes. You want it, they've got it. Chang Jiang is patronized extensively. It has high-quality fresh produce, condiments, meats, poultry, fish and seafood, and prepared goods.

points_of_interest.name: Artists & Fleas
points_of_interest.description: A large indoor market with many different local craft vendors selling jewelry, clothing, art, housewares, and more. Open on Saturday and Sunday.

points_of_interest.name: J.Crew - The Men's Shop
points_of_interest.description: J.Crew features classic men's and women's apparel and a small but quality collection.
points_of_interest.hours: Su noon-6PM, M Th F 10AM-7PM, Tu 10AM-5PM, Sa 10AM-6PM; closed Wednesday

points_of_interest.name: Adorama
points_of_interest.description: One of the country's largest suppliers of cameras, film, and photographic accoutrements of all kinds. Staffed largely by Orthodox Jews, Adorama is closed on Friday nights, Saturdays, and all Jewish holidays except Hanukkah, but packed to the rafters every other day. And they provide very good service.

points_of_interest.name: Hershey's Chocolate World
points_of_interest.description: You are able to purchase all types of chocolate goodies and Hershey-themed products at this store. A few dollars can also get you a personalized message scrolled across their zipper outside on the store's facade. Hershey stores are all over the country but this particular store is the largest Hershey's store in the world. It has three floors of pure chocolate, and Hershey's products.

points_of_interest.name: Macy's
points_of_interest.description: Billing itself as "The World's Largest Store" on the large signs outside, this is the flagship store of the national chain and covers an entire city block. Its holiday window displays are so popular that they usually have a corporate sponsor. One useful tip for visitors is to go to the Macy's guest center on floor 1 1/2 and they will give you a guest card that discounts virtually everything in the store by 11%.

points_of_interest.name: Kinokuniya Bookstore
points_of_interest.description: A Japanese book dealer, carrying a huge selection of Japanese reading material. It also sells a number of books by Japanese authors in English translation. It is also known as a source of excellent Japanese anime and manga, much of which is difficult or impossible to find anywhere else in the United States.

points_of_interest.name: M&M's World New York
points_of_interest.description: You can purchase all types of M&M goodies and M&M-themed trinkets here.

points_of_interest.name: Staten Island Mall
points_of_interest.description: The Staten Island Mall is the largest mall in New York City and the center of retail life in Staten Island, anchored by Macy's and JCPenney. There is also a large food court and a variety of smaller stores. In the vicinity, there are a number of sizable shopping centers.

points_of_interest.name: Midtown Comics
points_of_interest.description: An absolutely gigantic comic book store, one of the largest and most well-known in the country, with two full floors of comics, collectibles, manga, and back issues, as well as a very knowledgeable staff. Signings by giants in the comic book industry are a regular occurrence here and the store also sponsors the annual New York Comic Con held every October. Smaller locations can be found in Midtown East and the Financial District.
points_of_interest.hours: M Tu Th F Sa 11AM-7PM, Su noon- 7PM, W 8AM-7PM

points_of_interest.name: Bricktown Centre At Charleston
points_of_interest.description: Taking up 400,000 square feet, this mall houses a small number of large stores.

points_of_interest.name: Sephora
points_of_interest.description: One-stop shopping for cosmetics.

points_of_interest.name: Hylan Plaza
points_of_interest.description: A smaller shopping center, Hylan Plaza is still home to a number of retail stores alongside numerous mom-and-pop shops. It's located along a line of smaller shopping centers.

points_of_interest.name: Bergdorf Goodman
points_of_interest.description: Very high-end designer clothing, jewelry and accessories store for women, men and kids.

points_of_interest.name: Empire Outlets
points_of_interest.description: Only outlet mall in New York City

points_of_interest.name: Morrell Wine
points_of_interest.description: Perhaps the best wine selection in the city, this is the place to go if you want to find that unusual bottle to take home as a gift. They also ship all over if you want to take home more than you can carry!

points_of_interest.name: Saint George Greenmarket
points_of_interest.address: Hyatt Street and St. Marks Place

points_of_interest.name: Nintendo World Store
points_of_interest.description: more commonly just referred to as the Nintendo Store A two-story specialty store that sells a wide variety of Nintendo merchandise, including videogames, t-shirts, and plushies of your favorite Nintendo characters. The most popular aspect of the store is their Pokecenter which has a wall dedicated to Pokemon videogames, DVDs, action figures and plush dolls. The plush dolls and action figures that are on sale change every week or so, so you need to be quick to find and buy your favorite pokemon’s plush counterpart. The store has a large section devoted to Wiis and 3DS/DS’s that are opened for customers to play and preview videogames before they purchase them. The store also sometimes holds tournaments and video viewings to promote upcoming releases of games.

points_of_interest.name: Brookfield Place
points_of_interest.description: formerly World Financial Center Shopping, dining, events and the Winter Garden all open to the public.

points_of_interest.name: Staten Island Mall Greenmarket
points_of_interest.address: Staten Island Mall, Marsh Avenue & Ring Road (commuter lot behind Macy's)

points_of_interest.name: Disney Store
points_of_interest.description: A 2-level store for Disney merchandise.

points_of_interest.name: Heritage Farm
points_of_interest.description: This market sells products only grown on-site.

points_of_interest.name: The Back Vault
points_of_interest.description: Vintage jewelry shop.

points_of_interest.name: Barnes and Noble
points_of_interest.description: A large Barnes and Noble bookstore in the neighborhood.

points_of_interest.name: Book Culture
points_of_interest.description: Formerly known as Labyrinth Books, Book Culture is a scholarly bookstore, worth browsing for the books on science and the liberal arts. The sale tables on the second floor are full of bargains that will delight any booklover.

points_of_interest.name: Columbia University Bookstore
points_of_interest.description: Run by Barnes and Noble, this is the best place in the neighborhood to pick up travel guides for anywhere as well as Columbia University branded gifts.

points_of_interest.name: Westsider Rare and Used Books
points_of_interest.description: Specializing in used books.

points_of_interest.name: Cosmopolitan Hotel Tribeca
points_of_interest.description: Clean, comfortable rooms with private bath and color television, plus wireless internet at a reasonable price.

points_of_interest.name: The Roxy Hotel Tribeca
points_of_interest.description: Gorgeous, trendy hotel. Not for the light-walleted.

points_of_interest.name: Days Inn by Wyndham Jamaica / JFK Airport
North Brooklyn / 12 Towns YMCA
points_of_interest.description: 97 single-occupancy guest rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Hilton Garden Inn New York/Tribeca
points_of_interest.description: The Garden Inn has a slightly dated chain hotel feel, but a reasonably nice restaurant and a strategic location. Rooms feature the usual conveniences found in midscale hotels, enhanced with a microwave and fridge that could be convenient for self-caterers, who will also find a hotel "pantry" with convenience food items for sale in the lobby.

points_of_interest.name: The Greenwich Hotel
points_of_interest.description: The five-star boutique member of The Leading Hotels of the World takes "olde-worlde" charm to a new level in its rooms, but offers truly pampering service and a number of amenities unexpected for a hotel of only 88 rooms, including a reasonably-sized pool, Japanese spa and quite spacious gym.

points_of_interest.name: Courtyard by Marriott New York JFK Airport
Holiday Inn Express Brooklyn
points_of_interest.description: Opened in 2006, the hotel features complimentary breakfast, wifi access and comfortable furnishings.

points_of_interest.name: Akwaaba Mansion
points_of_interest.description: Akwaaba Mansion Inn Four guest rooms, each uniquely decorated with a cultural theme, private baths (some with Jacuzzis), air conditioning and clock radio/CD player, wireless internet and business center, guest library, TV and game room, personal concierge to arrange tours, restaurant reservations, etc.

points_of_interest.name: Fairfield Inn by Marriott New York JFK Airport
Hotel on Rivington
points_of_interest.description: 21-story glass tower full-service hotel with unobstructed views.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Lower East Side
points_of_interest.description: A fairly standard Holiday Inn except for the Retro diner serving as the hotel's restaurant. This is the hotel located the deepest into the Lower East side of all, and hence it is in a slightly deserted area, facing a parking crater.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Express New York JFK Airport Area
Hotel Indigo Lower East Side
points_of_interest.description: The idea of Intercontinental's Indigo chain is to provide a boutique hotel experience in a chain hotel, but many of the Indigos fail to live up to that. The one in Lower East Side, however, wholly does with a truly unique experience provided by its loft-like spaces and light, airy rooms echoing Scandinvaian designs, wooden flooring and practical designer furniture included. The supertall outlier in a low-rise neighbourhood provides multiple terraces as its slender build tapers off towards the top, one even includes a small pool. The Mr. Purple rooftop bar is an institution, and works of art can be found throughout the hotel. The only letdown may be the rather large room count, approaching 300 - meaning also that only the best rooms get the hotel's signature views.

points_of_interest.name: Soho Grand Hotel
points_of_interest.description: The Soho Grand Hotel is a pet-friendly boutique hotel, featuring 353 guest rooms, ten suites, and two sprawling penthouses.

points_of_interest.name: New York LaGuardia Airport Marriott Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Offers a fitness center, swimming pool, flexible meeting space and complimentary hotel shuttle to and from LaGuardia Airport.

points_of_interest.name: Soldiers', Sailors', Marines', Coast Guard and Airmen's Club
points_of_interest.description: A service member friendly hotel. The hotel is closed to non-military personnel unless accompanied by a service member, veteran, or military retiree.

points_of_interest.name: Vanderbilt YMCA
points_of_interest.description: Walking distance from Grand Central Terminal and near the United Nations.

points_of_interest.name: Best Western Brooklyn-Coney Island Inn
points_of_interest.description: Wi-Fi, free breakfast, free parking.

points_of_interest.name: Roosevelt Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A Pakistani-owned hotel named after the 20th President Theodore Roosevelt and opened in 1924. The hotel has 1,015 rooms including 52 suites. This hotel has been seen in several major motion pictures.

points_of_interest.name: Best Western Plus Brooklyn Bay Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Wi-Fi, free breakfast.

points_of_interest.name: New York Marriott at the Brooklyn Bridge
points_of_interest.description: The hotel’s luxurious accommodations boast a relaxed but modern atmosphere with state-of-the-art amenities.

points_of_interest.name: Ravel Hotel, Trademark Collection by Wyndham
points_of_interest.description: A luxury boutique hotel offering 63 lodging accommodations overlooking Manhattan with 9-ft ceilings, private balcony, and spa-like bathrooms.

points_of_interest.name: Comfort Inn
points_of_interest.description: Free Wi-Fi, free breakfast, fitness center.

points_of_interest.name: 70 Park Avenue Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Nice boutique hotel with good bar, Silverleaf Tavern, which serves a good G&T. Lovely rooms including LCD TV's etc. Some rooms have a view of the Empire State Building.

points_of_interest.name: Sleep Inn Coney Island
points_of_interest.description: Free full breakfast, free WiFi, free daily newspaper, free coffee and free parking (first come, first serve basis).

points_of_interest.name: 1 Hotel Brooklyn Bridge
points_of_interest.description: 1 Hotel Brooklyn Bridge has expansive views of the East River and Manhattan skyline. Designed by local artists using native greenery and reclaimed materials.

points_of_interest.name: Hampton Inn Brooklyn/Downtown
points_of_interest.description: Standard chain hotel, has all the amenities you'd expect and no others. The buffet breakfast is the only thing to write home about, a notch or two better than your typical hotel breakfast.

points_of_interest.name: Fitzpatrick Manhattan Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Irish boutique hotel with a popular on-site Irish restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Grandview Hotel New York
points_of_interest.description: Very inexpensive, with extremely small rooms

points_of_interest.name: Marco LaGuardia Hotel and Suites
points_of_interest.description: Upscale boutique hotel, clean, free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Grand Hyatt New York
points_of_interest.description: Attached to Grand Central Station.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Elysee
points_of_interest.description: This country French hotel offers guests free high speed Wi-fi and complimentary refreshments in the Club room 24 hours a day including breakfast in the mornings and wine and cheese receptions on weeknights.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel 48LEX
points_of_interest.description: A fresh blend of highly personalized concierge service with high-end contemporary art and design.

points_of_interest.name: Washington Square Hotel
points_of_interest.description: This hotel offers art deco styled furnishings and complimentary internet access at the lobby bar and considers itself a haven for writers, artists and visitors.

points_of_interest.name: The Harlem YMCA
points_of_interest.description: Has a Health and Wellness Center and a heated swimming pool.

points_of_interest.name: Kitano
points_of_interest.description: A luxury, four-diamond, Japanese-style hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Library Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Free high speed Wi-fi and complimentary refreshments in the Reading Room 24 hours a day including breakfast in the mornings and wine and cheese receptions in the evenings except for Sunday nights.

points_of_interest.name: Best Western Gregory Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Free high speed internet access. Free continental breakfast. Lobby bar serves drinks 5-10PM daily. Meeting & conference facilities and business services.

points_of_interest.name: Lotte New York Palace
points_of_interest.description: Luxury accommodations, good views, spacious rooms, spa & fitness center, fine dining at the Gilt Restaurant & Bar, meeting and event rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Days Inn by Wyndham Brooklyn
points_of_interest.description: Free parking, breakfast, and Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Courtyard by Marriott New York Manhattan/Upper East Side
points_of_interest.description: Free high-speed Internet & large work desk in each room, along with an exercise room open 24/7 with a wide range of equipment and services for everyone. A steam room is also present. The hotel is in walking distance of many close-by vibrant destinations along with quaint spots for any tourist.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel 17
points_of_interest.description: Slightly north of East Village, a long stay hotel. Minimum stay 30 nights.

points_of_interest.name: Greenpoint YMCA
points_of_interest.description: Economy and deluxe rooms daily, weekly and monthly rates; higher prices during peak period. $99 for a double room.

points_of_interest.name: Insignia Hotel, Ascend Hotel Collection
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel in Sunset Park's Chinatown.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Wales
points_of_interest.description: European style boutique hotel with numerous accommodations, free WiFi, paid parking, and elegant rooms with careful designs even for the cheapest traveler. Hotel Wales also prides itself on being an LGBTQ+ friendly hotel and has historically contributed to the movement.

points_of_interest.name: NY Moore Hostel
points_of_interest.description: Located in East Williamsburg and covered with street art.

points_of_interest.name: Park House Hotel Brooklyn
points_of_interest.description: "Kosher Suite Hotel" in Borough Park. A complimentary breakfast buffet is offered daily except Saturdays and Jewish Holidays.

points_of_interest.name: The Carlyle, A Rosewood Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A luxury boutique hotel, the Carlyle offers rooms and suites for extended stays, and luxury apartments and rentals. Art and music are historical landmarks of this hotel, with many murals and historic musical performances taking place at this elegant hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Americana Inn
points_of_interest.description: Single, double, and triple-bed accommodations.

points_of_interest.name: The William Vale
points_of_interest.description: This luxury hotel is the tallest in Williamsburg.

points_of_interest.name: Wyndham Garden Brooklyn Sunset Park
points_of_interest.description: This pet-friendly Sunset Park hotel offers free Wi-Fi.

points_of_interest.name: Best Western Bowery Hanbee
points_of_interest.description: A fairly typical Best Western, with Wi-Fi and complimentary breakfast, in a good location.

points_of_interest.name: Waldorf Astoria New York
points_of_interest.description: Another famous luxury hotel that is among the more notable in New York, with a long history in a lavish Art Deco building that has housed many a celebrity. Perhaps one of the most famous guests was President Franklin Roosevelt, and a secret platform that is believed to have been used by Roosevelt to travel directly from the train to his hotel room so he could hide his paralysis from the public survives under the hotel. The traincar that Roosevelt is believed to have used is parked on the platform. Sadly, neither the secret platform nor the traincar are open to public.

points_of_interest.name: The Sherry-Netherland
points_of_interest.description: Full concierge assistance, elevator attendants, and beautifully furnished rooms are all present at this fairly small but decadent hotel that has beautiful views and is within walking distance of both many bustling destinations along with Central Park. Amazing for visitors who have a bit more cash to spend.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Deauville
points_of_interest.description: Good price for the location. Family-run business, with friendly staff.

points_of_interest.name: McCarren Hotel
points_of_interest.description: On McCarren Park.

points_of_interest.name: The Bowery Grand Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Rock bottom accommodation. Single rooms are smaller than the size of a double bed, and the place is not exactly sparkling. Rooms have no roof, so there is no privacy, and you can hear everyone else packed in inches away from you. Wifi is slow. But you can't beat the price.

points_of_interest.name: Westgate New York City
points_of_interest.description: formerly Hilton New York Grand Central The former Hilton, an iconic landmark, neo-gothic hotel, only a few blocks from Times Square and Grand Central Station.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel 31
points_of_interest.description: 24-hour concierge, daily maid service, cable TV, telephone and helpful multilingual staff.

points_of_interest.name: The Bowery House
points_of_interest.description: Shared bathrooms, roof "garden", and bike rental.

points_of_interest.name: The MAve Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Comfortable, stylish place. This space was built in 1902 but still feels modern with vibrant murals on the walls and sleek bamboo floors. Offers a complimentary breakfast. Occasionally, Groupon has deals for this hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Chelsea International Hostel
points_of_interest.description: Small and clean. Internet access, 24-hour reception. All guests must show a passport when checking in, including U.S. citizens.

points_of_interest.name: Wythe Hotel
points_of_interest.description: An industrial-chic hotel with a trendy roof bar.

points_of_interest.name: Comfort Inn Lower East Side
points_of_interest.description: If New York hotel prices have made you resort to sleeping under a bridge, this may as well be your choice (pardon the pun), as it consistently ranks as one of the lowest-priced decent hotels in the city, and is also almost literally located under the Manhattan Bridge. The location is a bit remote and not quite charming, but the hotel does not lack anything in its limited-service standards, although it is on the small side with only 43 rooms and most facilities sized to match.

points_of_interest.name: BKLYN House
points_of_interest.description: 2.5 star hotel

points_of_interest.name: Comfort Inn Manhattan Bridge
points_of_interest.description: Standard chain hotel, with Wi-Fi, decent breakfast, and pets allowed for a fee. Reviewers often note friendly service.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Giraffe
points_of_interest.description: Free high speed Wi-fi and complimentary refreshments in the Grande Lobby 24 hours a day including breakfast in the mornings and wine and cheese receptions in the evenings except for Sunday nights.

points_of_interest.name: Four Points by Sheraton Manhattan Chelsea
Sohotel
points_of_interest.description: Billing itself as "the oldest running hotel" in the city (the building has been housing a hotel for over a hundred years), the hotel is in an old building with rooms with hardwood floors and exposed brick walls, giving it a pretty unique feel. Lots of in-room amenities, although reviewers have noted issues with noise and cold showers.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Chandler
points_of_interest.description: Deluxe rooms on the edge of Koreatown. In-room high-speed internet. Health club, sauna and day spa.

points_of_interest.name: GEM Hotel - Chelsea
points_of_interest.description: The rooms are tiny, though bright and in good condition.

points_of_interest.name: The Bowery Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Fabulously dark and moody, this newish old-school hotel is cool and charming in a low-key way. Rooms are spacious with plenty of light and dark hardwood floors, and the more expensive ones come with fantastic bathtubs. The bar and lobby are popular hangouts.

points_of_interest.name: Inn at Irving Place
points_of_interest.description: Near Gramercy Park, the inn, built in 1834, consists of two landmark townhouses.

points_of_interest.name: Eventi Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A boutique hotel near Penn Station.

points_of_interest.name: The Standard, East Village
points_of_interest.description: Pet-friendly boutique hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Avalon Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel with roomy suites, close to the Empire State Building.

points_of_interest.name: Hilton Garden Inn New York/Chelsea
points_of_interest.description: A comfortable hotel with moderately sized rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Comfort Inn Staten Island
points_of_interest.description: Straightforward hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Metro
points_of_interest.description: Complimentary continental breakfast or afternoon snack in the Metro Grill restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: Dream Downtown - Chelsea
points_of_interest.description: With a tree-shaded lobby, metallic lizard banquettes, a glass-bottomed pool, and nightly DJs it is no wonder this place is so pricey. This ‘dream-like’ building has classic furnishing elements such as Turkish rugs and white Beverly sofas complemented with futuristic touches like shiny steel baths. Dream Downtown has created a beach club vibe with suites that lead onto the pool area, sandy patches, and outdoor cabanas. The hotel’s Ph-D Rooftop Lounge will serve up your favorite cocktails underneath their Venini glass chandeliers.

points_of_interest.name: Andaz Wall Street, A Hyatt Hotel
points_of_interest.description: The only hotel on Wall Street featuring 253 rooms that begin at a very large 345 sq ft (32 m²). All rooms come with free internet, free minibar (except alcohol), free gym access, and free light refreshments in the lobby.

points_of_interest.name: Hilton Garden Inn New York/Staten Island
Hampton Inn Manhattan 35th Street/Empire State Building
points_of_interest.description: A business-style hotel with modern and clean rooms.

points_of_interest.name: The Standard, High Line Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A hip boutique hotel featuring business and event space, an on-site restaurant, bar and beer garden.

points_of_interest.name: Conrad New York
points_of_interest.description: Brand new all-suite luxury hotel overlooking the Hudson River in Battery Park City, located next to the World Financial Center and minutes from Wall St, Statue of Liberty and 9/11 Memorial.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Express Staten Island West
Bryant Park Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Distinctive black brick and gold trim building. Amenities include deep soaking tubs, cashmere blankets, Pipino toiletries, Tibetan rugs in rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Hyatt House New York/Chelsea
points_of_interest.description: Offers a choice of residential-like suites or studio hotel rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Eurostars Wall Street
points_of_interest.description: A small boutique luxury hotel a block north of Wall Street.

points_of_interest.name: Holiday Inn Wall Street
points_of_interest.description: A boutique hotel two blocks from Wall Street, one block from the New York Stock Exchange, and across the street from the Federal Reserve Bank. Consists of 113 rooms with free wireless internet, contains a fitness center, and is pet friendly.

points_of_interest.name: Millenium Hilton
points_of_interest.description: 55-Story hotel located in the heart of the Financial District, next to the 9/11 Memorial and 11 different subway lines, featuring a heated indoor pool and 569 guest rooms and suites with skyline views.

points_of_interest.name: Casablanca Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel just off Times Square. High-speed Wi-fi and complimentary refreshments in Rick's Cafe 24 hours a day including breakfast in the mornings and wine and cheese receptions in the evenings except for Sunday nights.

points_of_interest.name: New York Marriott Downtown
points_of_interest.description: Good views and nice rooms.

points_of_interest.name: Residence Inn by Marriott World Trade Center
points_of_interest.description: 242 rooms with kitchenettes and suites, 240sq.ft. to 600sq.ft with 10' ceiling height. All rates include a full hot American breakfast buffet daily, free basic wi-fi and fitness center.

points_of_interest.name: Salisbury Hotel
points_of_interest.description: King and double-bed rooms. Standard rooms are much larger than typical as the hotel was designed as a suite hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Sanctuary Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A Times Square-area hotel offering modern accommodations.

points_of_interest.name: DoubleTree by Hilton New York Downtown
points_of_interest.description: Standard business hotel close to ferry terminal and several subway stations. There's only three elevators for more than forty floors of rooms, so may not be a first choice if you're going to be arriving and leaving in peak hours.

points_of_interest.name: Truss Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Boutique hotel built in 2022, featuring a rooftop garden terrace with panoramic views of Hudson Yards.

points_of_interest.name: Belvedere Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Art Deco hotel.

points_of_interest.name: Crowne Plaza Times Square
points_of_interest.description: Upscale hotel with 770 guest rooms, Manhattan's largest indoor lap pool, Brasserie 1605 Restaurant, meeting facilities.

points_of_interest.name: Hilton New York Midtown
points_of_interest.description: A massive, amenity-laden hotel tower.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Edison
points_of_interest.description: Art Deco hotel built in 1931, steps from Times Square, known for its mock-Art Deco murals on the ground floor.

points_of_interest.name: Homewood Suites by Hilton Midtown Manhattan
points_of_interest.description: Extended stay NYC hotel. Complimentary Wi-Fi and wired Internet access. Free hot full breakfast each morning and evening dinner and drinks, Monday through Thursday.

points_of_interest.name: Manhattan Club
points_of_interest.description: Suites and first class services and amenities. Each suite features appliances, plush fabrics and elegant furnishings with marble baths. Timeshares available.

points_of_interest.name: The Millennium Broadway Hotel Times Square
points_of_interest.description: Hotel near Broadway that features spacious rooms and suites, a conference center, wedding reception locations, event venues and an on-site restaurant.

points_of_interest.name: New York Marriott Marquis Times Square
points_of_interest.description: Gigantic in size with updated hotel rooms, high-speed elevators and six hotel restaurants and lounges. It is known for its revolving bar and the view from its clear-sided elevators.

points_of_interest.name: Park Central Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Right next to Carnegie Hall and close to the Theater District. While its renovations have significantly improved this hotel, it is, at best, a four-star hotel and clearly not one of New York's luxury hotels.

points_of_interest.name: Renaissance New York Hotel Times Square
Staybridge Suites Times Square
points_of_interest.description: An extended stay hotel offering pet friendly lodging accommodations and suites with fully equipped kitchens.

points_of_interest.name: West 57th Street by Hilton Club
points_of_interest.description: Studios, one- and two- bedrooms suites with floor to ceiling views of New York City.

points_of_interest.name: Westin New York at Times Square
Baccarat Hotel New York
points_of_interest.description: An upscale hotel offering 114 rooms and suites. The hotel has many interesting features, including a mica-covered vaulted ceiling, silver-leafed wood paneling, pleated-silk walls, marble, and Baccarat crystal elements throughout.

points_of_interest.name: Peninsula Hotel New York
points_of_interest.description: Has a rooftop bar.

points_of_interest.name: Plaza Hotel
points_of_interest.description: Perhaps the most famous of New York's luxury hotels, the Plaza is an attraction in and of itself, having been used as a backdrop in numerous movies and TV shows and serving as the meeting place for many celebrities and politicians. The Plaza is also famous as a place to go for afternoon tea or cocktails, and of course you will pay dearly for that.

points_of_interest.name: 1 Hotel Central Park
points_of_interest.description: Featuring natural light, organic and reclaimed materials. Farm-fresh meal at the restaurant, menu created by Chez Panisse alum, Jonathan Waxman,

points_of_interest.name: Hostelling International New York
points_of_interest.description: HI-New York is the largest hostel in North America. Close to the subway, with internet, 24-hour reception, laundry, a lounge area, a small cafe, and no curfew. The building is old, but in decent shape and pretty clean.

points_of_interest.name: Hotel Newton
points_of_interest.description: Budget hotel with amenities like microwave ovens, mini refrigerators and flat screen televisions.

points_of_interest.name: Jazz On The Park Hostel
points_of_interest.description: On-site cafe, 24 hour internet and reception, ATM, laundry, no curfew.

points_of_interest.name: West Side YMCA
points_of_interest.description: Rates are a bit more than your average youth hostel but still inexpensive for Manhattan.

points_of_interest.name: Arthouse Hotel New York City
points_of_interest.description: The rooms are larger than in most Manhattan hotels, with a modern design.

points_of_interest.name: Central Park Inn
points_of_interest.description: Studio apartments; extended stay.

points_of_interest.name: La Quinta New York City Central Park West
points_of_interest.description: Free high-speed internet, complimentary breakfast, and an exercise room.

points_of_interest.name: Union Theological Seminary
points_of_interest.description: Well appointed rooms are set around a beautiful cloister.

points_of_interest.name: Lucerne Hotel
points_of_interest.description: A restored upscale boutique hotel that has been recognized as a landmark building.

points_of_interest.name: Mandarin Oriental Hotel
points_of_interest.description: The hotel has a spa, upscale dining at MO Lounge, amazing views, and a fitness center on the premises.

points_of_interest.name: Trump International Hotel Towers
points_of_interest.description: An elegant 52-story hotel designed by noted architects Philip Johnson and Costas Kondylis.

points_of_interest.name: The Wallace
points_of_interest.description: A spacious apartment-like hotel with kitchenettes and upscale amenities. The hotel has a lobby with fireplace, library/lounge and soft couches, computer room and exercise facility.

pois.name: The Boathouse
pois.description: Held in the Loeb Boathouse on the Lake, the Boathouse includes a sit-down restaurant with tables overlooking the lake, a sit-down bar area outside, and an express cafe with counter service for quick takeout and eat-in food.
pois.address: on Park Drive North on The Lake
pois.hours: Cafe: daily 8AM–8PM (winter 8AM-4:30PM). Outdoor bar: April–November daily 11AM-11PM (weather permitting). Restaurant: lunch M-F noon-4PM; brunch Sa Su 9:30AM-4PM; dinner April–November M-F 5:30PM-9:30PM, Sa Su 6PM-9:30PM

pois.name: Bethesda Terrace and Fountain
pois.description: Bethesda Terrace and Fountain are iconic architectural features in Central Park, offering stunning views of the Lake's southern shore. The centerpiece is the Angel of the Waters statue, surrounded by a beautiful fountain. The two-level terrace is connected by grand staircases and offers a seamless path to the Central Park Mall and Naumburg Bandshell. Crafted from New Brunswick sandstone with granite accents, the terrace features intricate stonework and herringbone-patterned brick paving. This historic landmark is a must-visit for its architectural beauty and picturesque surroundings, making it a perfect spot to relax and take in the park's natural charm.

pois.name: Central Park Zoo
pois.description: Small and gem-like, New York's "oldest, newest zoo" opened in its current guise in 1988, although animals in various zoo incarnations have resided here since the 1860s. This zoo is fairly small and doesn't have as many large animals as you might expect, but this zoo does include sea lions, penguins, polar bears, monkeys, red pandas, and exotic birds in pleasant exhibits. Next door is a children's zoo, covered in the cost of admission, which has a barnyard animals you can pet, a duck pond, and lots of play areas for kids.
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Daily 10AM-4:30PM, Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa-Su, holidays 10AM-5:30PM

pois.name: Friedsman Carousel
pois.description: A vintage carousel built in 1908 and situated on this spot since the 1950s, it's the fourth carousel to inhabit this location and is beautifully painted.
pois.hours: Apr-Oct: Daily 10AM-6PM (weather permitting); Nov-Mar: hours vary, check ahead

pois.name: Museum of the City of New York
pois.description: Rather large, interesting museum with all kinds of documentation of events in the 400-year history of this city and delightful artifacts of life in earlier periods, such as the extensive collection of 19th-century dollhouses complete with miniature furniture.

pois.name: American Museum of Natural History
pois.description: Holding a remarkably large collection, each of the 5 floors of this massive building has expansive and well-designed exhibits devoted to astronomy, biology, geology, anthropology, climatology, and paleontology. You will want to allow a full day if you hope to see the entirety of the museum. Some of the highlights are the '''Rose Center for Earth and Space''' on the northeast corner of the building, which contains a seven-story glass cube holding the Hayden Planetarium, a huge sphere suspended above the exhibit halls below and holding a "cosmic pathway" exhibit; the numerous '''habitat diorama''' halls on the first, second and third floors, with recreations of African, Asian, North American, and ocean plants and animals, including a full-size model of a Blue Whale suspended above the Ocean Life Hall; a '''Hall of Minerals and Gems''', which contains many rare and beautiful specimens, including the largest star sapphire in the world and a chunk of a massive meteorite; extensive '''anthropology halls''' on the first, second, and third floors, with exhibits devoted to people of Asia, Africa, Central America, the Pacific, and Native Americans; and the '''natural history halls''' on the fourth floor, with one of the largest collections of dinosaur skeletons in the world.
pois.address: Central Park West between 77th and 81st Streets (entire block)

pois.name: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum
pois.description: Probably the most famous of the Guggenheim foundations (others found in Bilbao and Venice), which hold avant-garde modern art by artists such as Kandinsky and Mondrian, the New York branch is housed in a unique and famous building designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and rendered in a rounded, organic form and completed in 1959. Be sure to take the elevator to the top floor, then follow the spiral viewing floors downwards to the street level. One of eight buildings by Wright to be listed as a world heritage site.

pois.name: Strawberry Fields
pois.description: So named in 1981 in memory of John Lennon, the former Beatle, who was murdered close by outside his home in the Dakota building. Lennon's widow Yoko Ono, who still lives in the Dakota, subsequently donated $1 million to upgrade the area with hundreds of tree and flower species, including strawberries. The area serves as a Garden of Peace and includes a memorial floor mosaic (donated by the Italian city of Naples) that says simply "Imagine", referring to the title of one of Lennon's evocative songs.

pois.name: Metropolitan Museum of Art
pois.description: The Met One of the world's largest and most important museums of art and world culture, you'll have to devote several hours; nay, an entire ''day'' (if not more!), if you want to do this place justice. This massive neo-Gothic building, originally opened in 1872 and with numerous expansions added on over time, holds literally hundreds of rooms on its two floors, containing thousands of art pieces from across human history and around the world, covering virtually every field of art in existence, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Along with the numerous permanent exhibit halls mentioned below are several changing exhibit halls.

pois.name: Belvedere Castle
pois.description: Sitting on Vista Rock, one of the highest points in the park, the castle provides excellent views of Central Park, particularly to the north. It is a popular spot for photography and contains a visitor center and a nature conservatory. Just below the castle to the north is '''Turtle Pond''', a small, swamp-like pond holding various fish, frogs, insects, and birds.

pois.name: The Lake
pois.description: The lake is a fine setting for a serene afternoon in the park. Rental boats are available from the '''Loeb Boathouse''' (on the eastern side of the lake) for a ride on the water. The '''Bow Bridge''', a Central Park landmark, spans the middle of the lake.
pois.address: 72 Terrace Drive, New York, New York 10023, United States

pois.name: The Reservoir
pois.description: Constructed between 1858 and 1862, the Reservoir is a vast urban lake that covers 106 acres of Central Park and is the largest body of water within Manhattan. Renamed the "Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir" in 1994, the Reservoir is probably best known for the 1.58 mile track that runs around its edge and which is a favorite for joggers, who can both run and enjoy the spectacular views of the city skyline.
pois.address: 110 97th Street Transverse, New York, New York 10025, United States

pois.name: Great Hill
pois.description: One of the highest points in the park, the Great Hill is a hilltop meadow surrounded by stately elm trees and serves as an excellent place to picnic.

pois.name: Ginny's Supper Club
pois.description: This is the upscale (and pricey) option for live jazz and other music in Harlem, with a beautiful, classy space, room for dancing, and fine dining (think soul food steakhouse with craft cocktails). Sundays see the gospel brunch, for which reservations are a must. Check the calendar for who's playing and dress to impress.

pois.name: Times Square
pois.description: A place filled with video screens, LED signs, and flashing lights; a world wonder or a tourist nightmare depending on your perspective, the "new" Times Square is a family-friendly theme park of themed restaurants, theaters and hotels, as well as a developing business district. The lights and signs can be viewed anytime, but the most enchanting experience comes when one visits Times Square at night, as all the signs and screens are ablaze with color. Times Square is also well known for its famous New Year's Eve ball drop. Those looking for the seedy Times Square of years past will find it around the Port Authority Bus Terminal, and on Eighth Avenue to the west.
pois.address: Broadway and 7th Avenue, stretching from 42nd to 48th Streets

pois.name: Washington Square Park
pois.description: The park and its famous arch are located in the heart of the Village. Though located in the middle of an affluent neighborhood, the park attracts a hodgepodge of people. During the warmer months of the school term, the park is a favourite hangout spot for students from nearby NYU. Part of the charm of the park is the view of the buildings across the street. All these buildings are now owned by NYU, and though there has been some controversial construction in the early 2010s, most of the stately 19th-century dwellings pictured in the classic movie ''The Heiress'' (based on Henry James' novel, ''Washington Square'') are still there for you to enjoy looking at.
pois.address: 49-57 Washington Square South, New York, New York 10003, United States

pois.name: Old Stone House
pois.description: Vechte-Cortelyou House 1930s replica of a Dutch colonial farmhouse that had been constructed on the site in 1699; the original structure was buried under landfill during the regrading of the Park Slope neighborhood in the early 1900s. Features an exhibit on ''the Battle of Brooklyn'', the first and largest battle of the American Revolution.

pois.name: Wall Street
pois.description: The historic heart of the Financial District and the home of the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street is a metonym for American big business, stock trading and the entire financial industry, although most New York financial firms are no longer headquartered on the street itself, but housed nearby in new offices, and some have moved to Jersey City. A narrow street running downhill from Broadway to the East River, Wall Street was named for the wall that was built here in 1652 to keep Manhattan's indigenous peoples out of the growing Dutch settlement. The wall was demolished by the British in 1699. By the late 18th century, traders and speculators would gather under a buttonwood tree at the foot of Wall Street to trade informally - this was the origin of the New York Stock Exchange that was established in 1817.
pois.address: 52 William Street, New York, New York 10005, United States

pois.name: Central Park Zoo
pois.description: Small and gem-like, New York's "oldest, newest zoo" opened in its current guise in 1988, although animals in various zoo incarnations have resided here since the 1860s. This zoo is fairly small and doesn't have as many large animals as you might expect, but this zoo does include sea lions, penguins, polar bears, monkeys, red pandas, and exotic birds in pleasant exhibits. Next door is a children's zoo, covered in the cost of admission, which has a barnyard animals you can pet, a duck pond, and lots of play areas for kids.
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Daily 10AM-4:30PM, Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa-Su, holidays 10AM-5:30PM

pois.name: Hispanic Society of America
pois.description: The Hispanic Society of America is a museum and library dedicated to the arts and cultures of Spain, Portugal, and their former colonies. Founded in 1904 by philanthropist Archer M. Huntington, it is housed in a stunning 1908 Beaux Arts building in Manhattan's Washington Heights. The complex, a National Historic Landmark since 2012, features sculptures by Anna Hyatt Huntington and Berthold Nebel. In 2021, the museum expanded into an adjacent building, offering even more space to explore the rich cultural heritage of the Hispanic world. A must-visit for art and history enthusiasts.
pois.hours: The East Building Gallery is open Th-Su, noon-6PM for special exhibitions on a rotating basis and the Main Building is closed for renovations, as of January, 2022

pois.name: Grand Army Plaza
pois.description: A public square at the southeast corner of the park which marks one of the primary entrances to Central Park. The square is named for the Union Army of the Civil War and sports a gilded bronze statue of Union General William Sherman and the Pulitzer Fountain, which is crowned with a bronze figure of Pomona, the Roman goddess of fruit.

pois.name: American Museum of Natural History
pois.description: Holding a remarkably large collection, each of the 5 floors of this massive building has expansive and well-designed exhibits devoted to astronomy, biology, geology, anthropology, climatology, and paleontology. You will want to allow a full day if you hope to see the entirety of the museum. Some of the highlights are the '''Rose Center for Earth and Space''' on the northeast corner of the building, which contains a seven-story glass cube holding the Hayden Planetarium, a huge sphere suspended above the exhibit halls below and holding a "cosmic pathway" exhibit; the numerous '''habitat diorama''' halls on the first, second and third floors, with recreations of African, Asian, North American, and ocean plants and animals, including a full-size model of a Blue Whale suspended above the Ocean Life Hall; a '''Hall of Minerals and Gems''', which contains many rare and beautiful specimens, including the largest star sapphire in the world and a chunk of a massive meteorite; extensive '''anthropology halls''' on the first, second, and third floors, with exhibits devoted to people of Asia, Africa, Central America, the Pacific, and Native Americans; and the '''natural history halls''' on the fourth floor, with one of the largest collections of dinosaur skeletons in the world.
pois.address: Central Park West between 77th and 81st Streets (entire block)

pois.name: Strawberry Fields
pois.description: So named in 1981 in memory of John Lennon, the former Beatle, who was murdered close by outside his home in the Dakota building. Lennon's widow Yoko Ono, who still lives in the Dakota, subsequently donated $1 million to upgrade the area with hundreds of tree and flower species, including strawberries. The area serves as a Garden of Peace and includes a memorial floor mosaic (donated by the Italian city of Naples) that says simply "Imagine", referring to the title of one of Lennon's evocative songs.

pois.name: Bowling Green
pois.description: A small park at the foot of Broadway which is the oldest public park in the city and is the site of the ''Charging Bull'' sculpture created after the 1987 stock market crash. Bowling Green is also the origin point for the Broadway ticker-tape parades; if you walk up Broadway, you can view plaques in the sidewalk honoring the people or events celebrated in these parades.
pois.address: 5 Beaver Street, New York, New York 10004, United States

pois.name: Metropolitan Museum of Art
pois.description: The Met One of the world's largest and most important museums of art and world culture, you'll have to devote several hours; nay, an entire ''day'' (if not more!), if you want to do this place justice. This massive neo-Gothic building, originally opened in 1872 and with numerous expansions added on over time, holds literally hundreds of rooms on its two floors, containing thousands of art pieces from across human history and around the world, covering virtually every field of art in existence, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Along with the numerous permanent exhibit halls mentioned below are several changing exhibit halls.

pois.name: National September 11 Memorial & Museum
pois.description: World Trade Center site - note that the term 'Ground Zero' is never used by New Yorkers On the site of the former World Trade Center towers, the memorial consists of two enormous waterfalls and reflecting pools set within the footprints of the twin towers, lined with bronze panels with the names of the nearly 3,000 victims of that fateful day inscribed. The surrounding plaza holds a grove of trees. The museum, which sits underground right next to the memorial, contains exhibits which explain the events of 9/11 and their aftermath, with remnants of the original towers and artifacts from that day. If you see a white rose on one of the names, it's because today is that victim's birthday.
pois.hours: Memorial: 7:30AM-9PM daily; museum: Su-Th 9AM-8PM, F Sa 9AM-8PM, last museum entry 2 hours before closing

pois.name: High Line Park
pois.description: Built on a defunct elevated railway that runs 30 feet above the streets, the re-purposing of the rail line as a park has made it the focus of major development in the neighborhood. There are plenty of plantings and art installations along the park as it winds its way between (and through!) buildings, and walking the stretch offers some pretty unique views over the streets of Manhattan. No dogs or bicycles. There are restrooms at Gansevoort St. (the southern terminus), 16th St, and 30th St.
pois.address: Runs mostly along 10th Avenue from 34th Street south to Gansevoort Street in the Meatpacking District, with access points at Gansevoort, 14th, 16th, 17th, 20th, 23rd, 26th, 28th, 30th, and 34th Streets
pois.hours: Open daily Apr–May, Oct–Nov: 7AM–10PM; June–Sept: 7AM–11PM; Dec–Mar: 7AM–7PM

pois.name: Statue of Liberty view
pois.description: Red Hook is the only place in New York where you can get a frontal view of the Statue of Liberty from land.
pois.address: 202 Coffey Street, Brooklyn, New York 11231, United States

pois.name: Central Park Zoo
pois.description: Small and gem-like, New York's "oldest, newest zoo" opened in its current guise in 1988, although animals in various zoo incarnations have resided here since the 1860s. This zoo is fairly small and doesn't have as many large animals as you might expect, but this zoo does include sea lions, penguins, polar bears, monkeys, red pandas, and exotic birds in pleasant exhibits. Next door is a children's zoo, covered in the cost of admission, which has a barnyard animals you can pet, a duck pond, and lots of play areas for kids.
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Daily 10AM-4:30PM, Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa-Su, holidays 10AM-5:30PM

pois.name: Unisphere
pois.description: The Unisphere is an iconic symbol of Queens, standing 140 feet tall in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. This stunning globe is surrounded by a beautiful fountain, creating a striking visual display. Originally built for the 1964 World's Fair, the Unisphere has become a beloved landmark, representing global unity and the park's rich history as the site of two World's Fairs (1939 and 1964). Its grandeur and historical significance make it a must-see attraction for visitors to the area.
pois.address: Avenue of Africa, Corona, New York 11368, United States

pois.name: Grand Army Plaza
pois.description: A public square at the southeast corner of the park which marks one of the primary entrances to Central Park. The square is named for the Union Army of the Civil War and sports a gilded bronze statue of Union General William Sherman and the Pulitzer Fountain, which is crowned with a bronze figure of Pomona, the Roman goddess of fruit.

pois.name: Gantry Plaza State Park
pois.description: Gantry Plaza State Park, located on the East River in Long Island City, Queens, is a 12-acre green space that blends industrial history with modern beauty. Once a bustling dockyard and manufacturing hub, the park now features remnants of its past, including iconic gantries that once transferred railcars between Queens and Manhattan. Stroll along the riverfront, enjoy stunning views of the Manhattan skyline, and explore the park's unique blend of history and natural scenery. It’s a peaceful retreat in the heart of the city, perfect for both history buffs and those seeking a relaxing escape.
pois.address: 47-40 Center Boulevard, Long Island City, New York 11109, United States

pois.name: Strawberry Fields
pois.description: So named in 1981 in memory of John Lennon, the former Beatle, who was murdered close by outside his home in the Dakota building. Lennon's widow Yoko Ono, who still lives in the Dakota, subsequently donated $1 million to upgrade the area with hundreds of tree and flower species, including strawberries. The area serves as a Garden of Peace and includes a memorial floor mosaic (donated by the Italian city of Naples) that says simply "Imagine", referring to the title of one of Lennon's evocative songs.

pois.name: One World Trade Center
pois.description: The One World Trade Center skyscraper rises 1,776 feet above the street and is the tallest building in the United States (and for that matter, the Western Hemisphere). Despite its colossal size, its simple design allows it to blend remarkably well into the Lower Manhattan skyline. An observation deck on the top floors offers 360-degree views of the city.
pois.hours: Daily 9AM-8PM, open daily until midnight in the summer months; last ticket sold 45 min prior to close

pois.name: Brooklyn Bridge
pois.description: From its intersection with Park Row (just east of City Hall) you can walk (takes about 20-30 minutes each way), bike, or drive across the historic and iconic bridge to Brooklyn. The view from the bridge is quite lovely, with excellent views of Lower Manhattan and Downtown Brooklyn and good views of Midtown and the New York Harbor in the distance.
pois.address: Brooklyn Bridge, Manhattan, New York 10273, United States

pois.name: The Reservoir
pois.description: Constructed between 1858 and 1862, the Reservoir is a vast urban lake that covers 106 acres of Central Park and is the largest body of water within Manhattan. Renamed the "Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir" in 1994, the Reservoir is probably best known for the 1.58 mile track that runs around its edge and which is a favorite for joggers, who can both run and enjoy the spectacular views of the city skyline.
pois.address: 110 97th Street Transverse, New York, New York 10025, United States

pois.name: Chatham Square
pois.description: At this square at the confluence of several major streets, there is a memorial archway to Chinese-Americans who died in World War II which has some interesting calligraphy. Also in the square is a statue of Lin Zexu, a Chinese scholar who opposed the opium trade in the 19th century.
pois.address: 4 Chatham Square, New York, New York 10038, United States

pois.name: Museum of Chinese in the Americas
pois.description: Exhibits on the history and culture of Chinese-Americans.

pois.name: Museum at Eldridge Street
pois.description: The museum, a non-sectarian cultural organization based in the restored 1887 National Historic Landmark Eldridge Street Synagogue, presents the culture, history and traditions of the great wave of Jewish immigrants to the Lower East Side drawing parallels with the diverse cultural communities that have settled in America. The museum offers guided tours of the synagogue, new exhibits and programs -- including concerts, neighborhood walking tours and film screenings.

pois.name: Italian American Museum
pois.description: The Italian American Museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the history and culture of Italian Americans. Located in the heart of the city, this museum celebrates the rich heritage and contributions of Italian Americans, from their migration journeys to their lasting impact on society. Explore exhibits that highlight the waves of immigration, the challenges faced by early settlers, and the vibrant cultural traditions that have shaped American society. Discover how Italian Americans have influenced art, cuisine, and more, making this a must-visit destination for anyone interested in cultural history and the Italian American experience.
pois.hours: Opening in its new home in Oct 2024; previously at 155 Mulberry

pois.name: Aji Ichiban
pois.description: Hong Kong snack shop, very popular with locals and tourists alike. The staff are friendly and give samples.

pois.name: The Ear Inn
pois.description: Located on the ground floor of the James Brown House, the Ear Inn is one of the oldest bars in New York.

pois.name: Stonewall Inn
pois.description: A veritable icon of the worldwide gay community, not just New York's. While it's not the original incarnation of the bar that was the site of the Stonewall riots of 1969 (the building has gone through several uses since then), the current incarnation pays homage to the old and has regained its prominence as a meeting place in the LGBT community. You must be 21 and a proper ID is required. 2-drink minimum.

pois.name: Lot 45
pois.description: A large lounge with a quasi-outdoor area and some games like ping-pong.

pois.name: Holiday Cocktail Lounge
pois.description: Old-timers to the neighborhood may remember this as a no-frills bar that had booths with torn upholstery and was presided over by a friendly old Ukrainian bartender/owner. After he died, the bar remained shut and vacant for several years. The new owners had it renovated and somewhat redesigned, but it still has the feel of an old-time room. To afford today's expensive rents and follow the new trends, they now specialize in excellent cocktails and also have a menu of small plates. However, one thing hasn't changed: The bartenders are still personable.

pois.name: KGB Bar
pois.description: A hard-drinking literary bar.

pois.name: The Irish Pub
pois.description: Great place to drink after a long day at work.

pois.name: House of Yes
pois.description: This eclectic club hosts a variety of events from dance parties to burlesque.

pois.name: Schimanski
pois.description: Another large electronic dance music club.

pois.name: King Manor Museum
pois.description: King Manor Museum, located in Rufus King Park, is a historic house museum in Jamaica, Queens. This 18th-century home, once the estate of Rufus King, a U.S. Founding Father, offers a glimpse into the region's rich history. The museum showcases period furnishings and hosts various exhibits and programs, making it a fascinating destination for history enthusiasts.

pois.name: Museum of the Moving Image
pois.description: A museum devoted to, literally, moving images, so visitors will find exhibits on zoetropes and video games in addition to film and television. They also put on a terrific screening program, with films showing continuously throughout the day.

pois.name: Museum of Chinese in the Americas
pois.description: Exhibits on the history and culture of Chinese-Americans.

pois.name: Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum
pois.description: Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, located in the Andrew Carnegie Mansion on Manhattan's Upper East Side, is the only museum in the United States dedicated to historical and contemporary design. Part of the Smithsonian Institution, it offers a unique perspective on design aesthetics and creativity across U.S. history. Situated along Museum Mile, the museum provides a fascinating exploration of design through its collections and exhibitions. Unlike most Smithsonian museums, Cooper Hewitt charges an admission fee, making it a worthwhile stop for design enthusiasts visiting New York City.

pois.name: Whitney Museum of American Art
pois.description: Founded in 1931 and now in a stunning building in the Meatpacking District, the Whitney Museum is known for displaying contemporary American art even more up-to-date than the Museum of Modern Art. It is most famous for its long-standing tradition of hosting a biennial art show that displays many lesser-known artists new to the American art scene.

pois.name: Museum of Modern Art
pois.description: MoMA One of the greatest and most popular collections of modern art, on a par with the Tate Modern in London or Paris's Centre Georges Pompidou. Exceedingly popular so be warned: queues for tickets start early and stretch long. To avoid the crowds, turn up at the door ''at least'' a half hour before opening, then take the elevator to the top floor and work your way down. The building is as much a draw as the outstanding collection; possessing arguably the best collection of modern masterpieces world-wide, MoMA houses important art works from Van Gogh, Picasso, Monet, Matisse, Salvador Dalí, Paul Cézanne, Frida Kahlo, Piet Mondrian, and works by leading American artists such as Jackson Pollock, Jasper Johns, Edward Hopper, Andy Warhol, and Chuck Close. MoMA also holds renowned art photography and design collections. In addition to being the crown jewel of modern art museums, MoMA puts on a terrific repertory program in a nicely renovated theater below the museum.
pois.hours: Sa–Th 10AM–5:30PM, F 10:30AM–8PM, open until 9PM on first Thursday of the month and every Thursday Jul–Aug

pois.name: Museum of the City of New York
pois.description: Rather large, interesting museum with all kinds of documentation of events in the 400-year history of this city and delightful artifacts of life in earlier periods, such as the extensive collection of 19th-century dollhouses complete with miniature furniture.

pois.name: Nicholas Roerich Museum
pois.description: Nicholas Roerich Museum is dedicated to the life and work of the renowned Russian painter, philosopher, and cultural activist. The museum showcases Roerich's captivating paintings, which often explore spiritual and mystical themes. A true Renaissance man, Roerich was also a writer, archaeologist, and advocate for peace, earning him multiple Nobel Peace Prize nominations. His legacy includes the Roerich Pact, an international treaty for the protection of cultural heritage. Visitors can delve into his artistic journey and philosophical ideas, gaining insight into his global influence and enduring impact on art and culture. A must-visit for art lovers and history enthusiasts.

pois.name: Woolworth Building
pois.description: One of the oldest and most famous of New York's skyscrapers (dubbed the "Cathedral of Commerce"), the neo-Gothic Woolworth Building was completed in 1913 and was the world's tallest building until 1930. The building has a beautiful ornate lobby. Tours are offered most days. Pre-registration is required.

pois.name: Chrysler Building
pois.description: One of the most recognizable and favored structures of New York, the Chrysler was the world's tallest building when completed in 1930, but lost that title to the nearby Empire State Building less than a year later. But what it lost in fame it makes up for in beauty, with its gorgeous, instantly recognizable Art Deco crown.

pois.name: Flatiron Building
pois.description: An iconic building, considered the oldest remaining skyscraper in Manhattan, the Flatiron was completed in 1902. 285 ft (87 m) tall.

pois.name: Empire State Building
pois.description: A legend from the moment it was finished in 1931, the Empire State Building was easily the tallest building not just in New York, but the entire world for many years before being overtaken by another New York landmark - the twin towers of the World Trade Center. With the destruction of those two buildings, the Empire State Building was once again the tallest building in the city, but that lasted less than eleven years. But even though it's no longer the tallest, it remains iconic and one of the city's biggest tourist attractions. Expect ''long'' lines, and a lot of them - you'll have to wait in line to pass through a security checkpoint, wait in line to get tickets, wait in line for the elevators, and then make your way through the crowd on the outdoor observation deck on the 86th floor. One way to deal with the lines is to buy an express line ticket, which will bring you to the front of any line, but it will more than double the cost of your ticket. Another option is to visit very early in the day or late in the evening, when the lines will be considerably shorter. Despite the long lines and inevitable tourist kitsch, the views are excellent and the experience of being outdoors on top of New York City is a great one. Hawkers outside the building may try to tell you there is a very long line inside and that they can get you tickets to cut the line for some exorbitant price; before believing them, go inside and check the actual wait time which is clearly written on the electronic boards.

pois.name: 23 Wall Street
pois.description: Located across from the Stock Exchange is this imposing office building which was constructed in 1914 and served as the headquarters of JP Morgan. The Wall Street Bombing of September 16, 1920 damaged the building, with shrapnel blasting several holes in the limestone facade. The holes are still there for any to see.
pois.address: 26 Wall Street, New York, New York 10005, United States

pois.name: Grand Central Terminal
pois.description: Walk in and see the main concourse, a cavernous room often filled with people and elegantly detailed, with arched windows, a lovely clock, and an astronomical ceiling.
