pois.name: One World Trade Center
pois.description: The One World Trade Center skyscraper rises 1,776 feet above the street and is the tallest building in the United States (and for that matter, the Western Hemisphere). Despite its colossal size, its simple design allows it to blend remarkably well into the Lower Manhattan skyline. An observation deck on the top floors offers 360-degree views of the city.
pois.hours: Daily 9AM-8PM, open daily until midnight in the summer months; last ticket sold 45 min prior to close

pois.name: High Line Park
pois.description: Built on a defunct elevated railway that runs 30 feet above the streets, the re-purposing of the rail line as a park has made it the focus of major development in the neighborhood. There are plenty of plantings and art installations along the park as it winds its way between (and through!) buildings, and walking the stretch offers some pretty unique views over the streets of Manhattan. No dogs or bicycles. There are restrooms at Gansevoort St. (the southern terminus), 16th St, and 30th St.
pois.address: Runs mostly along 10th Avenue from 34th Street south to Gansevoort Street in the Meatpacking District, with access points at Gansevoort, 14th, 16th, 17th, 20th, 23rd, 26th, 28th, 30th, and 34th Streets
pois.hours: Open daily Apr–May, Oct–Nov: 7AM–10PM; June–Sept: 7AM–11PM; Dec–Mar: 7AM–7PM

pois.name: Flushing Meadows–Corona Park
pois.description: Flushing Meadows–Corona Park is a sprawling green oasis offering a serene escape from the city bustle. The park features two picturesque lakes, meandering walking paths, and expansive grassy areas ideal for picnics. Visitors can unwind, enjoy nature, and take in the scenic beauty. Spanning 897 acres, the park is perfect for those who love to explore on foot or by bike. Bicycle rentals are available near the north entrance, making it easy to discover all the park has to offer. Whether you're looking to relax or stay active, Flushing Meadows–Corona Park provides a welcoming space for all to enjoy.
pois.address: 17 Ederle Promenade, Forest Hills, New York 11375, United States

pois.name: Freshkills Park
pois.description: Only in the first stages of development, this mega-park is set to be 2,200 acres—three times the size of Central Park. It will cover the wild areas of the Fresh Kills, and the former Fresh Kills Dump. The first section of the park, '''Schmul Park''', in Travis, features a large and colorful playground for kids, along with basketball courts, handball courts, and an open grass field.

pois.name: Central Park Zoo
pois.description: Small and gem-like, New York's "oldest, newest zoo" opened in its current guise in 1988, although animals in various zoo incarnations have resided here since the 1860s. This zoo is fairly small and doesn't have as many large animals as you might expect, but this zoo does include sea lions, penguins, polar bears, monkeys, red pandas, and exotic birds in pleasant exhibits. Next door is a children's zoo, covered in the cost of admission, which has a barnyard animals you can pet, a duck pond, and lots of play areas for kids.
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Daily 10AM-4:30PM, Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa-Su, holidays 10AM-5:30PM

pois.name: Great Kills Park
pois.description: This park is home to a large woodland and a number of beaches. A small portion of the beach is closed for radiation screenings.
pois.address: 205 Buffalo Street, Staten Island, New York 10308, United States

pois.name: Prospect Park
pois.description: Established in 1867 and laid out by Olmsted and Vaux, the designers of Manhattan's Central Park.
pois.address: Center Drive, Brooklyn, New York 11215, United States

pois.name: The Greenbelt
pois.description: A humongous collection of woodlands and parks (2,800 acres!), the Greenbelt is a collection of nature you wouldn't expect to see in any major city, let alone New York. The Greenbelt covers much of the Mid-Island, so it's best to know which part you want to go to beforehand. A good place to start is the '''[http://sigreenbelt.org/nature-center/ Greenbelt Nature Center]''' an educational facility in the center of the park. The park is a great place for hikers, and a map of hiking trails can be found [http://sigreenbelt.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/2012trailmapcroppedfinaljpeg.jpg here]

pois.name: Metropolitan Museum of Art
pois.description: The Met One of the world's largest and most important museums of art and world culture, you'll have to devote several hours; nay, an entire ''day'' (if not more!), if you want to do this place justice. This massive neo-Gothic building, originally opened in 1872 and with numerous expansions added on over time, holds literally hundreds of rooms on its two floors, containing thousands of art pieces from across human history and around the world, covering virtually every field of art in existence, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Along with the numerous permanent exhibit halls mentioned below are several changing exhibit halls.

pois.name: Lower East Side Tenement Museum
pois.description: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, located in Manhattan's vibrant Lower East Side, offers a glimpse into the lives of immigrants who shaped New York City. Housed in two historic tenement buildings, the museum explores the stories of thousands of residents who called this place home over nearly 150 years. Through guided tours and exhibits, visitors gain insight into the challenges and resilience of these newcomers. The museum also serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of tolerance and understanding, highlighting the enduring legacy of immigration in America. A must-visit for history enthusiasts and anyone curious about the city's cultural roots.
pois.hours: Tu-F 11AM-6PM, Sa Su 10:45AM-6PM, M (visitor center only; no tours) 11AM-5:30PM

pois.name: High Line Park
pois.description: Built on a defunct elevated railway that runs 30 feet above the streets, the re-purposing of the rail line as a park has made it the focus of major development in the neighborhood. There are plenty of plantings and art installations along the park as it winds its way between (and through!) buildings, and walking the stretch offers some pretty unique views over the streets of Manhattan. No dogs or bicycles. There are restrooms at Gansevoort St. (the southern terminus), 16th St, and 30th St.
pois.address: Runs mostly along 10th Avenue from 34th Street south to Gansevoort Street in the Meatpacking District, with access points at Gansevoort, 14th, 16th, 17th, 20th, 23rd, 26th, 28th, 30th, and 34th Streets
pois.hours: Open daily Apr–May, Oct–Nov: 7AM–10PM; June–Sept: 7AM–11PM; Dec–Mar: 7AM–7PM

pois.name: Times Square
pois.description: A place filled with video screens, LED signs, and flashing lights; a world wonder or a tourist nightmare depending on your perspective, the "new" Times Square is a family-friendly theme park of themed restaurants, theaters and hotels, as well as a developing business district. The lights and signs can be viewed anytime, but the most enchanting experience comes when one visits Times Square at night, as all the signs and screens are ablaze with color. Times Square is also well known for its famous New Year's Eve ball drop. Those looking for the seedy Times Square of years past will find it around the Port Authority Bus Terminal, and on Eighth Avenue to the west.
pois.address: Broadway and 7th Avenue, stretching from 42nd to 48th Streets

pois.name: The Cloisters
pois.description: Located on four acres overlooking the Hudson River in Fort Tryon Park, the building incorporates elements from five medieval French cloisters – quadrangles enclosed by a roofed or vaulted passageway, or arcade – and from other monastic sites in southern France. There are various artworks on display in the museum, with the Unicorn Tapestries being the most famous.
pois.address: 99 Margaret Corbin Drive, Fort Tryon Park
pois.hours: Mar–Oct: daily 10 AM–5:15 PM; Nov–Feb: daily 10 AM–4:45 PM (closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year's Day)

pois.name: Museum of the Moving Image
pois.description: A museum devoted to, literally, moving images, so visitors will find exhibits on zoetropes and video games in addition to film and television. They also put on a terrific screening program, with films showing continuously throughout the day.

pois.name: Washington Square Park
pois.description: The park and its famous arch are located in the heart of the Village. Though located in the middle of an affluent neighborhood, the park attracts a hodgepodge of people. During the warmer months of the school term, the park is a favourite hangout spot for students from nearby NYU. Part of the charm of the park is the view of the buildings across the street. All these buildings are now owned by NYU, and though there has been some controversial construction in the early 2010s, most of the stately 19th-century dwellings pictured in the classic movie ''The Heiress'' (based on Henry James' novel, ''Washington Square'') are still there for you to enjoy looking at.
pois.address: 49-57 Washington Square South, New York, New York 10003, United States

pois.name: Balto Statue
pois.description: In Central Park stands a bronze statue honoring Balto, a heroic Alaskan husky. This sculpture by Frederick Roth commemorates Balto's pivotal role in the 1925 serum run to Nome, where he led a team of sled dogs to deliver life-saving diphtheria antitoxin. Balto's bravery during this mission made him a celebrated figure, symbolizing resilience and determination. The statue is a charming spot for visitors to pause and reflect on this remarkable tale of heroism.

pois.name: Chrysler Building
pois.description: One of the most recognizable and favored structures of New York, the Chrysler was the world's tallest building when completed in 1930, but lost that title to the nearby Empire State Building less than a year later. But what it lost in fame it makes up for in beauty, with its gorgeous, instantly recognizable Art Deco crown.

pois.name: Flatiron Building
pois.description: An iconic building, considered the oldest remaining skyscraper in Manhattan, the Flatiron was completed in 1902. 285 ft (87 m) tall.

pois.name: Children's Museum of the Arts
pois.description: Art and interactive exhibits geared towards children.

pois.name: El Museo del Barrio
pois.description: El Museo del Barrio, located at 1230 Fifth Avenue in Upper Manhattan, is a premier cultural destination showcasing Latin American and Caribbean art. Situated near the northern end of Museum Mile, it was founded in 1969 and is the oldest museum in the U.S. dedicated to Latino art. The museum highlights works from Puerto Rico and the Puerto Rican community in New York City, offering a rich exploration of their artistic heritage.

pois.name: Bethesda Terrace and Fountain
pois.description: Bethesda Terrace and Fountain are iconic architectural features in Central Park, offering stunning views of the Lake's southern shore. The centerpiece is the Angel of the Waters statue, surrounded by a beautiful fountain. The two-level terrace is connected by grand staircases and offers a seamless path to the Central Park Mall and Naumburg Bandshell. Crafted from New Brunswick sandstone with granite accents, the terrace features intricate stonework and herringbone-patterned brick paving. This historic landmark is a must-visit for its architectural beauty and picturesque surroundings, making it a perfect spot to relax and take in the park's natural charm.

pois.name: Williamsburg Art & Historical Center
pois.description: The Williamsburg Art & Historical Center, housed in the historic Kings County Savings Bank building, is a stunning example of French Second Empire architecture. Built in 1860, this landmark structure served as a bank for over a century before becoming a cultural hub in 1996. Designated as a New York City landmark in 1966 and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1980, the building showcases a rich history and architectural significance. Today, it offers a unique space for art and history, making it a fascinating destination for visitors exploring Brooklyn’s vibrant Williamsburg neighborhood.

pois.name: Whitney Museum of American Art
pois.description: Founded in 1931 and now in a stunning building in the Meatpacking District, the Whitney Museum is known for displaying contemporary American art even more up-to-date than the Museum of Modern Art. It is most famous for its long-standing tradition of hosting a biennial art show that displays many lesser-known artists new to the American art scene.

pois.name: Rockefeller Center
pois.description: The Christmas Tree, the Skating Rink, NBC Studios, the shops and hubbub - you can't miss it. The Christmas Tree and the Skating Rink are naturally not year round, but in the summer, the complex is a hub for touristy operations. Within the striking Art Deco buildings of the complex are several dining establishments overlooking the area and many stores.
pois.address: 32 West 49th Street, New York, New York 10020, United States

pois.name: Dakota Building
pois.description: This massive apartment building has been (and is!) home to many celebrities. Probably best known was the former Beatle John Lennon, who was gunned down outside the building on December 8, 1980, by a crazed fan. Lennon had been living at the Dakota with his second wife, Yoko Ono, who still resides in the building. A memorial to the former Beatle exists nearby in Central Park. The building has become a popular place of pilgrimage for many who admire Lennon.

pois.name: Central Park Zoo
pois.description: Small and gem-like, New York's "oldest, newest zoo" opened in its current guise in 1988, although animals in various zoo incarnations have resided here since the 1860s. This zoo is fairly small and doesn't have as many large animals as you might expect, but this zoo does include sea lions, penguins, polar bears, monkeys, red pandas, and exotic birds in pleasant exhibits. Next door is a children's zoo, covered in the cost of admission, which has a barnyard animals you can pet, a duck pond, and lots of play areas for kids.
pois.hours: Nov-Mar: Daily 10AM-4:30PM, Apr-Oct: M-F 10AM-5PM, Sa-Su, holidays 10AM-5:30PM

pois.name: Daily News Building
pois.description: This Art Deco design classic, completed in 1930 to a design by Raymond Hood, was made famous by the ''Superman'' films; to be admired are the extreme verticality of the design, the understated setbacks and functional design. The newspaper no longer holds offices here, but the foyer is well worth a visit if passing, if only to see the newspaper's giant globe sculpture and wall weather stations.

pois.name: Brooklyn Museum
pois.description: Housed in a 560,000-square-foot, Beaux-Arts building, the Brooklyn is the 2nd largest art museum in New York City and one of the largest in the USA. Its world-renowned permanent collections include more than one million objects, from ancient Egyptian masterpieces to contemporary art, and represent a wide range of cultures. It is a 30-minute subway ride from Midtown Manhattan, and has its own subway station (renovated in 2019-20), the museum is part of a complex of 19th-century parks and gardens that also includes Prospect Park, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and the Prospect Park Zoo. On the first Saturday of each month, the museum is open until 11PM with free admission and special events.

pois.name: Empire State Building
pois.description: A legend from the moment it was finished in 1931, the Empire State Building was easily the tallest building not just in New York, but the entire world for many years before being overtaken by another New York landmark - the twin towers of the World Trade Center. With the destruction of those two buildings, the Empire State Building was once again the tallest building in the city, but that lasted less than eleven years. But even though it's no longer the tallest, it remains iconic and one of the city's biggest tourist attractions. Expect ''long'' lines, and a lot of them - you'll have to wait in line to pass through a security checkpoint, wait in line to get tickets, wait in line for the elevators, and then make your way through the crowd on the outdoor observation deck on the 86th floor. One way to deal with the lines is to buy an express line ticket, which will bring you to the front of any line, but it will more than double the cost of your ticket. Another option is to visit very early in the day or late in the evening, when the lines will be considerably shorter. Despite the long lines and inevitable tourist kitsch, the views are excellent and the experience of being outdoors on top of New York City is a great one. Hawkers outside the building may try to tell you there is a very long line inside and that they can get you tickets to cut the line for some exorbitant price; before believing them, go inside and check the actual wait time which is clearly written on the electronic boards.

pois.name: Friedsman Carousel
pois.description: A vintage carousel built in 1908 and situated on this spot since the 1950s, it's the fourth carousel to inhabit this location and is beautifully painted.
pois.hours: Apr-Oct: Daily 10AM-6PM (weather permitting); Nov-Mar: hours vary, check ahead

pois.name: Museum of Modern Art
pois.description: MoMA One of the greatest and most popular collections of modern art, on a par with the Tate Modern in London or Paris's Centre Georges Pompidou. Exceedingly popular so be warned: queues for tickets start early and stretch long. To avoid the crowds, turn up at the door ''at least'' a half hour before opening, then take the elevator to the top floor and work your way down. The building is as much a draw as the outstanding collection; possessing arguably the best collection of modern masterpieces world-wide, MoMA houses important art works from Van Gogh, Picasso, Monet, Matisse, Salvador Dalí, Paul Cézanne, Frida Kahlo, Piet Mondrian, and works by leading American artists such as Jackson Pollock, Jasper Johns, Edward Hopper, Andy Warhol, and Chuck Close. MoMA also holds renowned art photography and design collections. In addition to being the crown jewel of modern art museums, MoMA puts on a terrific repertory program in a nicely renovated theater below the museum.
pois.hours: Sa–Th 10AM–5:30PM, F 10:30AM–8PM, open until 9PM on first Thursday of the month and every Thursday Jul–Aug

pois.name: Museum of the City of New York
pois.description: Rather large, interesting museum with all kinds of documentation of events in the 400-year history of this city and delightful artifacts of life in earlier periods, such as the extensive collection of 19th-century dollhouses complete with miniature furniture.

pois.name: Grand Army Plaza
pois.description: A public square at the southeast corner of the park which marks one of the primary entrances to Central Park. The square is named for the Union Army of the Civil War and sports a gilded bronze statue of Union General William Sherman and the Pulitzer Fountain, which is crowned with a bronze figure of Pomona, the Roman goddess of fruit.

pois.name: USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center
pois.description: Home of the '''U.S. Open''' and also the largest public tennis facility in the world. It features 3 stadium courts, 9 indoor courts, and 14 outdoor courts that are available to the public year-round.
pois.address: 122-12 Roosevelt Ave, Corona, New York 11368, United States

pois.name: American Museum of Natural History
pois.description: Holding a remarkably large collection, each of the 5 floors of this massive building has expansive and well-designed exhibits devoted to astronomy, biology, geology, anthropology, climatology, and paleontology. You will want to allow a full day if you hope to see the entirety of the museum. Some of the highlights are the '''Rose Center for Earth and Space''' on the northeast corner of the building, which contains a seven-story glass cube holding the Hayden Planetarium, a huge sphere suspended above the exhibit halls below and holding a "cosmic pathway" exhibit; the numerous '''habitat diorama''' halls on the first, second and third floors, with recreations of African, Asian, North American, and ocean plants and animals, including a full-size model of a Blue Whale suspended above the Ocean Life Hall; a '''Hall of Minerals and Gems''', which contains many rare and beautiful specimens, including the largest star sapphire in the world and a chunk of a massive meteorite; extensive '''anthropology halls''' on the first, second, and third floors, with exhibits devoted to people of Asia, Africa, Central America, the Pacific, and Native Americans; and the '''natural history halls''' on the fourth floor, with one of the largest collections of dinosaur skeletons in the world.
pois.address: Central Park West between 77th and 81st Streets (entire block)

pois.name: Grand Central Terminal
pois.description: Walk in and see the main concourse, a cavernous room often filled with people and elegantly detailed, with arched windows, a lovely clock, and an astronomical ceiling.

pois.name: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum
pois.description: Probably the most famous of the Guggenheim foundations (others found in Bilbao and Venice), which hold avant-garde modern art by artists such as Kandinsky and Mondrian, the New York branch is housed in a unique and famous building designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and rendered in a rounded, organic form and completed in 1959. Be sure to take the elevator to the top floor, then follow the spiral viewing floors downwards to the street level. One of eight buildings by Wright to be listed as a world heritage site.

pois.name: Strawberry Fields
pois.description: So named in 1981 in memory of John Lennon, the former Beatle, who was murdered close by outside his home in the Dakota building. Lennon's widow Yoko Ono, who still lives in the Dakota, subsequently donated $1 million to upgrade the area with hundreds of tree and flower species, including strawberries. The area serves as a Garden of Peace and includes a memorial floor mosaic (donated by the Italian city of Naples) that says simply "Imagine", referring to the title of one of Lennon's evocative songs.

pois.name: Metropolitan Museum of Art
pois.description: The Met One of the world's largest and most important museums of art and world culture, you'll have to devote several hours; nay, an entire ''day'' (if not more!), if you want to do this place justice. This massive neo-Gothic building, originally opened in 1872 and with numerous expansions added on over time, holds literally hundreds of rooms on its two floors, containing thousands of art pieces from across human history and around the world, covering virtually every field of art in existence, but controversially including many items that were looted from their places of origin. Along with the numerous permanent exhibit halls mentioned below are several changing exhibit halls.

pois.name: Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine
pois.description: The world's largest neo-Gothic cathedral, the place has been a work in progress for over a century! There are also resident peacocks on campus, and many songbirds stop by during their seasonal migrations.

pois.name: Willowbrook Park
pois.description: Willowbrook Park, located in Staten Island’s Willowbrook neighborhood, is a 164-acre green space within the Staten Island Greenbelt. This expansive park offers a variety of recreational activities, including baseball fields, a playground, and a serene pond. Visitors of all ages can enjoy the charming carousel, which was added in 1999. The park also provides a glimpse into the area’s history, as the former Staten Island Hotel is visible from its grounds. With its mix of natural beauty and family-friendly amenities, Willowbrook Park is a delightful destination for both locals and visitors exploring Staten Island.
pois.address: Eton Place at Richmond Avenue or Victory Boulevard at Morani Street

pois.name: National September 11 Memorial & Museum
pois.description: World Trade Center site - note that the term 'Ground Zero' is never used by New Yorkers On the site of the former World Trade Center towers, the memorial consists of two enormous waterfalls and reflecting pools set within the footprints of the twin towers, lined with bronze panels with the names of the nearly 3,000 victims of that fateful day inscribed. The surrounding plaza holds a grove of trees. The museum, which sits underground right next to the memorial, contains exhibits which explain the events of 9/11 and their aftermath, with remnants of the original towers and artifacts from that day. If you see a white rose on one of the names, it's because today is that victim's birthday.
pois.hours: Memorial: 7:30AM-9PM daily; museum: Su-Th 9AM-8PM, F Sa 9AM-8PM, last museum entry 2 hours before closing

pois.name: Conservatory Pond
pois.description: Most well known as the Model Boat Pond, visitors can often see a racing regatta between members of the Model Yacht Club, or rent a model boat from a boathouse and cafe on the pond. Just to the north of the pond is the '''Alice in Wonderland''' sculpture depicting the Tea Party scene, and on the west side of the pond is the '''Hans Christian Andersen''' sculpture, which shows the writer seated on a bench reading a book to his ''Ugly Duckling'' character.

pois.name: One World Trade Center
pois.description: The One World Trade Center skyscraper rises 1,776 feet above the street and is the tallest building in the United States (and for that matter, the Western Hemisphere). Despite its colossal size, its simple design allows it to blend remarkably well into the Lower Manhattan skyline. An observation deck on the top floors offers 360-degree views of the city.
pois.hours: Daily 9AM-8PM, open daily until midnight in the summer months; last ticket sold 45 min prior to close

pois.name: New York by Gehry
pois.description: A 2011 addition to the Lower Manhattan skyline, this 76-story residential skyscraper by the noted Frank Gehry has a distinctive rippled, "wavy" facade that is quite eye-catching. It is best viewed from City Hall Park and the Brooklyn Bridge.

pois.name: Brooklyn Bridge
pois.description: From its intersection with Park Row (just east of City Hall) you can walk (takes about 20-30 minutes each way), bike, or drive across the historic and iconic bridge to Brooklyn. The view from the bridge is quite lovely, with excellent views of Lower Manhattan and Downtown Brooklyn and good views of Midtown and the New York Harbor in the distance.
pois.address: Brooklyn Bridge, Manhattan, New York 10273, United States

pois.name: Manhattan School of Music
pois.description: Another conservatory of music.
pois.address: 3081 Broadway, New York, New York 10027, United States

pois.name: Fordham College at Lincoln Center
pois.description: Fordham College at Lincoln Center, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is a vibrant academic and cultural hub within Fordham University. This campus offers a unique blend of educational excellence and artistic expression, situated near the renowned Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Visitors can explore the campus's modern facilities while being just steps away from New York City's iconic landmarks. The campus embodies the dynamic spirit of NYC, providing students and visitors alike with a stimulating environment that fosters both learning and cultural enrichment.

pois.name: Grant's Tomb
pois.description: General Grant National Memorial General Ulysses S. Grant and his wife are buried in this imposing mausoleum, the largest tomb in North America. If you come when it is closed, you can still see the impressive facade, but coming during open hours gives you the opportunity to view the murals, the tomb and various documentation inside. Across Riverside Drive, there is a viewpoint to look across the Hudson River, a museum, gift shop and restrooms.

pois.name: Fraunces Tavern
pois.description: Fraunces Tavern, located in Lower Manhattan’s Financial District, is a historic museum and restaurant that played a significant role in American history. Once the headquarters of George Washington and a site for peace negotiations during the American Revolution, it now offers a glimpse into the past. The building, conjecturally reconstructed in the early 20th century, is believed to be Manhattan’s oldest surviving structure. Visitors can explore its museum, enjoy dining, and appreciate its designation as a National Historic Landmark. Part of the American Whiskey Trail and New York Freedom Trail, Fraunces Tavern is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and travelers alike.

pois.name: Statue of Liberty
pois.description: "Liberty Enlightening the World" One of the most famous and iconic landmarks in the USA, if not the world. A gift from the people of France to celebrate the centennial of the United States, stands upon Liberty Island and is one of the most famous symbols of the nation and has been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage list. Upon departing the ferry, you can visit the Visitor Information Station, which has a schedule of the day's events. Visitors can also meet at the Liberty Island Flagpole (behind the statue) for a ranger-led tour of the island. You can also visit the monument lobby, museum (where you'll see various exhibits on the statue, the old torch, and the famous "New Colossus" sonnet), and outside to the promenade and Fort Wood (the 11-point star-shaped structure the statue stands upon). You can also take a trip to the pedestal observation deck (though not up into the statue itself, unless you have a Reserve with Crown ticket); visitors can look upward to view the interior of the statue (there are four marked viewing locations); and the pedestal observation deck provides a 360-degree view, which includes the New York City skyline. Security checks are rigorous, so travel as light as possible. Backpacks and other large bags are not permitted on the tours but can be stored in lockers for a fee. On busy days there may be long waits. Visitors with the Reserve with Crown ticket are allowed to climb up a circular staircase from the base of the statue to the '''crown''', but tickets are very limited and should be reserved three or four months (up to one year) in advance. Children must be at least 4-feet tall, and must be able to walk up and down the stairs by themselves, and all ticket holders must show a photo ID to match the name on their tickets. The design of Lady Liberty's torch evokes the universal symbol of enlightenment, which lights the way to freedom, showing immigrants the path to liberty and justice.
pois.address: 1 Liberty Island Ellis, New York, New York 10004, United States

pois.name: Ellis Island
pois.description: Ellis Island was home to the nation's primary federal immigration station, with over 12 million immigrant steamship passengers passing through from its opening in 1892 to its closing in 1954. Today, over 40 percent of America's population can trace their ancestry through Ellis Island. The island is home to the '''[http://www.ellisisland.org/ American Family Immigration History Center]''', which contains manifests of 25 million immigrants, passengers, and crew members who entered New York Harbor. The Immigration museum at Ellis Islands has details about "Peopling of America" and if you are an avid history lover, this museum will need at least 3-4 hrs of your time. Since the ferry ride takes you to both Ellis Island as well as the Liberty Island, you will have to plan your day well.
pois.address: 1 Ellis Island Bridge, Jersey City, New Jersey 07305, United States
